Bottle. Pours hazy mahogany, finely formed creamy head. Sour aroma of undefined fruit. Taste is slightly sour with body. Great beer.

Poured a hazy brown with nice frothy head.  Big Yeast aroma with sweet sugar and slight banana tones and brown sugar.  Taste is medium sweetness,with some spice.  Medium body, creamy and slick texture, ave carbonation.  Another complex beer by St Bern.  Smooth taste, great aroma.   The alchohol balances out the sweetness nicely.

Bottle @ Home. Pours deep amber with a fluffy white head that setles down to a ring of foam. Aroma of sweet bread, biscuet, fruit, yeast. Taste is yeast, biscuet, bready malt, plums, raisins, sugar, very nice. Medium body, low carbonation, silky mouthfeel. Nice belgian dubbel, and for the price and very good buy. 270311

The beer is dark brown with a light tan head. The head rises about 3 fingers, falling quickly to leave a soapy head. As it falls it leaves a trail of lacing down the side of the glass. 

The aroma is medium in strength with lots of malts, bready, biscuity, yeasty/clovey. There is also a little alcohol and at the end some sweetness. Lots going on, very complex.

The taste is pretty sweet, but not a ton of flavor, unlike the aroma. Its pretty bready.

The feel is a little to watery for me, but good drinkability. 

Overall, this is ok, not a great dubbel, subpar St. Bernardus beer.
Dark brown. Dark fruit and sugary aroma. Taste is rich Belgian fruitiness and brown sugar. Excellent dubbel.

Bottle.Pours brown with a big off-white head.Aroma of caramel, yeast, brown sugar, spice and licorice.Flavor is sweet and malty with some caramel and dried fruits.Medium body, dry finfish, lively carbonation.
Excellent medium brown color. Smooth and clean taste. Can see why this is the highest rated dubbel.

This brewery makes awesome beer, the mix 6 pack is awesome.

Nice pour, dark brown, very bubbly, and thick.

Smell is sweet and fruity with an element of yeast.

Flavor is rich, caramel, sweet and fruity.  Smooth and complex, slightly bitter and an element of yeast as well.  Abv not detected.  Has a Belgian Farmhouse element to it as well.

Awesome.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */: not too crazy about this one, taste is too heavy on overripe fruits, coupled with non-sweet malts, caramel, nuts, dried dark fruits, minor liquorice & the alcohol is not masked enough, showing itself in the taste, it is a bit like the small elements that worked nicely in their Abt 12 because too expressive in this one, like the overripe fruits, destroyed the balance, a distinctly lesser version of the Abt 12

Clear red brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty, dried fruit and yeasty. Flavor is rather sweet and moderate bitter. Light bitter and sweet finish with a hint of warming alcohol. Soft and smooth. Complex with a great balance. 300110

Pours medium brown with a big, foamy, light brown head. Nose is moderately sweet with brown sugar, belgian yeast, and a little alcohol. Flavor is similar and very rich, which the usual brown maltiness and spice tinge expected for the style, juxtaposed in excellent balance. Its not particularly unique but it does exactly what a dubbel should do and does it very well.

Bottled from Bierkompass. Chestnut brown color with thick white head. Aroma is fruity, honey and some spices. Taste, spicy, fruity, honey with nice bittersweet finish. Another good St. Bernardus beer.

Tap.  Pours clear brown with an average, frothy beige head, medium retention with good lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (bread, cookie, caramel, toasted, dark fruit), light hops (herbal), and average esters (fruity) with notes of bubble gum, raisin, dates, cola, and nutmeg.  Flavor is heavy malt (bread, cookie, caramel, toasted, dark fruit), light hops (earthy), and average esters (fruity) with notes of wood, alcohol, dates, and honey.  Full body, medium warmth, carbonation, and creaminess with a medium sweet finish.

Ahhh... St. Bernardus Abby Ale, this will be a treat.

Pours into my Duvel glass with a wild foamy off white head and deep brown body with hints of red. Lacing is spotted.

Strong banana bread scent, along with some citrus. Theres also dark fruits, sugar, alcohol, and some spice. Beautiful complex scent.

Body is smooth, the carbonation and alcohol slightly pinch the tongue adding depth to the mouthfeel, though it is a bit too prickly. There are some very nice dark fruits, great muffinlike malt, good sweetness, but not cloying, some good spice. The yeast and malt are stars here, exquisite.

Overall an excellent beer, it seems slightly better along side some food.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-06-2009 04:07:28
yet again another aweslome st.brenaurdaus beer fruity arom a ad dark fruit taste smooth light carbonation

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2011 Bottle. Upon opening, the smell is heavy fruits - mostly grapes/raisins and plums. Taste is full the same fruits, a little boozy, and some nice yeast. Pours a nice dark amber color with a 1 head in my trappist glass. Great stuff all around.

Cloudy brown pour, almost the color of a light coffee, though edging towards orange.  Good foamy head, dissipated slowly.  Light malty aroma with a hint of spice.  The taste follows the aroma, with a good balance of malt, sweetness, and spice, that lingers without feeling like it coats the tongue.  I really like this one.

330ml Bottle from Bierzwerg.  Pours a rich opaque brown color with two fingers of head that has some gorgeous lacing.  Aroma is sweet, dried fruits especially plum and raisin, and yeast.  Taste is complimentary with a prominent dried fruit flavors, along with spice, doughy yeast, and alcohol esters.  Very smooth on the palate, medium-bodied, sweet-bitter balanced aftertaste.  Nice Dubbel.

Le liquide dévoile une robe brune.  La tête mousseuse est petite mais séduisante.  Le nez permet de découvrir des arômes maltés caramélisés avec des effluves de bonbons aux raisins.  Lalcool a un souffle légèrement poivré et un aspect floral particulier.  Une pointe épicée semble se dessiner davantage au fil de la dégustation.  Le goût est dominé par un sucré de malt au profil caramélisé mais aussi subtilement chocolaté avec des saveurs évidentes et agréables de raisins.  En bouche, le liquide a un corps moyen avec une effervescence active qui donne une texture somme toute crémeuse.  La finale se fait sur des notes douces avec un alcool tiède et une amertume fantomatique.
Bottle. Power packed aroma of plums, Belgian yeast, and roasted marshmallows. Delicious stuff with some raisins, candied sugar, leather, and only a slight alcohol warmth. A perfect, strong Dubbel.

33cl bottle. Ive had this sitting in my cupboard for a year or two now. It slowly bubbled out of the bottle while I wasnt looking though I managed to catch it just in time for it to pour a murky, particulate ruddy brown colour with an initial two finger beige head that faded to a lasting layer of creamy foam leaving a light lace. Raisin, yeast, some chocolate and alcohol on the aroma. Sweet & juicy boozy raisins, figs, Belgian yeast, chocolate, a touch of brown sugar and a tangy edge on the tongue. Finishes dry with a short dark fruit skin and alcohol bitterness. Soft, medium body, delicate carbonation and some heat in the throat. Best before 25/11/13.

well this was a treat. Nice pour with a thin head. I smell figs and white grapes, but the color would suggest otherwise. The head will dissipate evenly through the drink. Full bodied and a little sticky at the end, but all very pleasing. Beautiful brown cloud with a red tone. I will have this one again.

Pours hazy dark brown with a great rich tanned head leaving nice lacing. Aroma is malty, bready, sweet, dark fruits, fidges, yeast and alcohol. Fullbodied crispy mouthfeel. Flavor is fruity, malty, velvety lean but still crispy, dark fruits, alcohol and hops. Yet another beer with great balance in flavor mixture. Alcoholy bitter hoppy palate. Finishes with a great longlived dry tart aftertaste.
pours a dark brown with a carmel head, thick lacing.  Aroma is malty, almost sour, lightly citrus and roasty.  Taste is sweet.  Palate is complex, long, thick, medium carbonaiton, full bodied.

Appearance:  cloudy medium brown; big foamy/creamy head.  Aroma:  similar to the Pater 6, but a little richer, with some added fruits (cherries?) in syrup.  Taste:  crisp, slightly bitter dark spices (pepper, clove, anise), smooth caramel and brown sugar.  Finish:  dry, smooth and clean; the tingly carbonation lingers.  Notes:  A very nice dubbel.  As it warmed, it got a little sweeter.  This was lighter in color and palate than some of the other dubbels, but it was solid.

UPDATED: APR 27, 2014 Appearance: Deep redish brown. Hazy. Lots of light tan head. Some sediments.
Aroma: Malt and fruit. Some yeast.
Taste: Malt and dark fruit. Warming. Slight alcohol. Nice.
Info: 330ml bottle, 14/1-2011, 35/300M

Bottle 330ml. Masterpiece. Aromas of caramel, grass, butter, and alcohol. Taste is bittersweet, with very long length. Palate is velvety, almost creamy, with a full body. Brown, the head doesnt last all the way.

11.2 oz bottle poured into a goblet.

3.5 A: Murky dark brown color. Two fingers of frothy off-white head with below average lacing and modest lacing. Some yeast clumps at the bottom.

4.0 S: Earthy and yeasty. Some dark fruits including plum and raisin. Good overall, just wish it was more intense.

4.0 T: Its good, but run-of-the-mill in its flavor and depth. Lots of raisin and plum flavor and a touch of tobacco. Caramel malts and brown sugar. Touch of yeastiness to boot.

4.0 M: Medium body. Good bubbly carbonation. Creamy.

4.0 D: Pretty good, not spectacular.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-14-2009 20:10:08
Molto probabilmente devo aver beccato una bottiglia (75 cl), non proprio eccellente, perchè ho trovato questa Prior ( che avevo sentito parlar molto bene) niente di incredibile...
31st January 2008  Dark brown ale. Very creamy head. Crisp and fruity but also slighty creamy beer. Nice.
Malty, sweet, spicy, caramel in aroma. Nice head. Sweet taste. Lively carbonated, like sparkling wine. Overall it tastes like Westmalle Dubbel.
Dark ruby with as thin white head. Very sweet in taste with a nice fizz on tongue. Dark fruits and caramel. Rather nice indeed.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy brown with redish/purplish hues.  It has a thin off ehite/tan froathy head with nice lacing.  Aroma is sweet malts with bread, dark fruits, brown sugar, carmel, and alcohol notes.  Palate is heavily carbonated.  Flavor is sweet, finishing dry.

aroma: nutty, bread, caramel with belgian yeast. maybe some raisin and vanilla.
appearance: red brown in color, hazy to clear, tan head
taste: medium sweetness, light bitter, with raisins and figs but lightly
palate: med to full bodied, average carbonation, good finish.
drinkable beer, but more of a sipper.
Hazy brown,small beige head.Faint malt sweetness in nose.Medium bodied sweet malt profile with winey hints. Medium hop finish. Not much here, disappointing

Hazy and dark brown witha  puffy, resilient off-white head. Aroma of caramel, yeast, fruit and alcohol. Tastes mostly sweet and yeasty with a slight alcohol and hop presence. Slightly warming, but smooth, full bodied and finishes dry. Excellent, a favorite.
330ml bottle.  Pours a hazy dark brown with a large frothy head.  Aroma is caramel malt, some raisin.  Bready malt start.  Caramel malt in the finish with some apple.  A bit thin.

Medium caramel color with a thin creamy head that just barely covers the pour.  Aroma of yeast and spices, flavor is caramel and raisins with a malty finish.  Chest warming alcohol that is welcome on a cold December night with blizzard conditions outside!

Poured into a St. Bernardus trappist glass. Appearance: Pours a deep brown with a one to two finger creamy tan head that lingers around on top and leaves nice lacing. Aroma: deep malty aroma with fruity alcohol notes that tickle the nose. Taste: malty sweet with light toast notes and plenty of raisin and dark fruits like fig. Alcohol notes as well as some light flowery hops serve to balance the sweetness. Finish is dry but leaves a creamy feel in the mouth. Well balanced for the abv. Overall: not much to complain about, big and malty but well balanced with a great finish.

Hazy brown with huge beige head that lasts forever. Lot of Belgian lace. Aroma is roasty malts, raisins, and yeast. Medium to full bodied, sweet malt, and light hop backdrop provides nice contrast. Texture is stcky like raw yeasty dough. Finish is very long and complex, starting out slightly sweet, but finishing firm with the slightest astringency.

Pours a dark ruddy color with a brown foamy head.  Rich sweet malts and deep dark fruits are caught up in the aroma.  Some baked cookies and raisins are also in the nose.  The rich fruits are very notable upfront in the palate.  Some baked cookies on the palate as well.  A long dry finish ends nicely.
Pours a dark brown with a white head.  Aromas of plums and raisins. Lively carbonation. Sweet to acidic. Nice beer.

33cl bottle from bierzwerg. Poured dark brown with a frothy head. Aroma is quite yeasty and spicy with some dark fruity notes. Flavor is malt, spices yeast and sugar. Finish is slightly alcohol warming with a smooth and nice palate. Nice dubbel.

750ml Bottle, sampled in a large Gulden Draak tulip and a St. Bernies trappist glass, 
pours a dark red-ruby with dark brown at the edges, gave a large one to two finger off-white foamy bubbled head, and left lots of bubbly lacing on the sides when the glass, the effervescence is good and strong in this beer, 
this ale had aromas of dark fruit  raisin and  prunes, with light toasted malt, bread, provided faint spice hints in the background, and a little alcohol esters, 

flavors consisted of toasted malt, dried fruit, bread, little caramel and chocolate in the background, there is a bread and caramel sweetness,
there was a little pepper after the finish, esters and malt flavors trailing after the finish, 

mouth feel is about medium with a nice creamy texture on the palate, light and airy, 

a nice Dubbel drink

Bottle. Dark, brown, average and mostly lasting light brown head. Medium, malty and sweetish aroma, caramel and some herbal spiciness. Body is medium, malty and sweetish flavor, toffee and light spiciness. Finish is average, malty and sweetish, some alcohol. Sweet strong ale with toffee aroma/flavor  too much  for me.
Mahogany pour from bottle with an off-white head. Aroma is molasses and chocolate.  Taste is yeast, raisins and some vanilla.  Nice, even finish.  Solid.

Tutti frutti, bread. Taste has both sweetness of malts and a backup dryness from the hops. Aftertaste is long lasting. Good taste development. Very good beer (maybe just not as good as the other Bernardus beers).
Hazy brown colour with a quick dissipating head. Spicy, malty aroma. Deep malty flavour.

head: bubbly, beige 
colour: dark brown 
smell: vintage, watery, malts, licqourice 
taste: vintage skunky wooden sweet and malty start, high carbonation, caramel and chocolat afterwards, stingy alcohol in end, aftertaste is dry

33cl bottle poured into a Chimay Trappist glass.  Dark brown with a large tan head.  Aroma is brown sugar, slight bread.  Flavor is toasted malt, brown sugar, some bread.  Very sweet, very smooth, silky.  Medium body, light carbonation.  Finish is soft, bready, slightly dry, lasting.  Very good brew.  Excellent example of a dubbel.

Poured a murky brown with an unbelievably large head. Scent is like a malty fruit basket, over ripe. Some spice. Taste is sweet fruit, berries, some yeast with spices and a hint of malts. Very pleasing and more so as it warms. I continue to be impressed with this brewerys offerings.

330ml bottle pours a very murky red to brown beer with great body. Aroma starts off with very heavy yeast and bread notes with some sugar. Appearance is amazing from the deep body that fills my glass to the semi thick off white head that stays around for the whole beer. Taste is heavy with yeast and a somewhat alcohol finish. Overall a great beer that is very pleasing. This brewery remains one of my faviort of all times.

Pours a dark brown with some chestnut coloring and a nice tan head with some good legs as it goes down my tulip. Smell is dark fruits with a good amount of caramel and some dark candied sugars. Taste is not quite as refined, with yeast character really beginning to dominate. Mouthfeel is nice and rich without too much heat. Quite creamy. Drinkability is quite good. Did this as part of the entire St. Bernardus lineup, and this was one of my favorites; though, to be fair, I suppose all of them were quite good.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-24-2010
33 cl bottle, pours dark with a decent head and slight lacings, aroma of malt, yeast and dark fruits, taste is pretty much the same as the aroma, smooth mouthfeel, decent finish, great beer overall.
Small, off white head. Dark brown in appearance. Slight yeast scent, hops come through in the taste. Fairly carbonated, tasty brew.

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2013 Cloudy brown pour.  Fizzy head that dissipated in my Saint Bernardus chalice.  The yeasty aroma is a bit disappointing.  Fairly sweet, malty brown ale with a Belgian edge.  Some brown sugar and yeast.   I wonder if it really is made by monks in the Belgique countryside.  This is a good ale and could be an excellent session brew, but I am surprised to see it is the #1 dubbel.
mostly amber malt and abbey yeast character, with a bright tart note. i did not get much depth or complexity out of it. on the less interesting end of the belgian spectrum.

11.2 oz bottle from Tournament.  Deep brown colored pour, a couple fingers of eggshell colored head that leaves great lacing..  Nice dark fruit aromas and flavors with a smooth & creamy mouthfeel.  Finish is a bit dry.  Not one of my favorite dubbels but still very good.
Dark murky brown colour with average tan head. Mildish dark fruits, plums, raisins and dark malt in aroma. Dark malty fruity flavour with raisins, raisins and alcohol. Alcohols warming big time.
Deep brown in color with a thick brown head. Prunes, Apricots and sweet malts in the nose. Soft in texture. Sweet prunes on the palate, that ends with a slight hop bitterness.
Nice Dubbel! Pours brown with tan head. Nose is all Belgian spices and candi sugar. Notes of dark fruits, prunes, apricots, plums. Finishes clean and is not too sweet.

Bottle poured into its own St. Bernardus trappist glass. 

Appearance: Brown with slightest yellow hue. visibly thick. finger thick tan head. everything  you want from a dubbel.
Aroma: not my favorite part of this beer. musty earthy smell with noticable alcohol. Also deep notes of brown sugar molassas and dark fruits.
Taste: malts and bread. very sweet
Palate: full body, creamy texture. The finish is short but I love the taste the beer leaves in your mouth. nothing lacking

Not the best dubbel I have ever had but it is up there. Selling point is the taste. although the palate is pretty darn good as well. I enjoyed the creaminess of the texture. A very enjoyable beer

Pours very dark, classic Dubbel colour with a big tan fluffy head that diminishes slowly and leaves a thick but not dense film. 
Aroma is complex and intensely malty with deep notes of molasses, raisins and brown sugar, spiced up with some clove, belgian chocolate, chestnuts and some liquor.
Flavor is pretty sweet with an interesting evolution in the mouth. The molasses sweetness starts to develop and finishes full on christmas cookies, dresdner stollen and clove flavors. 
Body is heavy but smooth and agreeable. This is one of the most powerful Dubbels ive tried. Low carbonation, warming alcohol and fantastic aftertaste. On par with Westmalle Dubbel... great.
Pours beautifully, nice and dark, and wafts a complex and rich aroma. As far as flavor goes, the packaging pretty much nails it with "heavenly nectar." Probably the best trappist beer of its style.

Pours dark with a full off-white head, slowly dissipating as it settles. Laces the side of the glass as you drink.  The smell is nothing special. Definitely get the alcohol, along with malts and some spiciness.  Tasting the malts up front, definitely followed by the spiciness, but doesnt finish well. Ill echo the dry aftertaste.  I could drink this beer all night, but the ABV (and price in Central PA) say otherwise. Also, Id rather take the abt 12 day in and day out.

Drank an 11.2oz bottle.Appearance: typical Belgian dark beer: rusty brown color with huge yeast chunks. Huge, frothy, tan head which stuck around to the end - nice.Aroma: similar to a red wine, but not as strong. Surprisingly mild. Fruity. Touch of alcohol in the nose.Taste: This beer started out strong with a robust and complex palate of dark fruit (cherry, plum, fig) and even a bittersweet chocolate which was an pleasant surprise. Creamy texture, too. However, as it warmed it seemed to thin out and become watery and bland. Thats the opposite Id expect from a Belgian bottle-condition beer. Mouthfeel: not very intense, but much more mild than a Belgian should be. Seems to thin out the more I drink.Drinkability: rather low. This beer is so effervescent its hard not to burp every 2 seconds. Overall: Started out loving this beer, but it just couldnt go the whole nine yards. Ill split the difference and call it good.

NOTE: Watch the video version of this review at:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2ppbTrSCTsE

Dark amber/cider color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of sweet malt, yeast, dark fruit, toffee, & spice; Flavor of sweet malt, yeast, dark fruit (notably plums), raisons, caramel, and spice; Very nicely balanced & complex; An excellent dubbel.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2011 Poured into a large snifter. Appearance is a hazy brown with an offwhite head that looked to come with a nice dusting of paprika. Aroma is very malty and sweet with notes of nuts and milk chocolate. Body is very creamy and easy to drink. Overall this is a very nice beer from one of the best brewers in the world. Well done St. Bernardus. I look forward to the remainder of your offerings.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2011 Bottiglia da 33 comprata dal Besagnino. Spero fosse andata, era  davvero imbevibile, sarà che ste dubbel a me non convincono mica con tutti questi sapori di alcohol, banana, bubblegum, butterscotch, clove, cooked vegetables, cough drop, ginger, licorice, raisin, rotten eggs, cough drop, soy sauce, skunky, smoke, vanilla, woody,
Aroma of butterscotch or toffee when in bottle. When poured more acidious and with hints of wine and oat cereal. Taste is refreshing with a character of caramel malt and an aftertaste of marzipan

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2011 bottle, 33cl, bought @bir&fud beershop. When I opened, it literally "exploded" like a coke shaked. Deep cloudy brown aspect, aroma of caramel, candy, brown sugar and some fruit. The taste is an explosion of fruits and roasted malt. Full body. Very good experience.

Pours with huge beige head, dark brown colour. Aroma is a faint mix of alcohol and barley. Taste is heavy on the hops and alcohol with some barley and malt notes. A little too much alcohol in fact, in my opinion. Dry finish. But Im nitpicking, its a reliable brew for this type of beer.

Bottle. The aroma of a sweet heavy red wine, berries, spices and malt. Smells like a Christmas beer... The head is small, pale beige and milky, not long lasting. The body is dark brown. The taste is very malty, some bread and malt and wine with caramel. The body is medium strong and fizzy-creamy with a lively carbonation. A very good beer, dangerous drinkable!

75 cl bottle. Big, chewy aroma of chocolate and caramel, nuts, spice, dried fruits. Dark brown color with a high, fine, off-white head. Fruity flavor of berries, cherry, big caramel and some chocolate. Roasty, bitter finish, alcohol present. Body is full yet not heavy. Slightly salty at the finish. A bit thinner and more watery than other times I have had it. Not as good as usual, for some reason.

Bottle from Beer Planet, Brussels. Pours a dark brown hazy body with a some finely grained sediments. Aroma is the characteristic nougat scent mentioned in my rating of the Pater 6, only enhanced and slightly twisted in the process towards a more yeasty kind of smell; still pretty good. Taste is similar, with lots of nutty flavors going around with hints of molasses, booze and maple syrup. Unfortunately, the alcohol seems to slightly overpower the delicate nougat-nut flavor so clearly on display in the Pater 6, making this the least enjoyable of the three dark brown abbey ale series from St. Bernard Brouwerij. That aside, this is nevertheless a very  good brew.

Bottle. Sparse off white head over a clear red brown body. Aroma of chocolate, apple/pear juice concentrate, driedfruits with a fruit bitter-sweet character. Medium bodied, with a slight carbonic acidity.
Bottle.  Wonderfully malty flavor with dry candi sugar body.  Garnet amber color.  Pours clear with a creamy head.  Big belgian special malt flavors dominate with perceptible earthy hop character.
Bottle. Dark brown with huge pale brown head, some rests of yeast in the foam. Aroma sweet fruity aroma, sugar and dried fruits. Taste dried fruits, sweet, sugar and malt.

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2010 330 ml bottle @ home. BBE 24.6.2013.
Very aggressive bottle. Pours a deep brown colour with a thick white head. Nice lacing. Rich aroma of Belgian yeast,  dark fruits, spices and banana. The flavour is pretty much the same. Very warming mouthfeel with a sweet fruity finish. Medium bodied, oily amd creamy mouthfeel with low and smooth carbonation. Very nice brew.

Aroma: dust, fig, and dark fruit.
Appearance: hazy, dark amber-brown with a medium sized foamy head. .
Taste: fig, date, apple, and fruit cake from the malt side. All the carbonation cuts through things a bit making it seem lighter than it is.
Palate: Medium in body with very high carbonation
Overall: This one is good, almost great, definitely worth the taste

Bottle consumed in La Grande Motte, 2010-08-12
AR: dark bread ( wee )
AP: dark amber body, of white totally dimishing head
F: wee sweetness, caramel, creme brulee

Bottle:
Big airy light brown beige quick disappearing foamy head.
Color of beer is dark brown.
Smell some dark sugar, fruit, malt, ginger bread, pepper.
Taste is fruity and light spicy.
Lots of fruits, well mixed, full taste soft on the tongue.
Slightly bitter, in the end but still very sweet.
Fruit (prunes, apricot, orange), malts, sugars, yeast, toast and hops.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: On tap. Happy to be saving a bottle of this as well. Rich stained oak color with an ample tan head. Smooth well integrated alcohol with slight bitter and spice driven long finish.

Smells suuuper yeasty and boozy and banana-y. Lovely cloudy amber color, with a serious head. Pretty lacing. Tastes well-balanced, again with the yeast and bananas, but its a nice flavor. Not too dry at the end, solidly boozy finish.

Aroma: Bready, yeast, candy sugar and milk chocolate
Palate: Very smooth
Flavor: Like the nose--what you smell is what you get. Finish is just a bit short.
Comments: Very solid suds.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2012 Very dark brown beer with medium and beige head. Aroma is very great, dark fruits, bananas, sweetness, portwine and hint of overcooked bananas. Flavour is first quite sweet, portwine, dark fruits, spicyness and then dryer and quite long aftertaste. Almost full bodied, smooth and nice to drink. Great, pleasant, sweet, complex and interesting beer.

Serving: 330 ml. bottle from Total Wine Sterling. 
Aroma: A subdued, yeasty, Belgian nose.  A bit of spice, dust, fig, and dark fruit. 
Appearance: It pours a hazy, dark amber-brown with a medium sized foamy tan head.  Good head retention and spotty lacing left behind. 
Taste: There is some fig, date, apple, and fruit cake from the malt side.  The yeast brings a bit of dust and that signature Belgian note.  All the carbonation cuts through things a bit making it seem lighter than it is. 
Palate: Medium in body with very high carbonation and a short, slightly dry finish. 
Overall: This one is good, but I cant quite say that I agree with the rating being as high as it is.  It comes across as a bit carbonic due to all of the carbonation.

Sat in some cafe in Diksmuide, Belgium. On the way to the De Dolle place. Bottle. Dark brown with a nice off white head. Aroma is mellow and gentle but still full of goodness. Flavour has dark fruits, bready yeast like flavours, malts, caramel. Clean and drinkable. A good dubbel.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2012 Bottle. The pour was a murky medium brown with an average sized (1-2 Finger) fizzy white head that was mostly diminishing and had fair lacing.

The aroma was of a toasted cookie malt, light herbal hops and a moldy yeast with notes of dark fruit (prunes and raisons) and caramel. 

It tasted bitter-sweet and a tad sour with a hint of caramel at first and finished about the same but with a strong note of dried fruit towards the end. The flavor lasted an average time proceeding the swallow and had a nice fruity aftertaste that lingered a bit longer.

Mouthfeel was medium in body and oily in texture with a lively carbonation. 

Overall a superb tasting Abbey Ale with a great drinkability, which did a great job of hiding the high ABV...

11.2 oz. bottle from a mix-pack. Pours a dark orange color with a large fluffy white head. The aroma is orange, caramel, coffee, and brown sugar. The flavor is bitter, with a little citric acid tartness balanced with roasted malt sweetness. The body is thick with a slight, lingering bitter aftertaste and some alcohol warming. An interesting and strong dubbel.

Has a really complex nose, a bit of bread and dried fruits. Nice bottle fermeneted cloudy look, not much on the head or lacing. Very creamy and thick, it leaves your mouth a bit coated from the yeast flavour. Im having trouble discerning specific flavours, it is quite a bit like other bernadus beers.

Very dark brown colour with a thick beige head.  The aroma is very nice notes of fruit and the distinct aroma of the St. Bernardus yeast strain. Great flavour, very malty and bready with notes of dark fruits and spices. It is a bit thin in the body however. This is a great brew.

Bottle pour to Trappist glass.  Had it chilled but came foaming out of the bottle anyway.  Mildly cloudy cola color with persistent fizzy off-white head.  Aroma sweet dark fruits and bread.  Taste dark fruits, sweet malts, caramel, belgian yeasts.  Clean finish.  Palate medium consistency and smooth.

I wouldnt say this as a watery ABT, rather a lighter version but still very good in its own right.

2009 Bottle - Pours dk amber with a frothy beige head...aroma is sweet cherry and raisin, toffee malt and grain...flavour is similar, light metal, kinda tastes like Abt 12 watered down slightly, same rich fruit and creme but a bit thinner...less alcohol bite and a bit more grain...

Dark brown with nice crema. Aroma malty, chocolate, fudge, dark fruits, yeast. Taste sweet chocolate,fudge, dark fruits. slight espresso bitterness. medium body, text smooth, slight trace of alcohol. Finish long dark chocolate bitter. Good.

A: The pour is a dark amber color with a creamy off-white head.

S: The nose is quite fruity and sweet. Some plums, blueberries, cherries, and figs. Sweet caramel, brown sugar, and bread provide the maltiness.

T: Quite heavy on the maltiness, much more so than the nose. Bready and quite sweet and lacking a little bit in terms of the fruitiness that was so prominent in the aroma.

M: The body is medium to full with a very pleasant, creamy carbonation and mouthfeel.

D: Another good beer from St. Bernardus. The alcohol warmth does come through a bit as the beers warms up a little bit, but it doesnt detract from my enjoyment at all.
Got to be one of the best abbey dubbels around, and this brewery makes some great ones (Abt 12 is amazing). Great flavor, just enough alcohol, maybe yeasty but I love it that way.

33 cl bottle. Big off white head, brown-red colour. Aroma is malty, dark fruits and some spice (sample was a bit too cold though). Taste is mainly sweet, but at the end you get a modest hoppy finish which is nice.  Good thick body and a warming alcohol finish.

Pours red/brown with a thick bubbly head. Large carbonation bubbles that quickly fade into nothingness and leave behind nice lacing. Aroma is of plums, raisins, and sweet malt. Taste is pretty much the same and ends with a nice tart fruit/slight hops finish. Very good.
33 cl bottle. Hazy  dark brown with big off-white head. Flavour is malt, caramel, fruit, alcohol and sweet.
Redish brown with white head. winey fruity aromas, some mead and alcohol notes. Tastes like caramel and punch, some chocolate and plums. Maybe a little too much alcohol flavour.

750 ml. bottle. Pours a large, fluffy, off white head of medium duration, over a light reddish brown (SRM 17) body.....nose is layers of plum, raisin, bit of dried cherry, light molasses......taste is sweet malts to start with raisin, plum, tones with a hint of cherry, brown sugar.......mouth feel is medium and slightly sticky, carbonation makes a frothy sensation. A typical Dubble, except that the alcohol is a bit high, but it is well hidden. The malt backbone dominates with all the subtle richness one could expect, and the reddish tints to the color are right on. BJCP 8/3/16/4/8

750ml bottle, tulip glass + St Bernardus Prior 8 = a marriage made in heaven.  Purchased at the Boca Raton Total Wine in S.Florida, where 99.9% of the population thinks Blue Moon is cutting edge craft beer.  Someday.  Someday.
Pours a brown concoction that is the Abbey Dubbel standard.  This ale is the platinum standard for the style.  I smell/taste caramel, figs, dates, yeast....love.
Fantabulous.  More, please.  Will return to this rascal.  Repeatedly.

Celebrated review number 600th (May 1st, 2006). Part of a gift pack of St-Bernardus brews for Christmas 2005, at the LCBO. Best before date written on back label is 27 04 10. Pours a deep brown-red colour with very slight raspberry highlights. The tanned head is creamy, leaves a bit of lace and has great retention. Sediments of yeast seem to be floating at the bottom of the glass. The nose is quite nutty with some fruitiness. Some tartiness in the mouthfeel. Lots of nuts in the taste, with some good malt. Some bitterness in the beginning, and then comes back in the aftertaste. Alcohol is very well hidden. Great brew, but I still feel it is lacking overall taste and aromas.

UPDATED: AUG 9, 2010 Draft at Sunswick, during Belgian Beer Fest 2010. Poured dark, ruby-brown with no head. (The beer was a basically flat.) A dark, rich malt aroma. Licorice, raisin, molasses and brown sugar abound in the flavor. Medium body with faint carbonation. Very good, despite the flatness.

Update: I had some of this bottled (not flat) and this stuff is totally good. Bumping up the rating from 3.8 to 4

Poured a dark brown with a large stable off-white head.  Aroma of caramel malts, dark fruits, raisins, brown sugar.  Taste is slightly bitter with caramel malts and brown sugar.  Finish is slightly sweet and fruity.  Full bodied, with a lasting finish.  Alcohol is well hidden.  Very good.

330 ml bottle. From Poperinge, Belgium. Courtesy of Brandman.
Dark murky brown colour with average tan head.
Mildish dark fruits, plums, raisins and dark malt in aroma.
Dark malty fruity flavour with raisins, raisins and alcohol.
Alcohols warming big time.

(330 ml bottle (best before 10/12/13) from McKean and Charles, cellared for 1 yr. after purchase) Pours slightly murky dark rubyish amber with a firm one finger or so of light cream-tan head. Aroma of dark fruit, brown sugar and spice. Palate is soft and smooth with a fine-bubble carbonation feel. Finishes a bit dry. Light, droopy rings of lacing. Flavor of dark fruit, spice and brown sugar as well as chocolate. All flavors as well as the ABV are well-integrated. A tasty, elegant and refined St. Bernardus winner.

750 ml bottle from Kellers IGA.  Pours a cloudy ruby color with plenty of visible yeast sediment and a big off-white head that leaves some sloppy lacing behind.  Aroma of biscuity malts, Belgian yeast, nutmeg, coriander, toast, caramel, overripe apples and plums, candi sugar, and some alcohol.  Flavor of berries, apples, leaves, plums, candi sugar, Belgian yeast, caramel malts, nutmeg, pepper, and a rum-like alcoholic taste.  Medium-full bodied, with moderate carbonation and a spicy, malty mouthfeel.  Dry, spicy finish.  Lots of nutmeg and yeast here.  Better than the Pater 6.

Served from bottle into a Chimay goblet.  Poured a nice dark brown with minimal off-white head.  Lacing was minimal througout.  The aroma was comprised of sweet and fruit notes.  The flavor was full of fruit, slight spice, and minimal alcohol.  It was medium on the palate with medium carbonation.  Overall this was a very nice brew that was quite drinkable and enjoyable.  I was glad I finally got to try it.  It is definite worth a try for any Belgian fan out there who has not tried it.
33 cl bottle, Brussels, Belgium, via Beer Mania. Deep cloudy apricot brown colour. Great raisin and prune aroma, sweet and mellow with a warming long finish.

From 11 oz bottle. Smells of dark fruit, raisin, caramel, chocolate. Dark brown color with loads of smaller yeast clumps. Flavor is a less pronounced version of the aroma, plus bubble gum. Medium body, lightly sticky. Delicious beer.

Outstanding beer. Wonderful appearance in the glass, with a lovely tan head. Beautiful aroma, figgy, yeasty, caramelly, delicious. Then the flavour is just amazing... a little caramel, some malts, a little raisin/dried fruit, and then a nice little bitter finish... Love this one...

A - Rich red brown pour with a 2 finger pillowy tan head that reduces slowly and leaves nice lacing.

S - Complex nose on this one - figs, bread, spice.

T - Bread, figs, spice, caramel and dark sugars. Complex and wonderful. 

M - Alcohol present, smooth and slightly thick.  

D - Smooth and very sippable. Sweetness would keep me from having a second in the same sitting. A wonderfully complex and tasty offering.
A little heavier than most dubbels I have had. Vey nice, but not as good as the St. B. 12.

[bottle]
Sweet and sour tropical and citrus fruit aroma with some brown sugar. Hazy (from my amateurish pour) brown under a beige top of large bubbles. Sweet, biscuity malt with orange, pineapple, and green apple accents plus a touch of vinegar. Pleasant toasty bread crust comes in late together with a bitterness that does not seem to come from hops. Light body, high carbonation, sweet bread crust finish.
bottle - complex and somehow spicy aroma. Flavour is complex too with hints of cardboard. Medium bitterness and medium maltiness. Lively carbonation.
Hazy brown with large off-white head. Aroma is of spices, malt and yeast. Taste is of malt, spice and booze.

bottle.  dark brown (granted theres dim lighting in all up in here),  light foam of a tan color and of course the sediment.  nuts, earthy,  aroma.  medium sweetness and powerful taste with average carbonation and long finish.  Lots of character and very promising.
Strong bodied dubbel. Nose and tastes of deep malts, brown sugar, molasses and candied fruits. Rated 2/9/03

Significantly better than the 12, the Prior 8 gives a bit more body and malt backbone.  Fuller mouthfeel compliments the carbonation perfectly.  Figs and dates make strong impression.  A must try in the dubbel category.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2011 This is a revision of my rating of the bottled version from 2010-05-07. On tap at the Blue Monk in Buffalo, served in a Trappist glass. Pours hazy chestnut with a small tan head. The head fades to a thin cover but leaves a small amount of lace on the glass. On the nose, there are big notes of molasses and liquorice, along with toasted malt, raisins, flowers, vanilla and a hint of spice. The flavour is moderately sweet up front, with notes of raisins, molasses, herbs and flowers. It dries a little towards the finish, which is long and malty. On the palate, it is medium-full in body with a smooth, milky texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a very nice dubbel; it is a bit lighter than some, but it is fairly complex. It is reminiscent of the Abt 12, but lighter and more floral. 2011-05-06

33cl bottle. Hazy dark brown with a billowing white head; spicy malt aroma with a touch of coriander; rich, smooth, malty flavour with some warming spice to finish. Rather thinly bodied - not the best Dubbel Ive tried.

St. Bernardus
Prior 8
Pours  deep brown with a reddish tinge. Medium creamy head and excellent retention, mild lacing. Aroma of cloves and caramel malt, with a thick yeast note. My wife says it smells of chevre cheese in a good way, but I just dont see it. Flavor is fizzy with a strong, nice malt note and a lingering dry finish. Effen good. I like it better than the 12.
Bottle from Beers of Europe. Complex malty grassy aroma. Dark reddish slightly cloudy brown colour. Very strong spicy flavour. I see that this is a very popular beer it just isnt for me.

(11.2 oz bottle).  Pours chocolate brown liquid with tan head. Aroma of bread, chocolate.  Sweet taste with little bitterness; very subtle sourness.  Sweetness lingers quite nicely.  Good example of the style; one of my favorites.

Bottle.

A - Murky chestnut brown to a dark, murky tawny color. Slight reddish tint. Large, foamy, bubbly, and off-white with a slight beige hue. A bit below average retention and some spotty lacing left.

S - Strong dark and citrus fruit smell along with some dark malt aroma in the background. Well spiced with cinnamon, clove, nutmeg, coriander, and a bit of pepper. Also strong Belgian yeast smell and some dark candi sugar. Nice complex aroma, with typical Dubbel aroma with a bit more spice.

T - Follows the nose pretty well. Initially there is a lot of malt and dark candi sugar. Then the dark fruit starts to come out more. Then, bam, a load of spices (same as the nose) comes through. The finish is a nice mix of rum soaked dark fruit and spices with a nice background of malt and dark sugar. Belgian yeast flavors is also fairly present throughout the sip.

M - Slightly more than medium body with a bit more than average carbonation. Quite smooth with a tingly and warming finish.

D - Good drinkability. Complex flavors that dont kill your palate. The spice might be a little strong, but it isnt bad for drinkability. 

Notes: Another good offering from a good brewery. Solid Dubbel that is well spiced. Well balanced and complex flavors that interplay with each other nicely. Definitely worth a try.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a trappist glass.  Pours a dark opaque brown with small tan head.  Aroma is dried fruit (mostly fig) and the lacing is excellent.  Taste is dark fruit and molasses.  I prefer Westmalles Dubbel.
Sample taster at wurstkuche, Honestly it tasted like a Summer seasonal Newcastle and i hate that taste. i wouldnt buy it again, in my case i wouldnt taste it again
what i have been figureing out is i dont really like belguim beers that much its either that or they are not fresh bread, cereal, resin, dough, basement aromas,

Bottle pour to trappist glass.  Aroma opens up as you drink, stone fruits and malts.  Initially pours the color of a stong tea, dark brown with hues of orange.  The orange hues become more evident as the head fades.  Initially tasted bready notes, and cherries and plums fold in as you drink.  The carbonation is ever present but softer than youd expect in a beer of this nature.  Medium body, pleasant mouthfeel.  Reminds a great deal of a fine wine or scotch.  Like all great Belgians, the lingering flavors make for fond remembrance.

330mL bottle.  Pours a murky mahogany brown with a frothy head that settles to a ring.  Aroma of caramel, dried fruit and a little alcohol.  Medium sweetness with some acidity.  Medium bodied, lively carbonation, creamy with a drying finish.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2012 11.2 oz. bottle, pours a cloudy brown with an off-white head. Aroma of raisins, plum, toffee and caramel malt. Flavour of toffee, dark fruits and caramel malts. Lots of complexity, much more so than the 6. Fantastic dubbel.

Malty, dark fruit, prunes and raisins, a hint of soot. Candy-like, som eherbs. Mint and terragon, pepper.
Complex, very pleasant.

Bottle. Poured a darker amber color with a small white head. Aroma was apple, plum, molasses, and other dried fruits. Flavor was bread, yeast, dried fruits, and raisin. Long finish. The 12 is better but this one is still very good.

This is my MOST favorite Abbey!  I was introduced to St Bernardas by a co-worker who bought me the 4 pack sampler for Christmas.  This guy is now the top of my Christmas card list.  Prior 8 was my favorite of all, and i am lucky enough to have several places that carry it here locally.

Poured from a bottle and has a great dark brown color and a nice frothy head.  A nice smooth taste with a hint of fruit.  The beer has a great fininish and leaves you waiting for your next sip.  Definitely one of my favorites!!
Vintage. Brown hazy body and a creamy off-white head. Aroma of nuts, brown sugar, raisin, caramel, roasted malt. Oily texture. The taste is heavy sweet and light bitter.

Shared this one w/ SkyCop32. Pours a darkish red/brown. Aromas of spice, coriander, yeast, and alcohol. Flavor has an alcohol taste to it, mixed with a nice smokey dark fruit. Also has strong hints of spice and orange.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2015 [3/10] Exuberant pour with quite a lot of floating bits. Murky brown with a thick beige head. Prunes, overripe peaches, toffee, leather, earth, cheese rind and Ill stop there. Deeply malty, chocolate and fruit sweet but lightened by carbonation and some hop bitterness. Finish has salt, booze and dark fruit. I imagine this would age into something more graceful but its a lot of fun now.  [4.1]
[4/11] Bottle. Opaque brown with a majestic light beige head. Dried and stewed fruits, lots of yeasty aromas - leather, dough, a little cheese. Taste is only moderately sweet and its quite light-bodied, with dark sugars mingled with the fruit. Dries out a little at the slightly salty end. Remarkably quaffable for something so yeasty. [4.2] [6/15] Curious, an almost flat one. Well off its usual form. Salt is quite prominent.

Like everyone else, Im in the tank for the abt 12. My introduction to the Prior has proven that the junior partner of "Big Bernardus" is also a worthy venture. Poured from an 11.2 oz. bottle into a chalice. The bottle was dated as cellarable through October 15, 2013, which suggests that the beer had been brewed in fall 2008. The age on this may account for the flavor, which featured restrained, mellow stone fruits and a hint of very dark honey. Bottle conditioning yielded a tremendous head and an extremely pleasant creamy texture in the mouth. A real winner, as expected from a fine brewery.

Most revered for their Abt. 12, St. Bernardus also brews a handful of other equally praise-worthy beers. Riding the middle of the abbey road is the Prior 8, a rich Belgian dubbel of epic quaffing proportions, no easy feat indeed considering its generous palate and ABV.


She pours like melted milk chocolates into my chalice, settling luxuriously under a soft khaki head. Light tinges the bottom and sides of my glass with russet-hues, browns, and rich ambers. Playfully swirling her head releases a rich nose moist with dark fruits and a tinge of tartness. Raisins, black plums, black cherries, and pumpernickel whisper amongst each other while I dip my nose once more. Vanilla bean and licorice root parry with fresh cinnamon sticks, and I waste no time wrapping my lips around hers. Sweet and tinged with unripe tartness, just as her nose promised. Gliding over my tongue like velvet, black plums and raisins swim in a river of gentle molasses. Her finish tickles and tingles while warm chewy pumpernickel gives weight and breadth to her naturally effervescent body. Bitter plum skins nip at the back of my throat even as more rich dark sweetness pervades her already seductive palate. Her sweetness is not the least bit cloying, and as black cherries marry into melted chocolate, beervana comes full circle. Each quaff is a pleasant menagerie of all the above, and the more she warms, the more she opens up.


The Prior 8 is truly a beer to sup and savor for a good long while; plenty of time to shake free from the shackles of shyness and open her heart, body, and soul for you and me. St. Bernardus never fails to impress and satisfy my oft-times discriminating and sometimes exhausted palate. I know that every time I bring home one of their abbey beers, I am in for a wonderful treat. Sometimes life does offer us unbridled guarantees of joy and happiness; St. Bernardus is one of those.

Hazy brown pour with a thin beige head, heavy on sediment.  Aroma is pleasant fruit, raisin and fig (?).  Taste starts with strong presence of alcohol and sweet raisin, soft mouthfeel.  Finishes expectedly soft with lingering fruit notes.

Bomber. Hazy dark caramel-brown with big frothy white head. Aroma of dried fruit (raisins, plum, apricot), malty sweetness, yeast. Taste is wonderful sweet belgian malt flavor with light hop bitterness. Plums, raisins and apricot fruit really come out. Very carbonated on tongue, overall a great palate.
Flaske 0,75l. Mørk brun på farge. Halvhøyt luftig skum. Krydret aroma. Svakt søtlig & krydret smak. Litt karamell. Avsluttes syrlig & bittert.
Bottle. Pours a hazy orange beer with a beige head. Full body. Really enjoyed this beer.

draft at redlight redlight.  Pours a dark amber with a billowy lacy off white head.  The nose is a nice combination of plum and tropical fruits and grain to give it a wonderful malty aroma.  The flavor is fairly sweet, pretty fruity, with an ever so slight bitterness in the finish to round it out.  Not as heavy as some other dark Belgians, it is the perfect mix between flavorful, full-bodied, and potent, but still easy to drink.

[2766-20100215] 330mL bottle. Fruity heavy yeast malt aroma. Hazy, dark brown amber body with a medium-lasting foamy light mocha head. Boozy, fruity heavy malt flavour has a Belgian yeast background. Full body. Drinkable, quite good.
(From Volo; Toronto, ON)

Bottle. Pours a hazy brown beer with a small head. Good aroma with hints of dark fruits and yeast. Taste is great with hints of the yeast. Sweet notes with light bitter aftertaste. Drinks smoothly. Good beer.

Reddish brown pour, small creamy tanned head.
Aroma of fruits, banana, raisin, caramel.
Flavour is bittersweet fruit with some spices and liquorice.
Nice one.

Deep cloudy mahogany, poured from a 33cl bottle.  Pleasant soft malt and earthy yeast aroma.  Malty and a bit sweet, with notes of raisin, alcohol, and banana on a full, creamy palate that has a long finish that is slow down the tongue.
Bottle. Hazy brown with a very thick creamy tan head. Fruity and yeasty aroma with some caramel. The flavour is light spicy, caramel and fruit. Sweet fruity finish.
malty,toast, sweet,dark brown, hazy, white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, creamy, lively, long finish,

Pours blackened ruby with a full, billowy head that lingers for a long while. The lacing is more like thick and clumpsy suds that cling to the side of the glass.  Aroma of fruits, bready yeast, and alcohol. Taste is sweet, slightly sour, with a present but mild bitterness.  Nice carbonation, fuller mouthfeel, thick, sticky, with a long finish. This is a good dubbel, but Ive had others I prefer more.

0.33 l bottle.
Cloudy reddish brown colour with a medium pale brown head.
Sweet, dried fruity, yeasty and hoppy nose, sweet taste.
Flavour of nuts and honey, aromas mainly of herbal/floral hops, some roasted malt and yeast.
The finish is pleasantly hoppy, spicy, tiny alcoholy and dry.
Bodys medium, textures sticky.
A well balanced dubbel with a nice hoppy aroma.
Pours a medium brown haze.  Aroma of yeast with notes of caramel, and bitter.  A caramel, bubblegum taste.  Has a medium head.  Medium mouthfeel.  Good dubbel but I am not a big dubbel fan.

Its amazing to me how these beers cover up the alcohol so well.  The bottle I had a ton of yeast and sediment...more than I would expect hence the lower appearance rating.  This had nice butterscotch malt and a floral and Belgian yeast bready nose.
Pours a hazy brown with a sediment and a small tan head.. Bready, malty aroma with some complex dark fruits... Flavor profile follows suit... Dry finish, fruity malty, complex, medium bodied...
Pours a hazy walnut with orange hues, a small white head and a lot of esters. The aroma has a lot of grape juice in it. The flavor is similar, with some toffee and caramel. Dry finish. Nice

It never ceases to amaze me how every bottle I open from St. Bernardus gushes, yet I never mind.  Pours a deep reddish brown almost burgundy color with a very cloudy white head that leaves plenty of lace.  The woody almost vinous character of this beer just kind of flys from the glass over to my nose. As I hold the glass up to my nose the pungent aroma of this beer is dominated by earthy, sweet floral, woody, and nutty notes.  Some other notes are brown sugar, molasses, and cheese.  The flavor of this beer is sweet without being overbearing, pretty well balanced really. Lots of fruit notes dominate the flavor with some semi tart cherries, some pear, and some red apple. There is a distinct nuttiness and some spicy cinnamon and clove notes.  Very mild notes of chocolate and booze show themselves as well.  The beer is very full on the palate is well rounded. Excellent.

Dark Brown with fruity earthy aroma.  Dense pillow head stays around to the end.  Sweet fruit taste with hardly any noticeable hops.  the alcohol is hardly noticeable   The finish it slightly sticky and filling.
One of the biggest surprises I had in my tasting-period. Very good taste, and one to buy again.

Nice clean fresh and sweet aroma. Cant put my finger on what it is exactly. The palate is smooth and exciting on the tongue. The appearance isnt anything special, although my bottle had some sediment which did make it a bit bitter than it should be. The taste is rich slightly fruity and quite heavy hitting for a 8%. Not a bad belgium at all, not the best but would definitely try again.

11.7oz bottle from grape & gourmet. pours a dark, cola brown with hints of ruby and a thick, creamy, light khaki head with sticky lace. aroma is excellent with cedar wood, vinous fruits, black cherry, clove and other belgian spices, caramel malts, yeast. flavor is great as well with dark red fruit notes of grape, plum, and fig, big clove and cinnamon notes, bready malts, and hints of cedar, port wine, honey, and sweet toffee. palate is medium bodied with high carbonation and a dry, fruity, spicy finish. overall, a delicious dubbel.

hazy brown with medium white head.  spicy and estery nose, moderate carbonation for the style.  low bitterness before spicy estery yeast notes that is perfectly complemented by the alcoholic warmth, thin mouthfeel.  perfect brew, an amazing and flawless belgian dubbel

On tap @ Concordia House in Portland, served in a tulip.  Dark brown with no head, although this may have had to do with how full they filled the tulip not leaving room for the head to develop.  Not as good as Abt 12, but still a very good brew.  Not much discernible in the aroma,  although without much head...   Nice malt flavor with some fruit, candy sugar and funky barnyard stuff going on.  Enjoyable brew.

Pours hazy amber brown with a big off white head.  Aroma is caramel, dark fruit, and a grape like champagne aroma.  Flavor is dark fruit, caramel, roasted malt, and some fruity, estery flavors.  Great stuff.
Poured tan with a decwnt white head tasted sweet with a nice alcohol warm aftertaste is of alcohol and leather

On tap, served in tulip.  Deep brown color with sizeable beige head.  Aroma of dark fruits, malts of molasses, caramel and a bit of chocolate.  Very smooth taste that finishes the same.  Alcohol very well hidden - a great beer to sip during or after dinner.

old note; not as memorable as the other St Bernardus brews

still - these guys make nothing but quality beer...

Bottle.  Pours deep brown with a slightly tan, frothy head.  Very sweet - first impression on the smell is hardcore raisins/grapes.  The taste is malty with a nice deep fruity backbone.  Complex mouthfeel - not too thin, not too creamy....very interesting.  High quality beer.
From a fairly limited old rating note (need to try again):  bottle.  similar to the Rochefort 8, but less complex and maybe more drinkable.  Need to try again for a better rating.

Pours with a mahogany hue,off-white head. 
Initial aroma is of candy/bubblegum. Bananas. Acidic wine-like notes. Spice like cinnamon. Strawberries. 
Flavours have a grainy malt, lots of sweetness and alcohol. Yeast in the finish. Cloves, other spices. Very nice.

Bottle. Pours a dark, murky brown with beige, somewhat fizzy head. Aroma is malty, barnyard, light citrus tang, musty, light fruit. Flavor has a nice spiciness to it, a little earthy, malty, some candy sugar, barnyard, light citrus, very faint chocolate, some light dark fruit. Mouth feel is light-medium body with high, fizzy carbonation. Overall, this is a tasty brew. I enjoyed.

Is that cherry I taste? Delightfully balanced with malts? Yum! Not too effervescent, nor bitter. Wonderfully pleasant. Intrinsically, this beer is quality. About the only thing one might criticize is the price, but there is no doubting the value of goodness here.
750 ml bottle a dark brown colored beer with a beige head aroma of roasted malts sweetness bitter and some fruit taste sweet dry fruit and spices a bitter after taste a good balanced beer

Pours a chestnut colour with a light brown head. The aroma is sweet, malty and only slightly sour showing green apple, molasses, chocolate and spice. The flavor is nice and malty as well. A very nice balance of sweet, and sour. Lively mouth feel. Very nice.

brown with garnet highlights when held to light w/ a nice head that leaves a beautiful belgian lace.  aroma is dominated by the dark malts w/ toasty chocolate notes and hints of alcohol.  the dark malts express themselves well without the beer becoming sweet or allowing the alcohol to dominate. best served with hearty beef dishes or as a dessert beer with strong cheeses and tart berries.

Pours opaque chestnut brown with ample cream colored head.  Aroma is malty with spices and hints of fruit swirled in a caramel package.  Taste begins with the spices with slowly melt into a flavor of malts, caramel, and fruits through a state of alcoholic bliss.  Delicious.

Bottle enjoyed at the Hop & Vine...  Poured deep, cloudy, maroon with a thick, retaining, tan head.  Aroma of cloves, spices, malt, and candy-like yeast.  Foamy textered while leaning on the dry side. Malty, earthy, ground pepper-ish, with caramel and toffee sweetness for balance and a smooth alcohol-sweet finish.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2010 large frothy off white head. good lacing. mostly diminishing. cloudy thick medium brown body. aroma: moderate malty, alcohol and raisin (UP). if: light sweet and acidic. ff: light acidic moderate bitter. average duration. palate: full body, creamy texture, lively carbonation moderate alcoholic finish. sem dulçor, toques ácidos bem próximos do azedume, diferente de outras Dubbel. vencimento 09/14. toques frutas secas e malte no paladar. na 2a taça surgiu pequeno dulçor, mas continuou ácida. toques de álcool no paladar. 46s. it is worth less than half its price.
It smells sweet, malty, and boozy. This Belgian brew is dark ruby amber in appearance. It is strong in alcohol and malts for an ABV of 8%, but still delicious and rich in flavor.

Poured into the St. B. Chalice from an 11.20z bottle.  Medium dark brown with huge off white head.  Nose was malty, bready; Taste was smooth with a sweetness of dried fruits. Medium bodied, well balanced, a bit bitter, but dry.
tasty beer. yeast is the dominant flavor... but its also sweet. the ester flavor is minimal compared to most Belgians. one of the darker and better tasting dubbels I have tried.

Sharp, bready flavor with alcohol bite. Slightly earthy, sour after-taste. Fuzzy on the tongue. Looks great, has good lace but head retention isnt very long. Colour is a thick light-brown but slightly red mud.

Dark caramel color with a foamy tan head. Aroma of caramel and spices. Flavor is disappointingly thin. Lightly bitter and sour, quite dry. Not as good as other St. Bernard beers that I have had, but still not bad.

11.2 oz bottle into a tulip glass. Subtle caramel malty, candi, and dried fruit aromas. Hazy brown color, sparkling, poured a thick off-white head slowly fading to a nice minimal lace. Medium sweet, medium bitterness. Full bodied, thin texture, lively carbonation, definite sharpness, then bitter-sweet finish. Found it quite aggressive with its aromas and effect on my palate, but liked it more, the more I sipped. Would try this again.

330mL Bottle. Rated blind. Seventh out of a set of 12 Abbey Dubbels. Minimal to no aroma. If 

anything, a sharp metallic malt character. Pours a murky red-brown, with 

a rocky, laced tan head. Flavor has a blood-like metallic dominant 

flavor. Sharp, ringing alcohol, light acid, and stale pils malt behind. 

Foamy, alcohol-forward and dry. The yeast didnt lend too much 

character, some pinging spiciness, and the malt character really doesnt 

hold up to the sharpness of the yeast and alcohol. Finishes on some 

juicyfruit an hop dryness. Mediocre.

I actually like the Pater 6 better.  The beers are very similar.  The Prior 8 takes the profile of the 6 and magnifies it with a bolder smell, taste, and alcohol content. I like the 6 because it was smoother.

Poured a murky brownish with a decent head that lasts and produces nice lacing.  Malty aroma with dark fruit.  Fig, prunes, dates, and other fruits.   Very light on the palate but pleasing.  Really nice.

Very dark brown with a short lasting head.   Aroma of earthiness and yeast - perhaps a bit of malt.  It has a refreshing taste - surprising for a dark beer.  Its very carbonated with tangy flavors.  The finish is bitter and malty.  I like this one and on first impression, may enjoy it a bit more than their #12.

750ml bottle.  Pours brown with a nice off-white head that reduces to a cap along with some pretty good lacing.  Aroma is sweet fruits, malty, candi sugar, some bread/yeast.  Flavor is very malty, caramel, dark fruits, yeast/bread, a little spice, very nice.  Mouthfeel is full and lively with relatively high carbonation.  Excellent, and I expect nothing less from St. Bernardus.

Pours a dark, murky chestnut brown with a thick, creamy beige head that shows exceptional retention and thick lacing.

The aroma is full of candi sugar and dark fruits, with a thick malty sweetness in the nose.  There is also some spiciness in the nose, that almost tingles, from the Belgian yeast.

The taste is even better with a big sweet fruit and lightly toasted bready malt backbone with lots of fruity esters lending a slight banana flavor to things.  The finish is where the spices start to come out, cinnamon especially.

The mouthfeel is very lively with lots of carbonation which leads the mouthfeel to feel lighter than it actually is.

This a great beer - very complex but insanely drinkable for the style.  Very sweet but with the right amount of toasted character and spices.  Excellent.
Subtle sweet candi sugar nose.  Deep, hazy gold/brown with soft white head.  Incredibly smooth and full, sweet but not overly, with a hint of spice.  Excellent.

Dark fruit aroma with Belgium yeast smell.  Cherries maybe?  Nice aroma but not as good as the Tripel or the Abt 12.  Very dark amber in color with a half to one finger white head that dissipates quickly.  Mouthfeel is a cherry cordial with lots of carbonation.  Nice dark fruit and cherry flavor with an alcohol burn and a very slight bitterness to the finish.  Good beer but I like the Tripel and Abt 12 better.

Bottle: Cloudy and deep amber coloured, lots of floaties visible, medium-sized creamy beige head; moderate to solid sweet fruity (pears?) nose with a caramelly/toasty background; moderate to solid sweet flavour, creamy MF, medium bodied; warming alcohol in the robust sweet finish, balanced by a light bitterness. Strong, warming stuff.......

750 ml. bottle.  Pours a rich earthy brown with slightly tan head.  Alot going on in the aroma here, fruit - banana, apricot, plum, dark fruit.  Clove, yeast.  Taste reveals an incredibly complex barrage of flavors, first spices and hops giving way to malty fruitiness.  Long finish of yeasty malt.  This is good.

Bottle, 33cl. Pours dense brown, with compact tan head that endures. Aroma of sweet dark fruits, and similar with caramel, chocolate and candy on the palate. Great warming mouthfeel, with perfectly blended alcohol. A great ale.

Very pleasant winter day beverage.  The finish is somewhat at odds with the initial taste.  I felt like it lingered, but not as long as I would like.  Someone mentioned astringent... I felt that.  Overall a delicious beverage with nice fruit, wood, and spice characters, but none of which are over done.  Well done.
een donkere body met een witte kraag. zacht en een beetje zoete smaak en de afdrong is ligt droge gerst

Served at about 56F, maybe a little too warm.  Poured a great deep hazy brown like the label states.  Smelled sweet of raisins or plums, as well as malt and a hint of alcohol.  Perhaps some chocolate.  Taste reflects the smell to a tee w/o the chocolate.  Mouthful is creamy with some carbonation.  Great brew.
Pour a murky brown with big white head.  Sweet aroma with notes of yeast, fruit, light notes of alcohol.  Flavor comes across heavy on bread, maybe a little banana, light spice.   Very nice brew.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2011 Bottle.  Pours a dark brune with a tan huge head.  Lots of fruity plum, caramel notes, with a berry seed note, and a hint of licorice.  Figs, and some toffee with a light alcohol warming.  Great Beer. 4.0
This is still drinking great after 5 years.  Bump to 4.2

bottle bb12/26/12  consumed 9/20/09. 

pours out about 50% foam on top of a sea monkey-like yeast community in a bath of reddish brown.... lots of yeast, over carbonation, foamy lacing. 

smells vinous....  over ripe plums (without tartness) and grapes mixed with chocolate, malt powder, vanilla, spice and flowers. 

some banana-like esters show up in the flavor and are met with vanilla, chocolate, spices, caramelized brown sugar and pancake batter with a dry slightly acidic finish. the alcohol is definitely noticeable... wasnt expecting it though.

the body is medium but thickens a bit when the yeast sludge gets mixed in toward the bottom of the glass. carbonation is high, prickly and a bit awkwardly sudsy...odd. need a rerate 7/4/7/2/14/3.5

Dark brown with a foamy thick and lasting off-white head. Aroma of toffee, some malts, a bit like a good walk through a beatiful autumn forest. Very delicate complex taste, desireably sweet and spicy. Medium carbonation. Long bittersweet finish. Delicious beer.

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2010 Bottle, 33 cl. Dark beer with a beige medium head, creamy, light unstable (becoming little lasting head). Aroma of malts, dark fruits and light caramel, not very strong smell however. Malty taste surrounded by a chocolate-caramel taste, dark fruits, creamy texture, light hop bitter finish. A beer I obviously rated much too low the first time, because in fact its one of the best beers in the St Bernardus-series!

33cL Bottle -- Pour chocolate brown with an off-white head.  Roasted malts, milk chocolate like a tootsie roll, and caramel are the first flavors to hit the palate.  Some roasted coffee bean and cherry on the finish.  Carbonation is a little much for me on a beer like this.  Full and almost creamy upfront with the darker flavors lasting for a good while.

Pours dark hazy brown with a little red and gold coloring in it. Nice lacing and a long lasting head are accompanied by a faint sweet aroma of dark candied fruits.  Matching sweet flavor is paired with a little sourness and has a slightly astringent finish.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy chocolate brown. Cramy off white head h fades slowly leaving plenty of lacing. Aromas of stone fruit, toffee and plenty of yeast.and a little yeast. Amazing. Flavours once again show the stone friut, some malt sweetness and some caramel. Carbonation is perhaps a little too high especially at the end. Very dry on the finish with some alcohol. A really nice beer.

Brown beer with light beige mousse. Aroma is malty, bready and has hint of caramel and hop. Taste is less intens than the SB 12 but it is in the same style. Taste is smooth caramel, malts, bread and some hiop.

( 750ml bottle thanks to fratto) Pours cloudy brown with beautiful small bubbles in the head that stays around. Good lacing too. Nose of yeast, corn, dark fruits, and plastic. Taste is dark fruits, spices, creamy chocolate. Finishes very smooth.

A: Poured this beer directly after finishing the Pater 6, and it looked virtually identical, with a large, off-white head that slowly diminished to 1/2-finger size, and a dark brown, cloudy body. Some light lacing.

S: Smells very similar to the 6, but for some reason it actually seemed a bit milder to me... the breadiness is there, but this time I can detect a slight alcohol scent.

T: Very nice flavor, with a bit of buttery diacetyl coming through, as well as the alcohol warmth at the back of the throat. Not quite as sweet as the 6.

M: Medium-bodied and creamy texture, with very lively carbonation.

D: Very drinkable, especially for its alcohol content at 8%, but I think in the end I actually have to give the edge to the St. Bernardus 6.

330ml bottle picked up at Utobeer in London last August. Huge, beige, head fading slowly over a cloudy, ruby-orange body. Dry, tart fruits to the nose with hints of yeast. Dry fruity taste with subdued candy sweetness. Notes of yeast and bitter spices to the finish. I got an impression of old books while drinking this one. Far from great, but has got its moments of joyful drinking. (Tromsø, 07.11.2009).

Brown with a large beige head. Aroma is very yeasty, fruity and overall fun with notes of caramell and dark fruit. Mouthfeel is borderlining annoying with plenty of carbonation, works better after awhile in the glass though. Flavour is fat malty, estery and fruity with a somewhat hot and sweet finish.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2013 Initial Rating: November 11, 2009. Bottle. 25.4 oz. Pours light, murky bown with a thick, creamy off-white head. Aroma of vanilla, caramel, walnuts, barley, and hints of hops, cinnamon, and figs. Medium bodied with a clean, modest mouthfeel. Crisp, medium finish. Good dubbel.

Re Rate: 12 oz bottle. Pours dark plum chestnut with a very rich, creamy tan head. Aroma of candied sugars, sweet bread, honey, and molasses. Cloying palate. Very sugary and not well balanced. Flavor is overwhelmingly sweet and rasin-bready, with some odd spice in the finish. Not nearly as good as a recalled, and Im beginning to believe that Rochefort, and of course Westvleteren, are the only trappistes I truly love.

Very hazy chesnut color with creamy off white head. Smell is a little less impressive then the 12 but very much in the same line. Smooth malts, bread and raisins. aftertaste is mild, sweet-malty and slight fruity. Slightly less bitter then the 12.

Cork and cage bottle. Pours a cloudy dark brown with a largish foamy off white head. Aroma is dark fruits, toast, yeast, nutty, some esters. Flavor is nutty, lots of yeast, roasted malts, burnt caramel. lively mouthfeel.

330ml bottle. Trappist glass. Appears translucent dark brown with a medium beige head that provides good lacing. Rich malty nose of nutty caramel, candy sugar, dark fruits and faint bananas. Palate is full bodied  with a smooth creamy mouthfeel and a perfect balance of malt sweetness and soft yeasty spiciness at the finish. An excellent Dubbel.

Bottle, fromm 2002. Pours a slightly hazy amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty spicy aroma. Sweetish malty spicy flavor with hints of dark fruit. Has a sweetish malty spicy dark fruit finish.

Pours a hazy brown with a decent sided tan head. Aroma is candi sugars, belgian yeasts, spices, dark fruits, alcohol, molasses and rasins. Flavor is rasins, candi sugar, yeasts, spices and a bit of alcohol. More full bodied than the 6 and more flavorful as well. Decent Dubbel.
Bottle thanks to Cavie.  The smell is fruits, some yeast, sweet, some alcohol.  The look is amber colored, clear, and biege colored head.  The taste is fruits, alcohol, and yeast.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2014 Dark, rich color. Aroma of honey baked bread, bread crust and some yeast. Flavor of bread, malt, baking spice, complex fruits. Low hop. A little sweet, honey like flavor. Very well balanced.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2010 Pours a darker, rich amber from the 750ml. bottle with tiny sediments dancing around the carbonation in my pint glass. Amazing head retention. Ripe prunes, dates, and figs swirl around a mild alcoholic presence (bourbon). Mildly tart, sweet (molasses) and yeasty. So wonderfully balaced. Drinkability: BombMer. Rebuy: Sure. #162 on 25102009, DG.

Well, after swirling in the ton of sediment at the bottom of the bottle all I have in my glass now is a awful looking concoction that resembles globby swamp water eggs. Brown muck, a small brown cap that returns on swirl, some spotty lacing and ok retention. Just a shitload of sediment. Sweet spice on the nose, candied orange rind, chewed gum with half the flavour gone, toffee, mellow, maybe a soft version of nutmeg. Instant spice flavour hits first, strange cocoa, bitter spice, minor alcohol on the nose, easy to drink but I think I am suffering through the immense sediment that will not settle one bit. A disappointing brew.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 11.2oz bottle into a chalice. The bottle has a best before date of 28 06 12 and it was consumed on 6-23-09.

Appearance: The body has a dark burgundy color with lighter reddish high lights. On top the head was about one finger thick and hangs on well but slowly fades to a ring of foam around the edge of the glass. It is light tan in color and makes some spotty and slippery lacing.

Smell: Dark fruity and estery notes mix with a mild sweet alcohol presence.

Taste/Mouth: Its flavor has a pleasant sweet and malty complexity. There are hints of dates and figs sweetened by Belgian sugar, warmed by a mellow brandy like alcohol presence and tempered by some mild bitterness of hops. The palate has a smooth but lively texture with active carbonation.

Notes: This beer is another solid brew from St. Bernardus.
Clear brown of color with a beige head. An aroma of spice, caramel and dark fruits. A flavor of spice and dark fruits.
11.2 oz. bottle. Nice opaque brown color.  Aroma  of fruit with hints caramel.  Nice flavor, very good creamy texture.  I liked this beer a lot.
Bottle. Pours a clear, dark brown with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet with malt and dark fruits. Flavour is malty and fruity; plums. Same finish. Too much carbonation. 26-09-09.

330 ml bottle - pours clear, dark brown with thin off-white head; aromas of figs, sugar, dank fruit, yeast and bread; candy malt, thick, dry and fruity; strong, but smooth and tasty; super rich and malty, great stuff

My wife is away so Im numbing the pain with delicious beverage treats. This is my Chimay Red upgrade. Its dark and cloudy with a good head that fades fairly quickly. I was pretty impressed with the appearance...lots of cool floaties. The aroma is of dark fruits and roasty. Sweet on the tongue and pretty dry. A full-bodied dubbel. Im a fan. But, then again, I like dubbels.
bottle thanks to fratto.  poured amberish with a white head.  aroma was straight up mac & cheese.  flavor was caramel with dark fruits.
bottle thanks to fratto.  brown with a cream head. nose is slight chocolate, spices and yeast.  overly carbonated with a yeasty spice flavor.

Bottle 33. Dark amber beer quite cloudy with a small head. Smells of caramel and malt, bitterness at the finish. Hops part is very less. Yeast brings fruit smells like cassis or apple. The feeling is vey less alcoolic, nice belgian beer.

Dark hazy copper/brown with huge rocky head.  Candy sweet aroma.  Fluffy carbonation and full maouthfeel.  Sweet on the tongue to start, light roast and caramel, develops into citrussy hop bite, surprisingly dry finish, even though some caramel lingers, along with prickly pepper on top of tongue.   Interesting spice notes from yeast and alcohol.  Good, but more simple than I expected.

11.2 ounce bottle from Total Wine in Tustin ($3.49).  Pours a muddy brown with ruby tones and lots of floaties.  The generous off-white head reduces to a steady layer composed of ultra-tiny bubbles.  Nose is sweet bready malts, yeast, overripe plums and figs, and light spice.  Much of the same in the semi-sweet flavor along with brown sugar and light alcohol.  Nice carbonation but the finish is surprisingly not very sweet but dry with a light bitterness.  A solid dubbel.
.750 Bottle.  Pours a with a healthy head.  Smells of dark fruit, candy, and caramel.  Roasted malts and brown sugar flavors.  Aftertaste is good, but faint, I wanted it to last longer.  Creamy feel.
Brown murky pour with two finger beige head. Definite dark fruit and brown sugar aroma. Nice medium body with roast and hop. Wow good.
Bottle courtesy of Fratto. Orange to red pour with lots of sediment. Sweet belgian aroma. Dry sweet fruit that sits lightly. Taste is incredibly smooth. Hints of sweet grapes. Decent finish. Not bad.

Unfiltered dark brown. Nice head with some retention, homogenous small-medium bubbles. Nice.

Sweat aroma, complex.

Works well all over the tongue, alcohol there, but not prevalent. Aftertaste is a little too grainy, like leftover spices.

Thin, watery. Fizzy.

 Very nice. After taste the only fault.

Pours a very dark reddish brown color with a nice thick cream color head.  Aroma of many dry fruits like raisains and plums, cream and brown sugars with roasted malts.  Flavors are very rich, creamy with roasted malts and brown sugars.  Fruty and spicy, with good carbonations. Dry, sweet and bitter and a warm finish.  Lots of great complex flavors, very enjoyable.

Rubyred brown colour, very dense creamy big head. Pours out easy with chunks of yeast in bottle and glass.Aroma is rather molasse-like, sweet. tastes bitter sweet, low carbonation, hints of cacao, roasted malts. Finish average, but nice beer.
Had this after trying the ABT 12. It should have been the other way around. It is a easier to drink version of the 12.
