Bottle. Cloudy brown with a foamy off-white head and floaties (yes!). Subtle pear, touch of light raisin and light bread/toffee in the nose. Flavor has notes of cola, brown sugar, raisin, plum, chocolate, pear/apple, sweet caramel, herbal/earthy hops. Pleasant sweetness, just enough hops for balancing purposes. Medium, airy (very drinkable) body with lively, yet very soft small-bubble carbonation. Good.

Poured from an 11.2 oz bottle into a Duvel tulip. The glass gives this beers exemplary and ample head plenty of room to stretch out to an impressive three fluffy fingers. The fine carbonation leaves lacing that cakes the glass as the head rescinds itself. The beer is an opaque dark brown that could be used to paint a UPS van. 

The smell erupts with sweet doughy malts and dark fruits, classic dubbel aroma, very enticing. 

Breadiness juxtaposed with fig, raisin, and plum esters caresses the tongue. A hint of spiciness, caramel, and candi sugar make this a sweet beer while a pinch of hop flavor and alcohol warmth fight for balance. 

The mouthfeel is creamy, smooth, and medium-bodied, and the carbonation is perfect. Excellent drinkability.

Bottle.  No head, just some see-thru bubbles at the top.  Dark brown, almost black.  Sour, winey aroma, dried fruit & cherries.  Wow, biting carbonation right away.  Recall too much carbonation in the 6 too, whereas the 12 was nearly perfect.  Not sure whats going on, but its nearly impossible to get past the carbonation issue here, except for a weird bitterness right at the end.  Arrgh!

Pour a dark brown and tan head. Solid carbonation and aroma lightly sweet and yeasty. Sweet bread aroma. Fantastic on first taste- very well balanced and not as much spice as i expected. Medium bodied but very nicely balanced with the carbonation to almost dissipate in the mouth. Weightlessness by another reviewer summed it up very well. Smooth and fantastic!  At the end it was almost too smooth and not enough bite...

Brown in color this poured a fine thick head that slowly dissipated.  It was darker than the 6 but the head also dissipated quicker.  The nose was filled with chocolate covered bananas, raisen, cherry, burnt caramel, dates.  In the mouth it was medium-bodied with a denisity to it that was kept light from all the very fine bubbles.  While overall similar to the Pater 6, this clearly had a denser midpalate with more powerful flavors.  There is still sense of weightlessness to the palate the belies its dark flavors.  Overall, this was similar to the Pater 6 with more power and flavor concentration along with slightly darker fruits.
Good Belgian strong. it is sweet and spicy at the same time. not as good as the 12
Dark brown colour with large beige head.The aroma is spicey and hoppy really power full mouth feels,sweet note of strong alc.

Pours a dark brown with a healthy head that stayed throughout.
Sweet, citrusy smell with some caramel aromas.
Great taste of dark fruit, black cherries, and malt with a touch of coffee.
Mouthfeel might be the best part of this beer with a silky smooth finish underneath very lively carbonation that felt like champagne.
My wife was drinking a Bud Light as I was drinking this one, so I took a sip of hers. The Prior 8 was better.

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2008 Bottle...pours brown with red highlights....super fluffy tan head that shrinks down to a cm and leaves a very delicate and elegant lacing behind....the pour left a small concentrated dollop of creamy foam in the center of my glass-head stays around through the entire consumption....aromas of yeast and clove...prunes and raisins as well....as it opens up I smell faint raspberries and apples.....well carbonated body, small dense bubbles....A bitter malt flavor and fruits show through on the tongue...raisin and prune again...on the finish a bit of spices...like a bitter allspice or something....this beer seems to have many different levels, but they all blend so quickly together, good.   gets better as you sip it...but leave it out for more than an hour and too much alcohol comes through and the finish is a salty mouth-feel

11.2 oz bottle. Pours a murky brown with tons of small bubbles clinging to the side of my Chimay chalice and a large frothy off white head that settles down to a smoth slick off foam that lasts the entire time and some nice lacing as well. Aroma of rum cake, brown sugar and nutts. Medium bodied with a slightly dry finsih and a creamy mouthfeel. Flavor of bread, some dark fruit and sugar. Decent all around beer, wouldnt mind if someone gave me one but nothing to seek out.

Poured from a small bottle. Dark brown and larrge tan head. Aromas of dark dried fig and prune. A little carbonation with a smooth mouthfeel. The flavors were caramel malt, sweetness and dried fruitiness. Pretty good length of finish. A bit less complex and chewwy as the fabulous Abt 12.
Dark brown with large beige head.  Aroma is caramel and yeast with a little spice.  Very sweet with a caramel taste.  Doesnt have enough hops or other flavours to balance the sweet malty taste.
Pours dark brown and hazy, with a nice foamy head.  Hoppy aroma, with hints of fruit and spice.  Sweet tasting, and not too heavy, but with a bit of an alcohol bite.  A great beer.

dark leather colored /

full tan head /

soft, chewy mouthfeel /

ripe banana, aged chardonnay, subtle malt
a reassuring friend that i sipped down at a new bar. they charged the crap out of me for this treat. reassurance has its cost. no surprises here. great job.
Rich dark color.. Rich smooth taste that went down easy. Flavor was sweet amd smooth with a hoppy finish.

The head is extremely nice, silky smooth and lasting. It leaves islands of foam on the surface. The aroma is spicy and hoppy and the mouthfeel is nice and full. The flavour has a nice body, its spicy and the alcohol burns a bit. It has notes of nuts, figs, ripe plums and other stone fruits. In the finish an unexpected but nice bitterness turns up together with brief notes of smoke. This beer should not be too warm, and I would like more complexity - but nice it is.

small bottle: pours with a thick creamy off white head with lacing. head last suring the drinking experience. this hovers over a dark caramel brown body. aroma is wonderful full of dark sugars and a great amount of fresh fruit such as sweet cherries, also has a great belgian yeast aromas. flavour is yeasty and dark sugaars at first ans them some darker fruits plums and raisins. finishes drying.

330ml. pours true deep ruby.  perfect head. high amount of sediment.  deep, complex aromas of candied ripe fruits.  i wish they made candles of this aroma.  while the taste mirrors the aroma, it adds the as-advertised malty palate and takes away the overtly candied aspect.  theres also a touch of cinnamon or clove on the palate.  i could drink this all day long.  if it werent for that pesky job...
It is dark red and pours a big head good lasting. The aroma is of figs, malt and swedness. The flavor is of Belgian candy, dark fruit and malty sweetness. What a great beer.

Draught. Dark opaque reddish beer with minimal head. Light cherry aroma. Flavor is cherry, oak, and well-rounded sweetnesses. Sharp and creamy mouthfeel with a smooth finish and a biting aftertaste hinting at the abv.

(New Years Eve tasting Flight (2 of 4) Pours a much larger head. Might have been warmer than the 6 which I had 90 minutes ago. While the head does collapse almost as quickly as the 6, it provides a LOT more lace than its lighter cousin. Lots of sediment in this one. Still an orangy color, however, a little towards the brown end of the spectrum. Can smell the brown malts coming out in the aroma. Body is heavier. Flavor of belgian candy sugars coming out. Must more complex body and flavor compared to the 6. More pronounced warming on palate and throat after a minute. The warmer it gets the heavier the body gets.
Pours a dark brown color with a huge frothy beige head.  Aroma of dark fruit, alcohol and chocolate.  Very tasty beer with lots of malty chocolate, raisin, prune, plum, spice and alcohol.

Dark brown color, tame little tan head for a belgium.  Rich caramel aroma with heavy malt, no real hops but a prune fruit smell.  Cherry flavor comes out in the beginning but then it gets complex - an array of fruit and a bit of malt. It all comes together to hide the alcohol content, thus no heat in the throat.  Palate is perfect for a belgium, a great mix of heaviness and not too bubbly to take away from the flavor.  Overall a great belgium thats different from some of the others.

Nice, but nothing special when placed next to other St. Bernardus selections. Nice aroma with pine, caramel malts and apples. Appearence is a muddy brown with smallish off-white head. Lacing as always excellent from St. Bernardus. Flavor is sweet throughout with a nutty, yeasty finish.

11.2 oz bottle
Label is orange with a monk holding a beer goblet that says Prior 8

I poured this slow and harsh. I have found out that the more gases released in the pour the more flavors are released. 

Pours a nice head that falls into a thin bubbly head with a very strong lacing. 

Smell is strong of flowery hops and sweet aromas

Taste is not strong, but light and aromatic. Strong pepper taste are very apparent

Mouthfeel is ok, nothing great.

I am glad to have this, but will wait for a great conditioned one next time

From the bottle into a SB glass, the aroma was very yeasty as if it was bread dough on the rise.  The color was hazy dark reddish-brown with a slightly tan head.  On tasting there is a big rush of brown sugar & molasses mixed with a raisin.  This beer starts out sweet malty with lots of yeast but that sweetness fades quickly and subsequent taste are not as sweet.  There is a slight alcohol warming at the end of the taste.  Overall this is a great beer, smooth and easy to drink.
Bottle.  ark brown hazy appearance with yeasty aroma.  Malty flavor with a strong bread like characteristic.   The alcohol is very noticeable.  Very nice.
Brown with red tinge.  Lasting head.  Malty rum raisin, dark fruit aroma.  Tastes sweet with a sizeable amount of yeast and some spice.  Alcohol finish.  Soft mid to full body.

11.2oz bottle, fridge cellared for approximately 1 year. Best by date (?) 04 08 10.

Wow, this beer has some head on it! Towering rocky white head, very crystalline in appearance. Slow to recede, and leaves excellent lacing. It takes a while to see enough of the body to tell the true color, which turns out to be  a very dark purple, almost red wine type color. Nose of white grapes, candied sugars, cherries, funky/musty yeast, bread dough and peppery spice. Bright fruits, sugars and yeasts continue to dominate into the flavor profile. Very wine like all the way around, really, from appearance to flavor. Some spice kicks up at the last instant. Medium-heavy astringency. Vinous, almost feels like drinking a sugar free fruit juice or drink. Finish is medium in length, grapes and figs, then pretty much yeast and some alcohol hints to finish everything out. Great stuff from a great brewery.

Red and dense color, malt spices with a glorious inch-tall head which recedes into a floating foam. Dense carbonation matched with yeast, dark bread and bitter fruit. Dry finish with some sweetness remaining. Not my favorite, would much prefer chimay blue which is a similar style .

33 cL bottle. Pours dark brown with a reddish huge and huge light brown/off-white head. Fruity an light medicine like aroma. Flavour is smooth malty with hints of chocolate and some spice notes. A smooth yeast flavour shines through. There is a slight banana fruity flavour beneath. Faint and soft liqourice note. Finish is more of the same smooth malt notes and a start of a winous feel. Otherwise extremely well hidden alcohol. Nice but not fantastic.

redish brown color, malty rum raisiny nose. Big malt flavor, biscuit/candi sugar and port like. I did not detect any sourness, and its a perfect beer on a cold winter night. my favorite from saint bernard.

Was actually not as impressed with this one as I was with 6 or 12. Pours a brown reddish color with a tope creamy head that last through out. Tastes of candy and belgian sugar. Also of dark fruits and raisins. Just ok but the taste was not excellant.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2013 Bottle (33 cl) at Tre små rum, Göteborg, Sweden. Murky reddish brown with a creamy beige head. Fruity and toffeish malt aroma, delicious, with some wooden notes and yeast. Medium bodied and smooth. Good balance with a dry finish. Very good.

Al naso il floreale prevale quasi da subito su una lievissima nota di tostato.
Il caramello sembra prevalere pur alternandosi a frutta secca, dolce.
Ottima!

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2008 0.33l, bb 19 04 12. Turbulent and hazy, dark orange-brown with a huge creamy head leaving nice frosting. Spicy biscuit, caramel, rum and cola aroma. Big, delicious flavors of dry-spiced raisin rum cake with brown sugar-caramel icing are tempered nicely by some dry, bitterish hops and yeast. Nearly medium body, with a lot of tingle. Only complaint about this beer is that it literally fizzles apart and explodes with CO2!

From a bottle, poured a very deep, almost opaque brown-chestnut body. Bold, thick off-white head with great lacing. Sweet medicinal candied nose.  Rich, syrupy mouth feel.  Rich and gritty.  Not my bag, but it could be because I had cellared it over a year.

Bottle.  Pours a thick hazy brown color with a tan head.  The beer has a very caramel and dark fruit aroma, heavy on the malts.  The flavor is caramel, fruit, and something I just cant put my finger on.  The alcohol is noticeable.  This beer is one of the more complex that Ive had in recent months.

Garrafa, em Utrecht (HOL), em novembro de 2007. Coloração preta turva, com creme bege consistente e persistente. Carbonatação alta. Notas de torrefação e frutas vermelhas. Levemente amarga e seca. Não é tão bem balanceada.

33cl bottle - pours very hazy, dark brown with a big light tan head. Creamy. Aroma of lots of dark fruit, caramel, malts, lots of yeast, typical of this line of beers. Flavour is full of wheat and sweet fruit, including cherries and apple, caramel again, with a light sour tart quality in the finish. Fantastic.
Brown colour with thick and creamy head. Aroma has caramel, dark fruits and malts. Flavour is sweet caramel with some fruits. Alcohol well noticable. Good beer.

Pours opaque brown-amber with thick creamy head.  Nutty aroma with notes of dark fruit, yeast, and caramel.  Flavor is slightly sweet, notes of dark fruit, yeast, port, caramel, coffee, and apple predominate, with a floral finish.  Palate is smooth and slightly dry.  Outstanding brew.
Bottle. Reddish/amber colour with large creamy off-white mostly lasting head. Fruity aroma with notes of caramel and yeast. Sweet flavor with light bitterness. Oily palate.

First impression it that like other St. Bernardus beers, this is very well crafted.  While it is not as complex as the Abt 12, this is a special ale that stands on its own.  The nose is dark fruit, sugar, with slight vinous accents.  The flavor is rich complex, and slightly more refined than the nose, while at the same time keeps one wanting more.  I will no doubt repeat this beer, and it maybe often, while supplies last.

(on bottle, some 2 years old) It´s weird to taste such a nice and complex beer, when words are so few. This is just a well made belgian beer. High on all levels, fruity like a day in the ochard in october, burning alcohol like the fireplace my wife lies before, colored red like our chestnut right there in the garden, earthy like my kids rubberboots. A great drink a sunday night in the fall.

Bottle. Pours deep reddish honey brown with tremendous ivory head. The aroma is sweetish with light caramel and sugar, red apple, coconut, plum, and maybe even a hint of wine. The flavor is a little more mild than I expected, but is still quite good. Light caramel and raisin start, then some floral and fruity notes. It gets an interesting tart note toward the finish, and finishes with a slight dry woodiness over the mellow malt. Pretty good stuff.

Rich aroma of mildly dark fruits - plum and cherry, perhaps. Ripe hazy reddish amber color with a decent light beige head. Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Flavor of caramel, plum, straw(?),  coffee, citrus.  The finish is lightly astringent, relatively dry, and mildly bitter. A soothing, ripe ale. Mouthsmackingly good.
Pours brown with medium off white head. Aroma is malty with overripe fruits. Flavor has plums, raisins and is malty. Rather complex with a nice alcohol warming finish.
Bottle @ Lowlander. Nose of alcohol, yeast and banana. Pours red mahogany. Soft mouthfeel, dates, alcohol. Long malty finish. Nice.

11.2 ounce in Westmalle glass.  Brown with dense lasting tan head and lotsa lace.  A few floaters. Yeasty aroma with some caramel and more yeast.  Raisiny, fruity caramel flavor with tobacco bitterness surprisingly clean finish.  Medium body and medium low carbonation.  Excellent soft mouthfeel.  A very good beer.

330ml bottle. Very dark brown with a decent off-white head. Malty fruit aroma with some chocolate and liquorice. The flavour had a touch of caramel with some spice and a long, smooth finish. Excellent.

11.2 oz bottle, poured into trappist glass.  Pours with a murky red brown with a very light, soapy head.  A rich, complex aroma of sweet malt and citrus.  The flavor starts off strong, with the malt and citrus matched with caramel and coffee undertones.  A lingering coffee aftertaste.  This beer is great, complex, interesting, just about what youd expect from St. Bernardus.

(#200) 11.2oz bottle. pours dark and murky brown with a perfectly formed fluffy cream colored head. really an exquisite beauty.  strong and complex aroma of citrus, sweet malts, and oaky vinous notes. very smooth velvety palate displays the fullest of bodies. soft and citric with delicate fruit flavors leading to a dusty estery finish. yeast and candy sugar contribute to the rich taste. quite a treat.

750ml bottle. Dark red brown body with a nice off-white head. Aroma is sweet vinous malty with dry fruit. Flavor is complex. Sweet malt, candy sugar, alcohol, caramel and dry fruit. Some hops in the finish.

Pours nice chestnut brown with great head leaving nice lacing on the glass.  Souring oaky scents are noticed as well as aromas of yeast, fruits and citrus.  The flavor itself is a tad souring, oaky with cherry,vanilla, alcohol, dusty malt, cardboard, with funky yeast touches and a crisping acidityand carbonation.  Not what I expected but good nonetheless.
bottle poured redish brown white head. Malt and yeast aroma . Nice mediun mouthfeel ,malty sweet flavor

Bottle, 75cl corked. Imediately after popping it, a vinous aroma escaped the bottle, along with some dried fruits. When poured, the big fluffy beige head seems to capture most of the aromas, but some dried fruits and sugary notes escapes. It has a brown body with a reddish-orange tint, and a lively carbonation going on. Nice lacings are formed as the beer is drank, and reappeares when the glass is filled and emptied again. Just lovely to look at. Flavorwise it starts with a sweet, caramel and dried fruits, soon followed by some cellar, yeast and warming alcohol. A little peppery spicyness as well. It finishes quite sweet, with dried fruits, a reasonable amount of alcohol, and a spicyness. When pouring the rest of the bottle into my glass, it turns out the before so clear body, now is hazy, and with some micro-floaties. As expected. The nose also reveals more of itselves as the head shrinks, unfortunately a bit weak, but the forementioned dried fruits and sugar has company with some alcohol, cellar, yeast and spices. Definately a well crafted brew, unfortunately I have to go abroad to find it. (070927)

Caramel brown with a light tan head.  Intense aroma.  Malts, yeast, spices, light fruits, peppery, some alcohol and sugary sweetness.  Medium thick mouth with active carbonation.  Flavor is spicy, caramel malts, dark fruits, and noticeable alcohol.  A good belgian.
Bottle. Pours brown with reddish tinge to it. Aroma is of alcohol, fruit, caramel. Quick dissipating white head. Nice sweet taste and finish.

Brown bottle, 330 ml, via Importations Privées Bièropholie, best before 27 02 12, savoured on September 25 2007; eye: brown with burgundy reflections, nice creamy beigehead that remains throughout the tasting, good lacing, opaque, no effervescence; nose: yeast, bread, caramelized malt, lightly fruity; mouth: in that order, creamy, caramelized malt, alcohol, wave of sugar, spices (including pepper from the alcohol), subtile chocolate à lorange, hint of hops, creamy finale in caramelized malt with an enjoyable presence of alcohol, mildly sweet, slightly bitter, medium to full body, quite carbonated, slight astringency; overall: quite good

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 330 ml, via Importations Privées Bièropholie, meilleure avant 27 02 12, savourée le 25 septembre 2007; il : brune avec des reflets bourgogne, belle mousse beige crémeuse qui se maintient, légère dentelle, opaque, pas deffervescence; nez : levure, pain, malt caramélisé, léger fruité; bouche : crémeuse, malt caramélisé, alcool, vague sucrée, épices (incluant le poivre de lalcool), subtil chocolat à lorange, petite pointe de houblon, finale crémeuse en malt caramélisé avec une présence agréable dalcool, moyennement sucrée, très légèrement amère, corps moyen-corsé, assez carbonatée, très légère astringence; en résumé : très bonne
Bottle.Red brown colour with a beige head. Aroma fruit, alcohol, apple, yeast. Flavour is fruit, yeast, alcohol, malt. Nice beer.

Big bottle.  Pours with large head that dissipates quickly, and the body remains a red/brown haze.  Aroma is the best part of this beer, with some molasses, vanilla, and a nice malt and yeast backbone.  The taste and finish are both a bit sweet, but this is what a good ale should taste like.  Definitely a favorite.  I was disappointed to hear my friend did not care for this brew, but he likes Coors Light and Busch Light so I take it with a grain of salt.

33 cl bottle from Bieropholie, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass.
App.:  Deep reddish-brown with an unstable off-white froth.
  
Aroma:  Lots of molasses, caramel, toffee, raisins, dark dried fruits, light herbal notes (mint, etc.), slightly nutty, very sweet, 
  
Palate:  Medium body and medium-full effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Much like the nose, less sweet than expected; some of the rich malts, some of the minty herbals, a bit of black licorice, nuttiness; a touch of alcohol and bitterness to finish.

Quite pleasant.

Medium brown... even-toned with a relatively dense tan head. Aroma is apple and spice, albeit rather faint.  Taste is same, and but rather weak and generic.  Carbonation is too fine for my palate, so it feels a bit fizzy.  $8/750ml

Bottle, Aikmans, St Andrews. Dark brown, huge off-white head that laces well. Nose is rice krispies, slightly floral and some clear fresh grainy and slight amounts of diacetyl. Mouth is plummy, some rice krispies and lots of sweetness - some oranges towards the end. Lively gassy beer with a lasting plummy full sweetness. Rather good actually.
bottle. big frothy head, with good lacing.  Cocoa, butterscotch, coffee swirl, some honey and fruit, evolving as it warms up.  Good mouthfeel and balane, nice long finish. Excellent.
Malt and dark fruits on the noze.  Hazy brown color with faint off white head.  Spicy body with more dark fruits.
It poured a dark brown with a off white head. You can taste caramel, dark sweet fruits, and honey. Smell sweet and finishes with a warm, malt cherry flavor left on the tongue.
Pours a dark brown with a fizzy tan head.  Alcohol is not masked very well. Has hints of some caramel, dark semi-sweet fruits, and warm spices. Finishes with a metallic spice taste on the tongue.

33 cl bottle in tulip glass, "Best Before" 3-2-10 but dangit; I want it now! Deep mahogany pour with lots of sediment bits, slightly gray head. A light honey smell with a metallic twang. Taste is honey with bits of currants and plums to start. Very mellow throughout, with impressions of fresh black bread and Christmas pudding, then raisin cookies. Very warming, but no alcohol hotness. Were I more patient with this bottle, it might have smoothed out in a year or so. Dumping in the dregs at the end gives it some bite at the finish.

Pours a murky red brown. Nose is like an over ripe peach that if you waited to eat it until tomorrow, it would be rotten. Hint of molasses. Flavor is perfectly balanced. A touch of cherry on the tongue. Slight alcohol presence noticable. Strong sweetness like a brown sugar. Feel is very bubbly and very smooth. Excellent drinkability. So perfectly balanced. 

This was the middle beer on a night of tasting that started with Damnation by RR and ended with the St. Bernardus Abt 12. This beer was my favorite, and the person I drank with felt the same way. 

I wish I could buy this in New Mexico. If I could, itd probably be a regular.
no fancy talk - this is just a fabulous brew.  great color, pours with nice head into a trappist glass, very pleasant flavors.  its quickly become one of my regulars.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2008 Bottle -- Beautiful big off-white head with OK retention and lashings of lacing. Dark, dark reddy brown. Aroma is rich malt and ripe fruit and a touch spirituous. Nice and earthy. Slightly creamy/Slightly thin palate. Spicy fruit flavour with a touch of alcohol warmth that creeps up on you from behind. The aftertaste is interesting, with the rich fruity flavours giving way to a slightly sour alcoholic taste, with the overall impression &quotthinning out&quot as a result.. Very, very nice just the same.

Name: Prior 8
Date: 07/13/2005
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting

hazy brown, tons of carbonation, huge frothy off white head, earthy malt aroma, nice fruity malt flavor, light esters, light spices, a fine drinking beer although a bit light, 
-------- />
Name: Prior 8
Date: 03/11/2006

dark with ruby edges, huge beige head, lots of lace, rich ripe fruit aroma, wonderful rich chocolate flavor with lots of ripe fruit character, but still a bit light even compared to the 6 which has a stronger malt profile

Aroma: 8/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20
Rating: 3.3/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: *4

Poured a deep brown into the glass with an off white head.  The aroma on this one was malty with some plumlike notes.   The taste on this one was surprisingly mild for the strength of this beer with some deep fruitlike flavors coming through.  A really great brew!

Bottle. Pours a very dark reddish brown with a medium beige head. Aroma is yeasty and malty with notes of fruit, black cherry, raisin, plum. Medium in body with light carbonation. Flavor is slightly sweet and mostly dominated by the malt flavors although there is some fruitiness/berry mixed in with the note of alcohol. It ends with a distinctly alcohol and yeasty dry finish. This is great.

11.2 oz bottle.  pours a dark brown with a decent sized head that quickly dissipated to a thin lacing.  Aromas of malts and spices... not all that strong though.  A bit thin on the palate.  Carbonation is strong and it has a very pleasant body on the tongue.  A good belgian strong ale, not the best by far.
Draft in signature St. B. glass...dark but not heavy, this one goes down easily. Flavors of chocolate and dried fruit. Thin cream-colored head is atop the dark body. Nice carbonation.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 Bottle. Aroma is muted, but I get raisins and ginger. Thick, dark brown, lots of creamy head. Flavor is full of fruits and spices, some ginger. Very drinkable, watery despite the high ABV. Very good.

[Sampled in 2003.] When I had thisone some years ago I found it rotten, sour, fat, too sweet, but later I realized it should be that way, then my notes has grown a little. Funny to see how the notes/ratings change by time. Next time maybe >4
Bottle Pours dark w/huge persistent head. Aroma is chocolate.  Taste is some raisin and cinnamon, along with some hoppy bitterness to finish

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2010 I first had this been when the LCBO was selling a St. Bernardus assorted gift set at Christmas 2005. This beer was not as impressive as the 12. I recently did a tasting along with the St. Bernardus Pater 6 and Abt12. Definitely a nice beer, but nowhere near as well-balanced as the Abt 12. The beer pours a nice red-brown colour with white head with aromas of figs and spice. Has nice raisin and port flavours, but has a winey sourness that throws off the balance of the beer
Pours dark in the tulip glass. Chunky thick white head with a nose of chocolate and malt. Body is bit lighter than should be for an 8% ABV beer. Drinkable but not memorable.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text:
Finish - Flavor
o Sweet - light, moderate, heavy, harsh
o Acidic - light, moderate, heavy, harsh
o Bitter - light, moderate, heavy, harsh
o Acetic (vinegar)
o Sour (sour milk) o Salty

Dark brown-red body. Tan on the head.
Aroma: malt, milk, raisin, dark fruits.
Flavor: malt, yeast, dark fruits.
It´s winous and strong. In a sense it has to much co2 in it. It should be more mellow in it´s way of presenting it self.

330ml bottle.  Pours a dark reddish brown with a very creamy off-white head.  Sweet and dark fruit in the nose with some alcohol.  Full-bodied dark fruit and malt flavors, with some vinous characters.  Light spice as well.

draft.  Chocolatey aroma, hints of roasted malts, caramel and dark fruits.  Pours dark brown with a fluffy off white head.  Smooth and rich malts, caramel and chocolate, creamy mouthfeel.  Easy drinking for 8%.

Bottled 33cl. It pours a dark brown beer with a rather big light beige head which remains nicely - Nice and fluffy too... This ale leaves a nice lacing. The aroma is dissapointing: Rather metallic with some sour apples, seawater and cane sugar. The taste is cloying with hints of licorice. Lots of cane sugar, plums, butterscotch, apples, plums and butter. Somewhat a bit stylish. The taste reveals some surprises. Not overly complex though. Some well hidden alcohol. Full bodied and malty. A whiff of very enjoyable elements just before the finish. (Plums, Christmas pudding). Then, a wonderfully grassy and buttery finish follows. This beer has a very low bitterness, not all that well balanced, yet decently enjoyable.

This is by far my favorite of all the St. Bernardus beers, and quite simply the best dubbel (if thats what it is) that I have ever tasted. The ABT 12 is almost perfect but just a bit too sweet, the tripel is great but several tripels are greater (say, Westmalle). The Prior 8 in contrast has no bad qualities I have been able to discern and no other beer has it beat in any respect. It is a very substantial, vinous beer. In fact, I have never tasted a beer that was so similar to a wine before. We have here the aroma of prunes, raisins, various fruit, and yeast. Caramel is very pronounced, but whats remarkable about the Prior 8 is that it manages to be caramel-y without being sweet (here the ABT 12 falls short). We have here plenty of carbonation and appropriate hop bitterness--the hops are definitely more pronounced than in most Belgian dark ales of this strength, and yet the beer is not bitter; its just very well balanced. "Dry" is the word, not "bitter". Another respect in which the 8 is superior to any comparable beer I can think of is that it manages to be quite dark and caramel-like without even a hint of roasty/burnt flavor (what some people call "coffee" or "chocolate"). In this respect I find it preferable to the comparable Rochefort (viz. 8, or 10 for that matter).
good, a bit more on the bitter side than the abt 12. similar dark pleasant color, high density effervescence, id prefer the abt 12 or the trippel over it.
Wow, another solid brew. Looks almost perfect. Dark murky amber, with a nice tan head. Smooth drinker, and full bodied.

Finally entering all my "Better Know a Style: Belgian Strong Ale" tasting 07 results.  Very yeasty, dark fruit aroma with some nuttiness as well.   Looked very nice as well with a dark brown color and large off-white head.  Flavor was moderate malt sweet with some spice and dark fruit, also some biscuit in there as well.  A nice med body with some carb.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2013 33cl 8% bought in Belgium.
Heavy, very dark, opaque beer, dark-brown red when held to the light. Bubbly with a creamy head.
A bitter yeasty, leathery, woody smell with hints of lemon and an alcoholic background.
Bitter-sweet taste, with the sweet dominating, with a burnt hop, caramel, chocolate palate. Well balanced, quietly fizzy with a nice warm, round aftertaste. Good quality in the Rochefort tradition. A little bit too alcoholic on the smell.

Cloudy mahogany with a small off-white head.  Malt, dark fruits, vanilla, and musty spice in the aroma.  Heavy malt backbone with spun sugar, corriander, raisins, and a sherry-like alcohol flavor.  Dense, sticky mouthfeel.  A little too thick and sweet for me.

Pours an amber/brown, with a thick sweet palate and a tatse, that while not as complex and favoursome as the 12, still has enough rich dark fruits and sweet malts to be a very good example of the style.
Flaske. Superlæækker, og til min glæde faldt den også i svogerens smag. Han svor der straks skulle placeres et par i køleskabet. Han er kok og har altid svoret til vin.
Visible sediment  abounds when this beer is poured. A strong aroma rises quickly. Very flavorful, with constant changes. A predominately sweet maltiness throughout and a long-lasting finish.
Brownish red in color, medium head. Lacing is sticky and long lasting. Taste is moslty caramel like most of these styles. Maybe a slight hint of cherry thrown in. Nice beer overall.

light cola color with very small head, strong lemon aroma with some caramel and dark fruit notes. medium viscous, cloying body. bittersweet lemon peel, toffee, raisin wine and a light cocoa spiciness, real light alcohol undertone.

Brugge. Malte, coffee, cacao, spices. Carbonated in the measure. Present but not evident alcohol........................................... Malte, café, cacau, especiarias, temperos. Carbonatada na medida. Álcool presente mas não evidente. Encorpada.

Dan, my puppy really digs this beer. Poured a thimbles worth in a glass and she attacked the glass with a vengeance. She then went after the bottle trying to lick inside the neck. Took some pics and I may change my profile pic to one of the photos.

Poured a dark, dark brown that seemed to have a purple tinger to it. Poured into my delerioum tremens glass and had to space out the pour because a big, frothy head that was stained a slight khaki. Nose was aromatically malty and sweet.

Flavor was a superb dubel. Lots of rich malts. Belgian sugars provided a nice solid base to this beer. Dark fruits such as prunes and dark cherries. Bits of dark grabes and dried raisins too. Could not pick out any heat from the alcohol at all but it sure hit m pretty good. Vinuous and heavy mouthfel that did a great job just coating the cheeks.

murky black with fluffy brown head. chocolate and roasted malts in aroma. outstanding variety of flavors in the taste and palate - perhaps a little fizzy but the rest is great. might be the best strong ale ive ever had

Draft. Moderate notes of caramel and milk chocolate with a light perfume and dough smell and dates and raisin in the background. Virtually no head (but Ill bet the bottled version has a decent head) with a clear dark brown color. taste starts moderately sweet and lightly acidic and finishes lightly acidic. Medium bodied, between watery and oily, and a soft carbonation. This beer is fruitier than the Abt 12 but less chocolatey. Definitely a good one though.

Bottle. Has a dark golden brown color with great ruby hues and topped with a medium offwhite head. Aroma was definitely highly fruity most noticeable are plums, grapes and green apples mixed with low honey hints. Flavor is mild and not overpowering. Actually quite amazing in its evolved blending of fruits and this smooth honey taste and feeling coats the tongue. Loved every drop

Rated 7/8/07.  Pours a cloudy, dark mahogany with a large, frothy off-white head.  Lacing was thick and coated the entire glass.  Aroma was that of sweet roasted malts, molasses, dark fruits, white grapes, and some spice.  I picked up the same components in the flavor, and they progressed well from the front of the mouth to the back.  Very complex.  A little on the sweet side for me, but not too bad.  Smooth finish, with a dark fruit aftertaste.  Very nice beer.  Really opens up as it warms in the glass.

Pours a dark brown with hints of red, with a small white head.  Smells of dark fruits, berries, and dark malts.  Some caramel too.  The taste is much of the same.  Pretty fruity, with alot of berry flavor to it.  Very sweet too, get some rasisns and dark malts in th finish.  Leaves a sweet residue on the lips and the palate.  Good beer.

Pours a deep brown with another nice, fluffy head with lacing.  Aroma is highly spicy and fruity, and I think I noticed a little citrus thrown in.  The flavor is heavily malty and smooth, another great beer from St. Bernardus
nose is BIG ripe fruit, and malt with a slight yeast aroma. Flavour is big and rich. lots of ripe fruit, and a nice maltiness that really coats your palate. really nice ale.

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2007 Bottle at the Hopdevil in Zagreb Poured a big beige thick but fluffy head that dissipated slowly on top of a lovely deep red body. The nose was nice and complex... raisins, dust, peach, malt, honey and alcohol. The taste is quite malt-driven, with a strong and warming presence of alcohol in the backgroundl. Almost too strong for the 8%, but not unpleasant at all. Honey, raisins, a bit chewy background hopiness. The taste starts out silky smooth until it shatters on the reef of alcohol. All in all, a really good beer.
Bottle. Pours hazy caramel, fluffy off white head. Aroma is dried fruit, malt, slight metal and spices. Flavor is dried fruit, wheat, grass, caramel.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2007 Dark chestnut colored hazy body, and a persistent off-white head. Malty, fruity aroma with lots of candy sugar, and some caramel, vanilla, cinnamon - like speculaas cookiedough;  that peculiar St. Bernardus yeastiness. Well-rounded malty taste, with notes of coffee, chocolate, vanilla, speculaas cookies, ginger, cinnamon; a spectacular interplay of malt- and yeast-complexity. Long finish, coffee-like (moccha), deeply malty. Some hop-bitterness  in the finish, which provides a nicely dry edge. Thick, but not too heavy on the palate, with subdued carbonation. Less intense but overall more rounded & balanced than the Abt12. The excellent price/quality ratio, plus the reasonable ABV% makes this one of the best beers I know.

Pours a deep dark opaque mahagony color with some fizzy offwhite head, kinda looks like coke in a way.  Sweet malty aroma with some banana and molases.  sweeter aroma than i had expected really.  Mouthfeel is rather light on the tongue but still has a nice flavor to it.  Dark fruits, warming alcohol burbony undertone, and doughy.  Overall, very enjoyable, perfect for a summer night.

Great looking cloudy rich dark brown color with deep red tones.  One cm thick white head.  Deep molasses and Belgian malt aromas.  Raisin, plum, coriander, mild cloves on the taste.  Surprised by the complexity of this one.  Very rich smell and taste, but not too heavy.

330. Pours a deep dark brown with a towering, fluffy, sudsy white head. Lots of clingy lace. Big malty sweet husky grain nose with some old wet leaves funk and maybe a little bit of basement thrown in there. Soft carb on the attack, medium body, very clean and drinkable, restrained flavors--nice, well-modulated attack.Rich, earthy, deep and dark flavors all over the mid-palate; delicious and drinkable. Very restrained finish to say the least, not much going on there. Really nice stuff.
Licorice, yeast, Fernet Branca/medicine, herbs, banana, cocoa, raisins, its all there. A great and complex brew with a fine head.

750ml poured into a snifter, poured a rich dark browish color with little head, floral sweet smell almost like flowers, wonderful malt flavor, very smooth, nice breadlike tastes present aswell, very solid beer.

Sampled from a 330ml bottle.  Murky brown hue.  Beige head.  Surprising citrus nose.  Touch of cinnamon.  Medium bodied and toasty.  Sweet malts.  Mild finish.  Solid and short.  Brown sugar smoothness.  Slight burn.  Lively with a good cocoa note.  Sweet breads.  Very nice and easy drinking.

Wow, this ale was so smooth! Very well made. Got this one on tap at 33 Winebar in St. Louis. Poured a very dark brown, almost black, with a thick white foamy head. Seemed to have little aroma, and a rather mild flavor (though so well-balanced amongst the malts). A bit sweet, but nothing overpowering at all.  Overall, very excellent!
Pours a deep brown with a huge white head. Swwet malt and fruit on the nose. Sugar, rasins, plums, and sweet malt on the palate. Clean dried fruit finish.
Nice dark brown color with big, cream-colored head.  Lots of malt, well-hidden hops (they can surprise you), lots of dried fruit flavors.  Almost like a less intense version of Abt 12.

bottle.  cloudy mahogony with frothy off white head.  big matls, baked wheat bread, floral hops, fig and raison aroma.  smooth, medium body.  sweet malts, mild sugars that fade as it warms, dark fruits.  some bready notes.  dry and slightly bitter finish.  very nice.

Classy and classic belgian. Hazy brown look with a huge head, collapsing abit faster than the nr 12 one. Aroma is rich of different esters, raisin, prunes and bananas. Palate is exploding yet velvet, allowing the different esters to show in the moutharoma aswell. Flavor is very complex, triggering all your tastebuds in an extremly plesant way. Nice warming finish and a tickling mouthfeel. Good one

330 mL bottle.  Hazy medium brown with big foamy white head.  Aroma of yeast, raisins, sugar, and malt.  Sticky and lively palate.  Taste of molasses and candy finishing with a spicy alcoholic warmth.  Quite good.

Shared bottle. I only had a small sample of this, but it seemed excellent. Definately the same family as my favourite Abt 12. Malts, caramel. Full mouthfeel. I really wish I could get my hands on a full bottle.

Bottle at Trappistenhuis, Gent. Huge off-white and creamy head on top of this dark brown beer. Maybe served a bit too cold to fully enjoy the yeasty and somewhat spicy aromas. Caramel flavours with spicy yeastiness and alcohol. Full-bodied, medium carbonation. A beer that oozes craftmanship.

11.2oz Bottle

Poured the Prior 8 into its very own St. Bernardus goblet. Poured a murky deep dark brown/garnet with yeast sediment even after a careful pour. A one finger head off white head sat on top that faded to a thin cap rather quickly. The body is loaded with small sediment. It does look inviting though like there is going to be all kinds of flavors coming through.

The smell has a lot of fruitiness to it. Figs and prunes come to mind first. An earthy mustiness comes through barely noticeable along with an old and slightly leathery quality. The backbone of this beer is a lightly toasted bread aroma. All this goes very nicely together.

The flavor is where its at. There is a very noticeable sweetness but its layer upon layer of flavors that casue this sweetness. The dark fruits come through first. Prune and fig just like in the nose sprinkled with some brown sugar. The earthiness comes next with must and a dark old leathery taste. All going very nicely together I must add. As I type this I notice its the exact same as the aroma but without the toasted bread. Its more along the lines of dough. I even get hints of chocolate as I sip. Finishes with a candy sweetness. Really nicely made.

Mouthfeel is key on this beer as well. Its very creamy and as it slides along my mouth, right before the swallow, it turns almost to froth. Fits very well with all the other aspects. The body is coating.

Drinkability is good. Its an easy one to put away. I cant drink too much of any Belgian but this is an easy one to do so. 

Another wonderfully made beer from St. Bernardus. An easy drinker for sure and one I will enjoy over and over.

1/8/07
Dark brown with off white head.  Dark fruits.  Nearly as good as the Abt 12.
light brown w/ medium head. fuity, malty aroma.  mostly molasses and malt flavor. nice mouthfeel. very good overall

Tap=served in St Bernardus glass.  Average, fizzy, off-white head into cloudy brown body.  Aromas of chocolate, light alcohol, spicyness, malts, and dark fruit.  Flavor is slightly bitter with some sweetness.  Thoroughly impressive brew.

On tap.  Beautiful chestnut brown pour and pleasing aroma.  The flavor is chocolate covered raspberries, with emerging hints of caramel and toffee.  There is also a vanilla or vanilla-blossom lacing which adds excellent dimension to the brew.  An excellent beer.  I go back and forth as to whether I like this one of the Abt 12 better - theyre both phenomenal.

Pours a dark burgundy to maroonish brown with a good bit of a haze and a big offwhite head, slowly settling, leaving very nice lacing.  The nose is big and sweet.  Rich full malt.  Sweet dark fruit, raisins, figs, and prunes come to mind.  A little bit of lemon, a little creamy.  Definitely some berry.  Creamy, rich and rather viscous.  Full and smooth on the tongue.  The flavors are very vinous.  Big ass grape.  Big sweet malt.  This almost reminds me of some renditions of scotch ales.  Not the type of scotch ale rendition I generally enjoy, but this is really very much better.  Creamy big sweet malt.  Even a bit of diacetyl, which is strange for a Belgian, but it seems appropriate here.  Very fruity, big grape, berry, and dark fruit.  Some light toast.  A little acid in the surprisingly dry slightly buttery finish.  The lingering slight tartness of a Belgian in the aftertaste is accompanied by toast.  I enjoy this, and for 7.50 a bottle, the price is right.

Bottle. Reddish/brown colored with a haze. Dense tanned two finger head. Yeasty and semi-dry malt aroma with some earthy hop scents and cellar notes. Predominant malt taste; gently sweet and roasty. Lots of fruitiness (raisins, plums and berries) in the background. Mild bittering hops. Medium to full body. Nice, quite dry and hopbitter finish.

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2007 At this point in the tasting, I was quite inebriated.  However, with how much taste was there, I was impressed.  I need to try this one again for sure.

**ADDING**

So I tried it again...my rating actually went up.  The aroma is very heavy and complex.  Deep flavours of caramel and molasses.  Somehow though, the character still remained light.  This may be my favourite of the St. Bernardus series.

300ml bottle.Pours a murky, hazy chestnut brown with tiny flecks of yeast hanging in stasis throughout the liquid. Big, tightly packed poofy white head forms on pour, gradually settling down but leaving a pretty thick ring around the edge of the glass. That rim leaves clods of Brussels lace all over the sides of the glass as the liquid moves down with each gulp. Aroma is very bready/yeasty with strong, weird hints of multivitamins. Flavor is rich, nutty, yeasty, earthy & malty-sweet with some notes of dark berries and hazelnut. Truly fascinating stuff. Palate is thick with a nutty aftertaste. Interesting.

Dark murkey brown thick fluffy tan head. Nice lacing moves into a nose full of sweet dark fruit, and a nut/plant I cant pick out. Sweet, but still balanced, a real treat to drink. I think Im finally getting these monks!

Pours a dark brown with a foamy off-white head.  Excellent lacing.  Beautiful.  Aroma is of raisins, malty richness.  Chocolatey taste, mild.  Very heavy  coffee notes, great taste, yet slightly sour.  Fruity, with slight alcohol warming.  Nice palate.

Had  to re-rate:  As it warms, it becomes a different beer.  I can now taste so much more cream, and fruit its amazing.  Much better as it warms in your glass over an hour or so.

750mL bottle.  When I untwisted the cage just enough, the cork exploded out of the bottle.. glancing off my forehead into the abyss.. since Im in a hotel room, I really couldnt care less.  The brew poured a moderately deep reddish-brown with a tall, rocky cap of creamy beige head.  The aroma picked up dried berries and vinous notes with a pinch of dust and some roasty caramel.. only complaint is that the dust got a little in the way at times... really good, though.  The flavor was even better.. toasty caramel, molasses, and vinous fruits form a formidable flavor core with brilliant accents of dusty, peppery spices from the heavy yeast presence and some alcohol warmth.  A hair greater than medium-bodied, and almost syrupy across the middle.. great contrast of dusty and spicy notes at the edges.  This was some really good stuff!

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2008 Brown with a loose short lived foam head, strong slightly sour malt nose, bit too much fizz, rich roast malt with little bitter malt linger, and a bit too yeasty 2.8...  Tk2  Big thanks to Joris for this aged bottle  Deep copper colour ... sweet bready with plums nose ... rich sweet bready malty treacly ... plums raisins ... madiara ... this bottle is in stark contrast to the previous bottle. must try another fresh one to see if its the age that make the difference.

Bottle.  Pours a medium brown color with a moderately sized head.  Aroma is dark fruits, malts and some vinous notes.  Flavor is molasses, dark fruits, malt and yeast.  Medium body with a decent mouthfeel.  Quite enjoyable.

A very good dubbel. Not as sickeningly sweet as many other dubbels.
Harmonic yet complex.

Bottle.  Had this the other night to celebrate bringing home my 4 day old daughter from the hospital.  St. Bernardus makes wonderful beers.  This is sweet and spicy and utterly delicious.   You can actually taste the wonderful belgian sugars in this one.   Delicious.

Bottle. Outstanding dark brown head. Aroam and taste of lots of fruit: Plum, cherry, nut and orange. So full of flavour and taste. The best dubbel I´ve ever tasted! Perfect head, beautiful colour. warm finish.

Bottle at Steelgarden in Bethlehem, PA.  Pours an impressive dark brown with reddish hints.  Cream -colored head with impressive lacing.  Aroma is fruity-cherries with some malt.  Taste is acomplex combination of fruits, malts, and yeast.

Bottle at Delirium Cafe, Brussels.  Pours a deep brown with nice red highlights in the light.  Aroma is sweet and fruity, with berries and cherries.  Some yeast funk presence as well as slight spice is noticeable.  A bit of alcohol warming upfront in the taste, along with dark pit fruits and a lingering sweetness.  There is also a nice, slight, subdued chocolate dark malt presence as well as some dough.  Slightly sour in the finish.  Palate is a bit flat, uninspired.

Beautiful deep mahogany beer with sandy colored head.  Light floral nose with malty sweetness.  The lingering velvet foam ads a great ads a wonderful creamy fullness to the mouthfeel before the sour, sweet, and malty flavors break through.  Minimal bitterness just to balance the malt.  A bit of spicy hop comes through on the finish.
Very deep amber pour with decent head.  Aroma is mild but good, dark and sour.  Flavor is yeasty and sour with a dark maltiness.  Very good.  Palate is nice too, not too thick like the 12.

Sweet in the nose, sweet flavor.  Burnt toast and some light spicy yeast, some maple and even bacon scent, some brown sugar dough, that’s the heaviest scent.    Doughy, chewy and thin but not watery at all, more like doughy, I keep coming back to that word, but for this beer it’s probably the best descriptor.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2007 Bottle: drinking it as a toast with my brother and father for our Independence day, well its a really nice beer, light-medium bodied. quite malty, fruity, yeasty, some honey, some molasess, dried fruits, spicy and nice bitterness.
CHEERS!

11.2 oz bottle, best by date marked 07 12 06. Geez, I hope its not stale... lol. Hazy brown with a dense off white head. Sweet, vinous nose, malty, plummy and light molasses. Flavor is full of dark fruits and molasses, sweetly malty. Medium to light body, beautiful sheet of tight lace. Alcohol is well hidden, but a light burn in the gullet hints at the 8%. A bit of bread and spice pops up in the finish. Excellent.

Bottle:  Pours a cloudy brown, on the lighter side, with a large beige head.  Nose is fruity, yeast, and malt.  Taste is fruity up front with a deeper malt body.  Some hints of spices and a rum-raison character.  Overall a sweeter taste and lingering, warm finish.  Very good.

Bottled bought at the Bier Temple, Brussels. Pours redish brown with a nice lacing head. Aroma is fruity and malty. Taste is also fruity and malty. Very nice balance between bitterness and alcohol. Notes of caramel and some licorice
Delrium Cafe Brussels: really nice, great earthy taste, dark, malty, lovely...just like the girl working the bar that day

Bottle.  Very nice, but I would have expected nothing less.  Great beer just to look at - slightly murky brown with red highlights, larger than usual off-white head that lasts and laces, floating filament is apparent when held to the light.  Sweet and malty but delicately balanced. A quality brew.  Anything from st. Bernardus should be tried.

Bottle.  Pours a reddish brown with a small, airy beige head.  Strong, complex aroma of brown sugar, sweet fruits, dark malts, a teeny bit of alcohol.  Nice.  Smooth, rich fruity taste.  Sweet and chewy.  This brewery rocks.  I like the 12 better but this is stunning as well.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2007 Massive off white head - the aroma is very sweet - smell fruit, plums, raisons, etc.  very nice and pleasant.  Dark brown color with a lot of movement.  Has a rather salty like finish to me, pretty sour..not really as expected.  Definately give a big nod to the 12.

33cL bottle.  Poured a clear, dark brown with an off-white head.  Sweet aroma of molassas.  Smooth taste and similar to Westy 8 but slightly less complex.  It hid its alcohol well too.  Recommend trying this beer.

Rich, dark brown color and a beautiful tan head that stays. Big aroma! mostly raisin, figs, sweet plantains, other dark fruits and alcohol. malty flavor with lots of spice and a bit of sugar. palate finishes nicely with some yeast and a fruity complexity. great, but the Abt 12 is obviously better!
Bottle. 12OZ.  Beautiful, murky red to brown color.  Aromas of raisin, banana, caramel, and malt.  Lively carbonation.  Medium bodied.  Nice balance of sweet and sour flavors.  A fine beer.

I drank too cold but let warm for a while as drank this 1pt 9.$ oz bottle,  Mahogany hue appeared clear not hazy with white creamy head with great lacing, sweet alcoholic smell, full body, softy carbonation, creamy to syrupy texture, full body, sweet initial flavor, hints of carmel, brown sugar, mild hops, dark fruit nectar tang. BIg like a St. Bernard should be...Quality, wish I had let the bottle age more!

Bottle from Tuckers Maltings. Poured a dark brown, really lively probably losing a quarter of a bottle on the work surface as I searched for an appropriate glass. What was left of the beer had a large beige fluffy head and there was a strong but sweet malty and dark fruit aroma mmmhh very nice. Some toffee like flavours along with the dark fruits, bit spicey and some molasses as well. A really very good beer and deservedly so but there are better in this category.

Deep, reddish brown appearance with a large tan head and good lacing.  Complex aroma full of soft fruits, sweet malts and yeast.  Medium-to-full bodied, delightfully carbonated mouthfeel.  Taste is well balanced, moderately hopped, with a mix of rich fruit and caramel malts along with earthy, vinous qualities.  Pleasant, long lasting, sweet fruit finish.

Bottle. Pours a dark amber with slight reddish hue. Big frothy head. Very yeasty aroma, very fresh. Generously carbonated, very malty, bready. This beer felt very smooth on the palate.  Honey, cherry, carmel. Abrupt finish. This is a great standard for a Belgian Strong Ale.

Pours a generous head and active carbonation. The aroma is both fruity and yeasty, and is made up of cherries, plums, bread, honey, and currant. The flavors are quite nice, most of the fruit is evident, as is a bit of toffee and chocolate. A nice feel in the mouth and a moderate finish.

Bottle. Light brown with red tint. Large dense foamy head with hang time and thick lacing. Bready malty aroma, a bit grassy, pleasant, fresh. Still waiting for the head to subside. Heavy body, very malty sweet caramel. Alcohol is very apparent in flavor and warmth. Very nice belgian.

Another goody from my Tokyo trip earlier this month. Brown with ruby hues, a foamy but short lived beige head, leaves plenty of lacing. Loads of sweet rich malt, caramel, cardamom, prunes & alcohol, a busy nose.
Sweet with plenty of rich fruit dessert flavors, familiar Belgian yeast and a dry tannin bittersweet finish with a warm alcohol follow. This reminds me why Belgians Strongs are one of my favorite styles!
Bottle.  Borwn sugar color.  1 micro-bbble foam.  Banana, lightly yeasty, tart aroma.  Less bite than expected on the tongue.  Smooth, dry finish.  Honey, nutty.  Very nice.  Ill have another.

BB 10/2010
Deep brown beer with a creamy tan head.  Sweet fruity aroma, cherry, plums, mint, and a soft sweet spiciness.  Clove, cardamon, raisins and dark toasted wheat spiciness all make an appearance.  Very fruity and spicy on the palate as well, but it manages to remain quite light as well.  Flavour of plums, clove, cinnamon and cardamon.  Rich sweet toastiness and a touch of wheat/rye character.  Sweet plums/raisins and a minty finish.  Lingering yeasty breadiness.  A rich and elegant brew.

11.2 oz bottle sampled at "Better Know a Style: Belgian Strong Ale" Blind Tasting 07.  Rasin colored with a fizzy off-white head.  Moderately malty aroma, dark bread, cookie, molasses, chocolate, dough, raisin, plum, cherry, toffee, and vanila.  Light sweet aroma, bakers chocoalte, raisin, plum, cherry spice, cardamon, nutmeg, corriander, balanced really well.  Light body, with creamy texture and soft carbonation.  Lightly bitter finish.  This one is damn tasty and my second place for the night.

This beer was disappointing. It started out nice. The pour was a great pour, the color was a darkish brown. The head was nice, but not too powerful. The flavor was lacking. I am considering this to be just as good as the Pater 6. As the beer warms the flavors beginning to open up, but they never fully mature as I was hoping they would. I taste a slightly bitter caramel flavor, but as I stated it doesnt even reach its maximum potential as the Abt 12 does. The Abt 12 opens up on your tongue and leaves a flavor that one can taste. This is subordinate the the Abt 12, but should still be complimented for its taste. Accolades to St. Bernard Brouwerij.

Color is dark, opaque brown. The serving I received had a nice thick but not overly persistent head. Smell is delightful and very tempting. Flavor is rich with smoky undertones, and this beer feels smooth and tingly. I was quite impressed, and will certainly order this one again if I get the chance.

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2007 Tasted 2007-03-08. 3 year old bottle. Stored properly. BB 2009, but still, I suspect it was way past its prime. It poured nicely - off white head, that disappeard quite fast. The Aroma was OK, but nothing special; malt, citrus - maybe a little caramel. Flavour was initially a bit bitter then turned sour. Not nearly as much flavour, as I know this beer is capable of having. Overall it seemed a little watery, and the aftertaste was not optimal. It was an OK beer but only OK. I have tasted this many times before, and this was the worst bottle of them all - and the only one of this age. Im disappointed!

Bottle at ZBF. Dark brown color, geige head. Aroma: roasty malt, yeasty. Taste is complex, smoky, smooth, yeasty and malty. Like im more as the 12.
Full body.

DELICIOUS! This dark belgian was heavy in taste and sediment. Creamy mouthfeel with tastes of chocolate covered fruit. Caramel and alcohol in the after taste. This is one complex and beautiful Belgian that I will buy more of.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: 33 cl bottle, best before 27/04/10, courtesy radiomgb. Beautiful mahogany amber colour with a mostly lasting frothy and creamy off-white head. Raisin, cherry, plum, chocolate, more dark fruit, and light apple aroma with alcohol notes. Rich flavour of raisin, plum, fig, and other dark fruit lightly dipped in chocolate and perhaps a touch of rum and port. Full bodied, rich mouthfeel with lively carbonation and just warming enough to convince you to take your time and savour every sip. Wasnt expecting all that much after trying the 6, this one just kept improving with every sniff and taste.
Pours like rootbeer nice foamy tan head that remains about a quarter inch. Aroma of yeast and fruit. Tastes a little fizzy, touch of malt, spice, honey, balanced with a nice finish.

0.75l bottle. nice cloudy brown appearance, spicy aroma of cinamon, clove and cardamon, finish very long and lingering. A bit like drinking panaforte (a spicy tuscan dried friut cake). Excellent with a seafood stir fry.
Overall a great beer.

sampled at blind "Better Know a Style: Belgian Strong Ale" tasting 07. poured muddy brown, with a great big off-white head that lasted. nose was very nice, toasted nuts, molasses, yeasty, and plums. flavor was nicely balanced, toasty, cookie, cardamom, and plums. palate is a tad thin with alcohol in the finish.

This beer pours a dark beige/brown color with a creamy tan head with large bubbles.  I smelled dried fruit and carmel on the nose.  This is a well balanced beer and I would strongly recommend this.  After tasting this, I am excited to taste 12.

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2011 Medium big-bubbled beige head.  Deep red body with carbonation.
Earthy linoleum and caramel aroma with spicy musty notes.
Unusual.  Sweet-dryish buttery caramel and licorice taste with
cocos and spice notes.  Fullish body.  Mild, soft mouthfeel with
slight slickness.  Dryish spicy cinnamon and earth aftertaste
with butterscotch and licorice notes.  Recognizably St Bernardus.
Really nice. (0.33l bottle, Bier Tempel, Brussels. Rated in 2007, rerate in 2011.)

Blackish beer with ruby highlights. Beige head, creamy and sticky. In the nose: dried fruit, Ill go with raisins and apples. Malty flavor with some dried fruit, but its smooth--not the same party you get with the 12. Mouthfeel more bubbly than creamy. Finish is mild and balanced among malt, bitterness and alcohol. A first-class beer, but kick it up to the 12 when youre really in the mood to contemplate.
UPDATED: MAR 11, 2007 not as deep tastings as the abt but still agreeable.  this is still a damn good beer.

11.2 oz. bottle. Pours a slightly hazy ruddy orange-brown color. Produces a beautiful huge, fluffy and rocky tan head which maintains a 1/4" thickness throughout the glass. Quite intense and pleasant aromas of fresh baked wheat rolls, yeast, ripe pears/apples, caramel candies, toffee along with faint hints of buckwheat honey, spices, charred oak and alcohol. Palate is full and round combining a nice spritzy carbonation with an enjoyable chewy texture. Flavor profile seems a bit more reserved compared to the aroma, but still quite good. Notes of sweet Belgian crystal malts, light brown sugar, caramel, toffee, spices, fresh dark wheat bread and ripe light fruits are savored. Finish shows just a quick hit of hops and alcohol, but unfortunately tends to fade out fast leaning toward some thiness in the end. All in all a well done Belgain Dubble and would certainly visit this again.

Thanks to secret Santa for this one.  12oz bottle.  Hazy, murky, chunky, caramel colored brew.  The aroma is heavy with dates, raison bread and sweet malt.  The flavor is similar with bread, dates, yeasty malt, light fruit and perhaps hints of sherry.  Chewy body.  A solid brew.  Glad Im having this one at my tasting next month.
Malty, with some sour notes in the aroma. The flavor was most noticeably of malts, with raisin, yeast, a little spice. Undoubtedly good, but not the best of the Belgians.

Bottle.  First impression was a good slightly hazy amberish pour with the typical foamy head.  The aroma seemed a bit sour and dry, not the sweet maltiness I am accustomed to.  At first the taste was a bit more sour than others, maybe a bit prunish or raiseny.  Definitely not as good as the 12, but good nonetheless.

Aroma: I felt somthing strange and I cant say what it is
Appearance: brown, hazy, small head (not minimal)
Flavor: sweet (chocolate?)
Palate: full body, creamy, lively, long finish!!!
Overall: interesting
Rich. Malty. Have had on tap and in the bottle. While not the original recipe, still a Belgian favorite.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2009 Strong thick malty aroma.  Tan frothy head with thick brown body, very impressive thickness to the head.  Strong malty flavor as well.  Well carbonated.  Light bitter dried fruit accents.    Good malt heavy beer with a decent duration.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy brown with a large fluffy off white head with nice lacing.  A nice big of flavor and aroma of malt, dark fruits, yeast some faint hints of chocolate.  A nice finish that is somewhat thick on the tongue.

Bottle, poures a hazy dark brown with a thick head.  Nice aromas of malts, yeast, fruits, brown sugar.  Very similar to the Pater 6.  I wonder if they do the same as Rochefort and just make 3 strengths of the same beer?  Either way, nice flavor, spicy yeast that marries with the rich maltiness and flavors of dried fruits.  Wonderful mouthfeel and a lingering finish.  Very nice beer.
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text: Draught at The White Horse on Parsons Green (London), a deep colour with ruby tints and a creamy off-white head. A subtle nutty aroma, not quite what I was expecting. Full bodied, with an alcohol presense and both chocolate and coffee flavours. Good.

UPDATED: APR 23, 2008 Boozy, raisiny, brandyish snout. Smoothly roasty malt and creamy liquorice. Possibly a wisp of smokiness. Imparts a metallic sensation on the tongue. Mildly Marmite-yeasty, underwhelming at first, but becoming increasingly complex as it warms. Smoky, smooth, yeasty and malty. And thats enough for me.
(re-rate, 23/04/08, previously 7/3/8/4/16) Heady nose of booze, chewy dried fruit, sticky prune, Westy8 nuttiness and choc, a pinch of aniseed. Alcohol big and glowy, but smoothed out with berry fruit, currant, liquorice, peaty malt. Late savoury breadiness (smudged with Marmite), again like the dark Westies, but without the hop spike on the end. An eggcup of Everards Original (?).Tasty ale, a touch too sweet and alcohol-accented to break my top...91.

Bottle. Dark brown colour with a nice big long lasting light brown head. Medium roasted maltiness in the aroma, moderate caramel,  dark fruits and yeast. Flavour is smooth with  a bready like maltiness, good fruitiness, caramel, plums and raisins, bit of alcohol, some hops. Sweet malty bit dry finish. Great tasting beer.

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2013 Re-rate 11/13: Bottle sample at a tasting at  Norma Jean. Bottled 2006. Hazy brown with a beige head. Aroma of dark fruits, malt, a bit of chocolate, nuts, yeast, caramel, candy-ish notes. Sweet flavor, malty, fruity, caramelly, yeasty, finishes a bit spicy and alcoholic. Medium-bodied. 6/3/6/3/13=3.1

Re-rate 7/10: Bottle. Clear deep reddish-brown with a huge beige head. Decent lacing. Vinous aroma of dark fruits, alcohol, caramel and some licorice notes. Sweet flavor of brown sugar, some prunes and raisins, some dark bread, yeast and a drier alcoholic finish with some spiciness, licorice and herbal notes. Medium-full body. 7/4/6/4/13=3.4

(Re-rated on 6/9/07. Numbers are the same. Added a bit to the description). Bottle. Dark brown color. A big head that disapears rather fast. Aroma is malt, caramel and spices. Sweet malts, spices and dark fruits (mostly plums) in the flavor. Finish is rather dry, a bit bitter, with a bit of alcohol. A medium body. 7/4/7/4/15=3.7

Pours a hzy ruby-brown color, with a good 3" of almost pinkish tan head. The foam looks a lot like soft soap suds. Good lacing. Bread dough, beer yeast, and alcohol in the aroma.

Very flavorful with sweet fig, brown sugar, wheat bread, toffee, and mild chocolate malt. Dry spice and alcohol in the finish. Somewhere between medium and full bodied, moderately carbonated

11.2 oz bottle - Clear dark brown/ruby red color with medium sized creamy off white head. Aroma is full of cherries, hints of caramel, bit of vanilla, dates, figs, red grapes. Flavor is malty, fair amount of light caramel, bit of dates and oak, with a relatively sweet finish.

Cloudy dark amber with a thick, tight white head. Malty body with a sweet, plumlike finish.Notes of raisin, candied sugar, wood. Very pleasant lingering aftertaste. Very full on the palate. Very good brew.
Nice, rich malty flavor.  Just a bit shy of being as good as the 12.  Definitely worth a try if you like the style.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2009 Dark burgundy body.  Initially large head that quickly diminishes to a long-lasting thin off-white layer.  Aroma of toasted bread and coffee-shop.  Taste has a lot of toasted malts, light chocolate (not the dark bitter type), some nuts.  The beer is only moderately fruity with some raisins and maybe plums flavours.  Very little hop presence and almost no bitterness.  No alcohol flavour at all.  This is a rather smooth round beer, not aggressive at all, with a soft foamy body.  As good as it may be it lacks something to make it stand out, to give it its own character.  High quality, reliable, well put together but ultimately unexceptional.  The Mazda 6 of Belgian beer.

poursa cloudy amber hue with a light, slight off-white head.  Aromas of caramel, toffee, some oats and some yeasty goodenss.  Mouthfeel is medium -light bodied with flavors remiscent of the 12, but very soft.  Raisins, caramel,  some orange peel and a hint of bitter-sweet chocolate.
Bottle. Nice big creamy tan head with good duration. Color is dark. Aroma is sweet and fruity with lots of spices. Taste is likewise.
Not quite the 12 but a enjoyable none the less. not a heavy body, nice off-white head, initial tastes of raisins and maybe grapefruit. nice smooth finish

Dark dark beer.  Head poured over two fingers high (and I drink mine out of schooners, which look like giant goblets- they work well but dont have the slight taper).  Not as bitter as many trappist ales, but also bit less overall body.  It still has complexity though, a bit of caramel sweetness, raisins or perhaps fresh grapes, and maybe even a bit of citrus.  Easily drinkable and alcohol is well-hidden.

Poured from bottle...Murky brown with even an almost greenish tint to it. Very little head. Smell was sweet, yeasty. Taste was VERY light. Not what I was expecting...Tasted like waterd down apple cider...I really could have drunk it straight down. I preferred the number 6, I think. This one was a bit light for me...Maybe a bad bottle? As I detcted no after taste, no bitterness, nothing...

11.2 oz bottle- Poured a hazy, mirky brown color w/a moderate tan head & good lacing which lasted thru the brew. Light floral Belgian aroma. Clean crisp fruity flavor w/a touch of sweetness. Traces of lemon/lime, cotton candy, & spice. Light to medium finish w/ some malt bitterness. Good Ale, very drinkable. Alcohol was well hidden.
Bottle (75cl) at work - shared with Jesper & Rune. Unclear brown - light yellow head. Licorice, yeast, wheat, malty, nice hopped, resin, grass, cirtus. Sommth finish - nice !!

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2009 BB 04-11.  Pour is hazy with noticeable, dark brown with deep red highlights; head is beige, average-sized, and pillowy/fizzy which settles quickly to a lasting creamy layer and leaves some nice lace.  Nose is a scaled down version of the 12; Belgian chocolate, light caramel, raisin, plum, nutmeg, and light doughy yeast.  Flavor is nice with light chocolate, plum, and raisin with some clove and brown sugar.  Palate is medium-full, very lively, and almost round; a bit too carbonated.  Finishes with some earthy bitterness but still sweet with light chocolate and plum and a moderate length.  Much better than the 6 but nothing in comparison to the 12.  Lacks the great richness and complexities, but is highly drinkable.  Very nice strong Belgian, just not up to the level of the Abts.

12 oz. bottle, part of a St. Bernardus sampler 4-pack, complete with logod Trappist glass.  Excellent balance of all the dark fruit elements youd expect to find in a BSA, with spiciness and a wee bit of alcohol burn.  Not *quite* Abt 12, but its a great concoction, and perhaps the next best thing?

33cL bottle from A-1 To-Go in Gardiner.  Dark brown body with less than a quarter inch of off-white head and feint ruby-red highlights.  Smells peaty and kind of nutty.  Aroma is not that prominent.  Roasty chocolate and date notes dominate the flavor with hints of nut.  On the upper side of medium bodied with a fair bit of carbonation.  Very drinkable despite the thickness of it.  Fantastic.  Better than all Ive tried from them except Abt.

Sweet plum and other dark juicy fruit aroma fizzes out of well carbonated beer that poured with a dark brown body an off white head. The beer is very sweet flavourd with lots of yeasty fruit flavours, again plums with an addition of prunes or raisins that hides in the background and doesnt taste exactly alike. Again this is well carbonated and dances aroubnd my tounge, making it hard to really get the flavours out of it.

Pours a dark cloudy brown with a nice white head.  Big aroma, sweet caramel and fruit.  Yeasty and sweet, can  notice some chocolate in the flavor.  Not as dry as the Pater 6, but much more complex.  Worth searching out.

Hazy dark amber-brown, almost purplish color.  Light brown-colored foamy head that leaves some lacing on the glass and remains on the surface infinitely.  Sweet malty aroma of dark dried fruits (cherries, dates), yeast, and some floral hints.  Huge sweet malty/yeasty flavors with a heavy presence of dried dark fruits, fresh apples, pears, cherries, and grapes.  Some light spiciness.  A soft and silky, almost creamy mouthfeel with a slightly dry finish.  A really great beer, Id never pass one of these up.

(Bottel) Pours hazy, dark redish nut brown. Fruity, a bit wineous aroma with some grapes and cherries. Raisins and marzipan. Chocolate, candy sugar and dried fruits. Cigars and some earthyness. A bit fiery from the alcohol. Rich carbonation, wineous flavour with malt, raisins and chocolate in the finish. Tones of brown sugar and alcohol. A bit salty. Pretty smooth mouthfeel and a medium body.

[bottle] Pours a dark, murky brown color, with a beautiful off-white head. Yeast, spices and a touch of alcohol in the aroma. Flavors are dark malts and fruits (prunes, dates), and some nice bready yeast character. Full bodied palate, with a touch of warming alcohol towards the finish. Very smooth and enjoyable overall.
Nose is caramel, yeasty dark fruits, alcohol.  Flavor is rich malt, sourish caramel, yeast, fruit, alcohol.

pours a cloudy dark brown with a one finger off white tannish head and has some sediment. aroma is a little bread, malt, and almost cinnamon like smell to it. light to medium body and some nice lacing. flavor is bread, malt, little cinnamon maybe, and a lttle dry hoppy aftertaste. little raisin smell and taste more so half way down the glass and when it warms, also alittle sweeter in the aroma and flavor. very nice!

Poured a dar brown hints of ruby.  Large lingering head.  Aroma of caramel, malt, fruit, yeast and spice.  Flavors much of the same. , plus some chocolate.  Picked up a warming at the end due to alcohol.  Nice and complex.

Pours very dark with hints of brownish orange shining through. It pours with a medium sized tan head that fades relatively quickly, but not completely. The aroma has caramel and malts along with some soft fruits (apricot, banana). The aroma has also hints of toffee and distinct smell of alcohol. The flavor at the beginning follows the aroma, but with much more malt and caramel than fruit. Flavors of raisin bread, bitter hops, and dark fruit (plums) reveal themselves on the middle of the tongue. The beer finishes somewhat dry and bittersweet (some roasted grain flavors showing through in the end) with virtually no after-taste. The finish also has some alcohol warming the throat as you swallow. The mouthfeel is splendid - quite creamy and light - particularly light for such a strong beer.

Dark hazy brown with a large off-white head, poor retention. Spicy christmas pudding aroma, caramel, yeast, alcohol.. so complex and inviting. The body is near perfect, full, but without a dominating alcohol. Flavours of spice, old blood plums, yeast and a warming fruity finish. Brilliant, I think Westy have a better product than St B in the ABT, but this St B thrashes the westy 8 with this beauty.

Very smooth aroma of fruit and true Belgian yeast that gvies me comfort in drinking this. Pitch dark brown hue with a creamy perfect foaming on top. Delicious in its flavor. Just so true to the style i cant believe i never picked up a bottle of this before.

Corked 750 from Ross. Pours brown with a nice off white head that laces beatifully down the glass.Fruity ester aroma, along with some alcohol.  Not as murky as I was expecting. Very earthy texture. Flavor of dark fruits, caramel, and yeast. Finish is spicy with a medium alcoholic kick. The yeast flavor coats the back of the mouth after it goes down. Nice beer. Its no Westy 8, but much cheaper and easier to get. I would love to A/B this to Rochefort 8. Thanks for another solid beer Ross. Keep them coming Mr. RR.
Aroma is very malty.Pours a murky brown with a medium head.Flavors of dark fruit and yeast.Medium mouthfeel with a sweet finish.

Pours a clear amber with a beauiful lacy off-white head. Aroma is nutty, dried fruits, chocolate and a touch of alcohol. The body is very smooth, med. body and moderate CO2. The flavors are milk chocolate, very subtle spicy hops, a touch of caramel and toffee. Finish is long and somewhat sweet.

On cask at the Bishops Arms in Helsingborg. 
Aroma: coffee, roasted, malty, slightly fruity, some sourishness, some chocolate, vinous, fantastic yeast.
Appearance: extremely dark red (almost black) w/ a pale head. 
Flavour: sweet, full-bodied, malty, hoppy afterbitterness, strange sourishness. 
Palate: soft, smooth & old.

Bottle from Whole Foods. Pours an opaque brownish color with alot of sediment floating about. Slightly sweet dark fruity aromas. THick creamy mouthfeel. Flavor is dark fruit. Roasted raisins and fig. Very rich and full flavored.

Another one of the "monk" beers that I havent seemed to gotten around to rate yet, so I figured it was high-time to step it up. Aroma was great with whiffs of dark fruit, very earthy almost like wet dirt, woody, and malty. Appearance is really deep brown, almost soft drink like in color with a nice head. Mouthfeel was soft and creamy, alcohol hidden fairly well. Flavors were nice and complex. I was getting everything from apples, dirt, wood, malty and figs.
