Hell, there were tastes that I couldnt begin to recall what they were. Overall, a nice experience and Id get this again just to sip during a cold Winters night while watching football.

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2006 Sampled from an 11.2 oz brown bottle this beer poured a dark brown color with a medium sized tan head. The aroma is somewhat faint but has sweet, yeasty and bready elements. The flavor is strong and very malty with ripe fruits - raisin and plum particularly and hints of chocolate, toffee and caramel. Wonderful!
UPDATED: AUG 15, 2008 creamy and delicious...little head on this one. Nice and chocolatey, like an understudy to the Rochefort, but still very enjoyable

This beer made me smile.  Had a different Belgian just prior (no pun intended) that didnt do the trick.  This is much better.  Dark pour with a tan head.  Warm palate and flavors.  Caramel, chocolate, malt.  Tasty.

Bottled(330ml). So far the best St.Bernardus that Ive tried. Dark brown almost black coloured, medium pale brown head, slight malty chocolate nose. Aroma is malty, spicy, caramel and cocoa with lots of fruit (raisins, plums and prunes). Nice fruity and slight alcoholic finish.
0.33l bottle at home. It was a real pleasure to drink this beer. The most distinctive is smooth, creamy mouthful and than after few seconds pleasant warmth.  Excellent beer.

Nice mahogany colour, with stable and dense head. The aroma is very fruity, with a lot of citrus, chocolate, malts and aromahops. The palate is really creamy, and the flavor has fruits, and really much chocolate and caramel, but also a little alcohol.

Pours a dark hazy brown witha decent head.  Delicious fruit, bready, sweat, and spicy aroma.  Very tasty flavors of sweet malt, dark fruit, spice, bread, plum, and belgian yeast.  Very complex, good stuff.
dark heady brew, fruits and malts, great aroma and flavour few still cellaring got in gift pack and had at many fine beer establishments in T.O.

Nice dark and cloudy, plum color with lots of foamy head.  Sweet fruits and plenty of sweet malty aroma - Taste matches the fine aroma, with a nice yeasty bite.  Plum, raisin, and sweet malt tastes blend together nicely.  A really good Belgian strong - not the best, but a quality product from a quality brewery.
pours beautifully with a good body, little too malty in the aroma but has a great taste. amen
tastes like im 10 ys. old again sipping jesus blood after the eating of his body during morning mass. yeasty, fruity, rich, heavy, holy goodness.

33cl bottle best before 2010.

Hazy amber with a lasting two finger tan head and thick lacing.

raisin, figs and a little bubble gum on the nose.

Flavor is raisin, plum , brown sugar and yeast.

Creamy mouthfeel, but it becomes a little sticky towards the end of the glass.

poured a opaque brown hue with a nice white head.  Aroma was a mix of many fruits and alcohol but also seemed to have a slight coppery hint to it.  Initally this beer had fruit notes (currants, banana) but a mild bubblegum flavor appeared. There was some coppery notes in the flavor as well.  Otherwise a good beer. It seemed to have nice carbonaton.
12 oz Bottle:  Pours a dirty brown color, and by dirty Im referring to the yeasty bits floating about.  Nice carbonation and tastes of roasted malts, raisins and figs.  A bit of a spicy aftertaste.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2006 12 oz Bottle.  Dark chestnut brown with the aroma and flavor of raisin, butterscotch, malt and fruit.  Definitely warms my throat a bit.  Creamy mouthfeel with noticible carbonation.  A quality brew.

~12oz. bottle.  Deep garnet colored and relatively clear, some yeasty floaties dance around.  Big and long lived beige head.  Fantastic lacing.  Fruity and yeasty aroma.  Plenty of sugarplums dance in my nose.  Quite rich.  Medium bodied with a nice carbonation that doesnt work over the palate.  Malty and pit fruit flavors, alcohol isnt really detectible for me.  A touch thin in the finish perhaps but overall a really nice Belgian Strong.
Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours  brown with a beige head. Aroma of citrus, fruit, and alcohol. The flavor is  citrus, fruit, and sweet. Excellent beer.

Big dark fruit and malt aroma, taste is the same, fruit becomes a little tart in the middle, there is a bite on the tongue,it seems to be over carbonated,alcohol not much of a factor, very tastey brew

33cl bottle shared with mate:  pours dark brown with moderate size head into the trappist glass.  aroma is very vinous and full of plum, raisin, and alcohol.  flavor is very complex tons of rich malt, notes of dark fruits, raisins etc.  slightly yeasty.  good palate.  solid brew.

very dark piano colour. tastes like melted down violet crumble. stench of blue cheese and vegemite. rich, heavy and tasty, without getting out of control. full body with chocolate and honey sweetness, then a long gentle drying out with coriander and rum. perfect on a cold winters night.
UPDATED: NOV 1, 2006 Like the bigger brother abt 12, but more smooth and round in tast. Very nice dark color and with a very ritch and full tast. Great beer.

Pours a nice brown with a tan head. Aroma is sweet and fruity with a touch of chocolate and belgian yeast. Nice roasty raisin & fig flavor, with a slight toffee aspect along with belgian yeasts. Finish is nice & has a slightly sweet roastyness, almost like cinnamon toast.

draft at Brick Store - Aroma is sweet dark malts, raisin, and butterscotch.  Pours dark brown with medium head and great lacing.  Flavor is rusty water until it warms enough to show off the creamy butterscotch and dark fruits with a hint of chocolate.  Palate is creamy and smooth.  A tasty brew.

I had this a BrickStore Pub on draft.  malty, blackberry?, hearty and breadlike.  deep brown color.  off white cream on top.  huge lacing in the glass.  slight aroma of butter toffee, and fig.  Probably the best dubbel Ive had!

Draft @ The Brick Store Pub.  Clear dark garnet color with a small beige head. Dark fruity aroma with out too much sweetness.  Notes of raisins along with some earthiness.  Sweet fruity flavor, more raisins, with a dry finish.  Light bitterness at the end.

draft at the Stumbling Monk in Seattle - Pours dark reddish brown.  Smells of malty sweetness and dark fruits.  The same comes through wonderfully in the flavor along with a touch of spice.  Its medium bodied with an excellent creamy mouthfeel.  Theres a hint of alcohol in the finish, but this one is so easy to drink and so good.  Great beer!
Dark brown/redish. Malty, sweet, sugary, fudgy nose. Chocolatey, malty, dried fruits in flavour, with some yeasty & almondy hints.

Draft. Beautiful smell and awesome dark appearance with nice thin head. Very good satisfying flavor that is full of a nice malty presence. Sippable and enjoyable. Reminicent of a good Rochefort. I think this is better than the 12 and a great find on draft. Cheers!

Bottle.  Dark brown, and cloudy with a reddish glow.  The head is stable and pillowy.  The aroma can be picked up from far from the glass, up close its sweeter.  The taste is sweet and malty and smooth.  The 8% is completely hidden by the strong and sweet taste.  Its a nice belgian strong on the lighter side, with a very nice feel in the mouth.

Wow this one chocked me, poured a dark brown with massive head good lacing.  Aroma was of spices alcohol and malts.  Flavor was fruity malty.  Now that mouthfeel that is where it was at so creamy perfect.

Thank you Ross for this gem. Pours a deep brown/orange with a prolific bubbly head that eventually settles into a 1/2 inch blanket. Big earthy aroma with stewed fruits, molasses, a bit of spice. Flavor is big and complex without being overwhelming. Alot more of the cooked fruit, malt, alcohol and holiday type spice. Nice warming effect, lively carbonation with a lingering sweetness. Excellent beer!!
Bottle. Dense and murky brown. Malty in aroma, full and sweet tastewise. Complex. Rock solid beer.

Pours a large head, with lots of lacing. Dark fruits are there, but not as intense as the 12, alcohol is well hidden, and I was suprised how the aftertaste wasnt too strong. Dark fruit, Abit yeasty, very drinkable, another great bier from St B.

Pours burnt orange w/ full semi creamy froth. Aroma of red licorice and rock candy. Medium to full nectar w/ ample residual effers. Flavors are slightly sweet w/ stewed apricot, peach, raisons, brown sugar, angstura bitters, anise, ginger root, cinnamon,  and chewing tobacco. The finish has a nice dry bittering.  This is one complex specimen. Well balanced, not too sweet, alcohol is well hidden. Connoiseurs choice! Highly recommended. I have to say this again. I love this brewery. Everything they do is amazing.

From a slender 11.2 oz. brown bottle with a best before date on the back label, 03.02.10, sampled at a cellar temperature in a chalice.

Poured a nice dubbel brown with a foamy, fizzy topped off-white/beige head that settled into a thin sudsy lacing, a fair amount of ringed sticking.

Aromas of caramel and bready malts, a tad buttery, plums with a trace of apple fruity and whiffs of alcohol.

Good light carbonation and a malty crisp, creamy smooth medium-light bodied mouthfeel.

Nice, malty tasting, cocoa, an earthy nuttiness, bready, a light fruitiness, a soft bitterness from the hops, the alcohol is noticeable at the end, warming through out, and a dryish sweet, mild caramel and alcohol finish, very good dubbel drinkability, dangerously quaffable.

Another good brew from St. Bernardus, tasty and balanced, a great Belgian ale to recommend to a someone who starting to explore Belgians.
Bottle sampled with Beerded_one. Pours murky brown with a decent size beige head. Citrus, fruit, spices, and alcohol. The flavor is exceptionally smooth, citrus, fruit, sweet. Great body, great brew.

750 bottle. Pours a thick, dark rust color with big large-bubble head that lasted until the last sip. Amazingly complex but subtle aromas of raisins, orange and almonds. Palate was complex with high maltiness but low overall sweetness. Sourness was milder than many abby ales. High yeast content but it stayed in the bottom well and I could pour all but about an ounce. No hint of the alcohol flavor (until I tried to stand up...). Left me wanting another.

Poured from the bottle a dark brown with a big tan head. Aroma was of malt and dark fruits. Flavor consisted of sweet malts, dark fruits(raisin/prunes/dates), and it had a good alcohol warming as it went down.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2007 Pours dark brown and red, a little syrupy.  Can taste the alcohol and the complexity.  A fruity aroma.  Thick-bodied.  Fruity and malty in the mouth. If college wasnt making me broke, I would drink it more often.  Definitely worth a try or 12.
This is a very enjoyable drink, but rather difficult for me to come by.  I look forward to drinking more of it.

11.2oz, Best before end 04 08 10.  Pours a cloudy ruby brown with a large creamy light beige head.  Aroma of yeast, powdered sugar, dust, dark fruits, a little alcohol.  The alcohol is much stronger in the taste, some pears, cherries and raisins more decipherable.  Still fairly yeasty and dusty, a little bit of tartness noted as well.  Not nearly as sweet as Id imagined it to be from the aroma.  Warming alcohol stays in the back in the throat for some time.  Dry finish.  Highly carbonated, medium bodied.  Very nicely done, though maybe a tad too hot on the alcohol, and a little too high on the carbonation.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Bottle - Pours a rather dark hazy brown with an off white head.. Smells of strong yeast with hints of fruits.. Palate is syrupy at first but then the carbonation hits you... rather good belgian brew... preferably after dinner .. 15/20

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2007 Bottle from Utobeer. Pours a dark chocolate brown with a creamy off white head. Strong nose of yeast and fruit. Malty texture with a spicy edge. Hints of cherries, raisins and plum. Sweet finish. Medium body. A great dessert beer - or even better, as dessert. Yum.

Bottle. Dark brown with a light brown head, good lacings. Aroma moderate/heavy malty, brown sugar, raisin, plum and hoppy. Flavor moderate/heavy sweet and bitter, in good balance. Medium/full body, syrupy, soft carbonated. Moderate in alcohol.

Ok, Ive had the 12 a few times before. This was a bottle, poured a heavy murky brownish red. Thin off white head. Aroma is of sweets and prunes. Tastes is alittle acidic  with a mix of plums.Enjoyable, but I prefer the 12.
Pours a dark brown, darker than the 6 with a good, cream-colored head. Spicey, dried fruit in the aroma. Brown sugar and a touch of alcohol in the flavor.

This beer pours a dark reddish brown with a tan head. Aroma is sweet and invites you to drink. Taste is sweet as well with raisins coming to mind then some hoppy goodness with a pleasing bitterness. An interesting saltyness at the very end perhaps? I love St. Bernardus everyting Ive had is amazing.

750 thanks to vyvvy for sharing this fine belgian.  crimson red with lots of carbonation with a fizzy-off white head.  lots of spicy yeast tones here with a good candy note (hard candy-fruity and estery).  lots of dark fruit here-plums and rasins.  flavors exhibit alot of plum flavor with some toasted belgian amber malt accents.  yeast is very active here.  It drives alot of spice into the flavors.  fuzzy carbonation with a spritzy feel on the tongue.  pretty nice BSA.

crazy rat cork...um, this is like a dubbel licking an ass...dark murky..great lacing...smooth, phil gave it a 6/10 ..but i dont like it...tastes old and dusty. ill try agin in future to make sure, on tap for sure!

Nose is of dark fruits, malts, and sweetness. Hazy, rusty brown with a small but long lasting beige head; flavor shows spice, plums, and sweet malt. The alcohol was covered pretty well and a bit of hops lingered in the aftertaste with that little alcohol.

The pour was dark brown, with hints of orange and some suspended particles. Good thick tan head that lingered throughout, and excellent lacing. Aroma was strongly dark fruit...grapes, plums, figs, and the flavor was more of this, along with the malty sweetness early on. As beer warmed at mid-glass, alcohol became more evident in both the flavor and the aroma. THis is a  very tasty beer, and pretty much what I expected. Not the best for a hot summer night (like tonite) , but there is no mistaking the good aroma flavor and overall quality of this beer.
Deep clear red full of small floaties and a small thin creamy head. The aroma is full of malt and marzipan and the taste is rich, sweet and fruity.

Picked up a 4 pack of this (330 ml bottles) after being pleased by the Abt 12. The Prior 8 poured a cloudy nut brown with large yeast particulate present on the bottom. The mild carbonation gave rise to an even thick white head which quickly dispersed with minimal lacing. Presented a yeasty aroma with a hint of fruits, cheeses, and alcohol. The flavor was malty sweet, doughy, and rather spicy with a warming dry finish. The body is a bit creamy and only moderately thick, less so than the Abt 12 if I remember correctly. I think this is very drinkable if you like belgian strong browns.

Yeasty dark red pour with tremendous head we all come to expect from this style.  Many similar qualities to the abbot 12.  Exquisite taste and very enjoyable beer.  St. Bernardus has yet to disappoint.

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2014 Bottle.  Dark brown pour with a beautiful fluffy and lacing light brown / tan head.  Nose is sweet and yeasty, candis and fruit (raisin or plum), spicy.   Taste is very spicy and malty with some alcohol.  Caramel and brown sugar.  Love that spiciness.  Thicker than the six, and much more flavorful.  Medium-dry finish with a touch of salt.  Wow! [2006.06.23: 4.0]Re-rate in the States, bottle best by 27 09 17.  Have had other Bernies in the last eight years, but not this one.  Nose of brown sugar and plum, dark malt with red berry and light yeast-air, touch of candis.  Pours a deep, dark, beautiful ruby red with fizzy carb and a soapy beige head (a little ugly, tbh).  Airy in the mouth, taste semi-dry with low bitterness and a lot of alcohol warmth (really, scorch even, surprising!), some soft Coca Cola mouthfeel in the medium body, but lots of smooth dry brown sugar accompanied by hearty warmth. Very light earthy hops, touch of cereal in thin malt, ginger and restrained phenolic character.  And a note of fume, not quite solventy, really a stripped rum-raisin.  By the end this is very, very warm and bone-dry; bad bottle?  I have another stashed, well see[2014.05.02: 3.3]

Aroma:yeast,dark fruit,plump....
Appearance:light hazy amber,small head...
Flavor:yeats,caramel,dark fruit,plump.....
Medium brown color, thin white head with bananas and chocolate. Reminded me of a chocolate sunday. Sweet malty mouth, chocolate, candy sugar, slighlty alcoholic and an alcoholic finish.
hazy brown/nutty with white head. Aroma of Malts, dark fruits & spices. Some sweetness. The alcohol is present -  a little warm. Finish  is pleasant and long lasting! Another great from Watou!

smaller bottle.  Pours a hazy dark brown with a long lasting big head, somewhat heavy carbonation.  Aroma is caramel, toffee, and dark fruits, raisins.  Taste is slightly tart with dark fruit all over the palate and some light vanilla, or possibly wood notes.  Smooth finish.

From 11.2oz Bottle.  Pours a murky, dirty leathery brown color with a tall crop of saopy beige head.  Musty, yeasty perfumes waft from my tulip glass with a bit of chocolate and chewy gingerbread.  Some waxy banana and brazil nuts spice up the estery bouquet further.  Medium bodied, yeasty mouthfeel with loads of spices and a light, dry belgian chocolate powder.  A nice sprinkle of shaved nutmeg shell and vanilla bean round out the spice profile.  Very nutty.  Final smack of yeasty chocolate powder.  Nutty, chocolatey, dry beer with a massive yeasty kick.  A fine example of my favorite style.
750 ml bottle purchased at American Beer Dist in Brooklyn, NY...dark cloudy brown with a thick head, aroma reminds me a bit of prunes, carbonated and malty tasting, a very solid Belgian.

750 ml from 05...
Appears a hazy brown mahogany with a foamy off white head that slowly fades into a floating film and collar. Streaks of lacing are left around the glass.
Smell is of mild cork that is far outweighted by caramel, brown sugar, doughy bread, and alcohol.
Taste is of the mentioned aromas with mild fruit doused with caramel.
Mouthfeel is smooth, chewy, doughy, and rich with brown sugar and caramel.

750 ml bottle. Dark brown with a thick foamy head that last almost forever. Wonderfull beer. The aroma is spicy with notes of caramel, yeast, dark and red fruits... Taste is very complex, malty, a good presence of alcool, spices, caramel, some fruits, yeast. Full body. Another excellent beer from Belgium.
Absolutely great beer.  Awesome flavors and aromas.  Not quite as good as Abt 12, but still great.
Medium brown color, thin white head with bananas and chocolate. Reminded me of a chocolate sunday. Sweet malty mouth, chocolate, candy sugar, slighlty alcoholic and an alcoholic finish.

Oh, baby, I wasnt expecting this to be that strong of a showing, but St. Bernies comes through again. Poured like a dubel, nice cloudy brown with a nice creamy white head. Man, the head just sat there the entire drink, perfect. The aroma was spicey and somewhat yeasty. The flavor was clearly not as malty rich as the quad, but dark fruits (plums) and cherries were present in the beginning. The spices came next as the beer finished with a bready, yeasty touch. Mouthfeel was carbonated but fairly creamy. The lacing is superb too.

Initial sense is a wonderfully spicy aroma.  Lacey thin head that casually lies on top.
Orange, caramel and rasin, with a finish thats got a tinge of sour thats not overpowering and just in balance with the residual sweetness mixed with orange remaining.

The aroma had molasses, coriander, dark fermented fruit, and was malty sweet.  The beer poured a cloudy brown color with thin head and lacing.  The flavor had caramel, molasses, dark fermented fruit, and slight spice.  The mouthfeel was medium bodied and creamy.

11.2 oz bottle poured a cloudy copper brown with a large lasting rocky amber head. Aromas of plums, raisins, molasses and spice. Palate was medium bodied. Flavors of dark fruit, carmel, molasses and spices with a lingering sweet finish.

A brown red coloured beer, with an average off-white head and some light carbonation. Sweet malty and caramel aroma, rather soft, little yeasty with some alcohol. Full sweet taste, some light carbonation. Finish is bitter sweet, little alcoholic with an burned caramel taste. Strong and good beer, very enjoyable.

0.7 l bottle: Pours with a nice and creamy, beige head, a deep amber and cloudy body. Aroma of dried fruit, dark malt and caramel. This returns in the flavour. Medium to full bodies. It got a pleasant sour and bitter finish. Very enjoyable.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2006 11.2 oz bottle, best before 3/2/10.  Pours a reddish brown with a large fizzy head that quickly goes to a thin film.

The aroma is sweet woody malts, some dough, some cream, and a little pepper.

The flavor is sweet bready malts, dark fruits, and yeast with a slight bitter finish.  The mouthfeel is medium-full and a little harsh on the carbonation.

Overall, it is rather similar to the Pater 6.  I liked that one better though.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2006 Poured a slighthly hazy deep red with a full and lasting tan head and good lacing.  Aroma is very strong and consists of candied fruits and caramel topped nuts.  Flavour starts out very sweet and malty with a good dose of fruits and again a slight nuttiness.  the nut character is reminiscent of sherry.  It has a watery complexion but plenty of residual sweetness to give a sense of fullness.

Aroma of malt, biscuit, and other cant really pinpoint belgium yeast charactistics.  Reddish-brown with off white head.  Slightly cloudy with yeasties floating around in there but to be expected.  Kinda like the little brother to the Bernaruds 12.  Good malt flavor with hints of bread and maybe even a touch of chocolate b/c I was looking for it.  Medium to full bodies with a tad too much carbonation for my taste but with the approriate range.  Getting better as it warms.  Pretty dam tasty...

11.2 oz bottle.  04 08 10 (?).  Dark brown with ruby edges.  Dense tan-white head with spots of powdery dregs; coats til the end.  Walls of lacing.  Yeast, cocoa, woody alcohol and subtle cherry.  Alcohol very prominent at first but silky mouth smooths it out.  Sort of a smoky melon that sours into dry wild mushrooms.  Good; different.
Another great beer from St. Bernardus. Brownish colour with a light brown moslty lasting head. Lots of aroma and flavour. Highly recommendable.

Bottle, at Benny.
Dark brown with a light brown head, good lacings. Aroma moderate/heavy malty (brown sugar, raisin, plum) and hoppy. Flavor moderate/heavy sweet and bitter, in good balance. Medium/full body, syrupy, soft carbonated. Moderate in alcohol.
UPDATED: AUG 4, 2006 Wow, so the second time I had this beer was even better; guess my taste is evolving. Lots of fruit smell with a very similar taste. Spices are ever present as well.

Begins with a very strong and pleasant aroma, sweet and alcoholic with raisin notes dominating and, upon further reflection, a hint of lemon (?) tartness. While appropriately dark for a dubbel, Im just not that into the coca-cola brown yielded by dark candi sugar--as opposed to the roasted malts of a porter or stout. Moreover, unlike the thick contrasting color that can make a dark pint of Guiness so attractive, the head was very thin, although persistent.

The strong aroma and dark color leads one to expect a full-bodied, malty sweet meal in a glass. But this beer is instead very dry and subdued on the palate--too subdued for my taste. Still, a very clean and balanced beer that, in true Belgian style, is extremely drinkable despite its powerful punch.
Dark brown with a froathy creamy head. Floral aroma with a sourish tint. Very rich malt fruit flavor which leaves a nice smooth after taste.

Dark brown pour with thin, but appealing head that sticks around. This is an aromatic, flavorful beer. The nose is spicy with notes of clove and pepper. The flavor is filled with sweet fruits and notes of clove. Medium to full body and moderately long finish. Overall, a very enjoyable strong ale.
Pours dark and fizzy, looks like a cola at first.  Hazy with visible suspended  (protein?) flakes.  The aroma is clearly malt.  The flavor is sweet abd malty with a thick heavy body.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text: I actually prefer this to the Abt 12 by St. Bernardus.  I found it to have much more of a sweet, spicy, malty aroma and taste than the 12.  One of my absolute favorites.

This has a deep brown body highlighted in red with a creamy tan head.  Light and soft in the mouth, this is still one big malty beer.  The aroma has rich malt scents, caramel with a gob of toffee, sugar and raisins, spices and berries, and a healthy helping of alcohol, all of which is skillfully blended into the flavor.  The finish is sweet and fruity with a low alcohol burn.  Very nice indeed.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Beverage Depot, Orland Park, IL<font size=-1>

Pours a two finger, thick cream head that barely fades leaving a good lace.  Cloudy amber color.  Medium carbonation and medium bodied.  Cherry nose.  Starts sweet, raisiny, sweet bready finish, not cloying. $9.60 for a 750ml bottle from Colonial Spirits Acton, Ma.

Bottle Code 051009Pours a light-hazed, caramel/ruby with a holding and creamy tan head. Cereal malt aroma with a big dose of strawberry or raspberry. Alcohol begins to show even as it holds a chill. A caramel presence indicates that this will be a nice bridge between Pater 6 and the "bigger" Bernardus beers. A sip, and... yes! Malts showcase prominently sweet in the flavor. (I was worried after my recent tasting of "6" which held a malt profile that was full yet boring.) Cararmel, spices and berries mingle within a fluffy palate, but a latent stickiness keeps them from drifting too far away. Sweetness turns sour in the aftertaste, lingering as a childrens cough syrup with mild alcohol and fruitiness. All in all this is an excellent beer which makes me glad that I purchased the Bernardus "gift set" for myself on a whim. 
<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Beverage Depot, Orland Park, IL 60462<font size=-1>
slightly murky amber color, slight spicy, with some nutmeg, crisp and clean nose, light earthy with good malty taste , with a sharp bubbly refreshing body, aftertaste bitter and sweet very nice

Dark brown, frothy tannish colored head that is pretty substantial.  Aromas are full... yeast, prune, sweet, spice that I cant pin down.  Not a whole lot to get me excited even though it is well crafted.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: The aroma has lots of dark fruit, brown sugar, and yeast. The appearance is hazy purple brown with a medium head. The flavor has raisins, spice, and sugar. The palate is typical for the style. The alcohol asserts itself in the finish. Overall its a very nice Belgian Strong Ale.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2012 Dark brown body with mahogany highlights. Thick, creamy, tan head that fades to a cover, nice lacing. The aroma is sweet, plummy, light spice. Flavor is spicy with golden raisins, candi sugar, caramel. Mouthfeel is rich and creamy, very full. Finish is bitter, slightly dry with just a hint of tartness that cleans the palate. This is terrific stuff.

The pour is a very dark brown with a slight reddish tint.  Stars with a nice sized head that leaves quickly with a layer remaining.  Aroma is very spicy and peppery - very clean and sharp.  Mouthfeel is very thick and filling - lots of carbonation.  Taste is very malty and rich - lots of caramel, generous amounts of yeast.  There is some spiciness in the taste, but not nearly as much as the aroma predicted.  The beer laces as much as Ive seen.  Great beer from a legendary brewery.

Pour is a nice red-brown with a huge tan head.  Aroma is bready biscut with a touch of spice.  Flavor is caramel and dark fruits with a nice helping of alcohol.  Lots of things going on in this brew and it all comes together to please all the sences.  Well recomended and i can kick myself for not trying this sooner.

I like this beer...better than the st bernardus tripel.  Pours a baked pumpkin brown/red with a huge gummy head...lots of floaties.  Aroma is sweet malt and yeast.  Flavor is very subtle and well balanced.  Hints of spice and alcohol...malt, dried fruit, and toasted bread.  Mouthfeel is greatly refreshing.  This beer is great.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2007 Dark brown dubbel style belgium ale.  Hazy with some spices floating about.  This has a full dark fruity offset by some spices.  This was absolutely delicious.  I did not expect this one to be this good.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2012 First ratingInitial Rating Date: 3/27/2006 2:47:33 PM75 cl bottle at Bishops Arms (Avenyn) Gothenburg.Beautiful dark red color with a brown head. Fruity and Belgian scent. Spicy taste.9/4/8/3/16=4.0RerateDraught at Ölrepubliken, Göteborg, on September 19, 2012Hazy dark brown color, tan head. Sweet, fruity, caramel, cream taste. Medium to smooth mouthfeel, medium low bitterness. Some apple and almond paste aftertaste. Sweet, malty, caramel, fruity scent.8/4/9/4/17=4.2

UPDATED: APR 6, 2012 Vintage: best before June 2010
Consumed: October 2011
Not a lot to report in terms of development from the lasting of 14 months ago. Continues to be in good nick although the malt is fading. Big whack of funky vegemite on the nose. I have one bottle left and there will be very little risk hanging onto it to drink 2 years past the BB date. Massive ice-cream floater head, good lacing. Brown in colour with a red tinge, a little cloudy.  Savoury, earthy malts, some raisens, but a little subdued.  More thick raiseny notes on the palate with sugary malts. Some spice and fruit as well. A little heat doesnt detract. Pretty good stuff.
Vintage: best before June 2010
Consumed: August 2010
Probably about 3 years old. Holding up well if a little unspectacular. Shows all the usual dubbel traits and also has a nice, albeit it mild, chocolate overlay. Carbonation is a little softer than I remember. Lacks some punch in the flavour department and Im not sure cellaring any further will benefit.
Murky brown pour, raisins in the aroma.  Flavor is prunes, plums and caramel.  Delicious.

Moderately sweet, yeasty, bread aroma.  SOme fruit, as well.  Appearance was perfect.  Poured a nice, creamy head with excellent lacing.  No yeast particles.  Initial and finish flavor were moderately sweet.  It has a decent wheat flovor component.  Overall, another great beer from St Bernardus.

Cloudy dark ruby  color with chunkies and a moderate light tan head. Fruity aroma of plum and pear with a hint of black cherry. Flavor starts moderatly sweet with dark fruit followed by a hint of cocoa and a black cherry tartness. Finish is kinda dry and lightly acidic with a little alcohol. Medium bodied with a velvety texture and lively carbonation.
brown beer with a  huge pillowy off white head and lots of lacing.  fairly weak and unimpressive aroma of brown sugar, malt, yeast and coriander.  weak malts and spices make this one just o.k.

Pours dark brown with a big tan head. Aroma is malty with a hint of yeast. Flavor is  more wheat than I would have expected with a pretty strong alcohol presence. Fruity flavors appear once the beer has moved past the tongue. A good and different beer.

This beer offers a hearty aroma consisting of wheat, yeast, caramel, vanilla, and hints of fruit.  It is a cloudy mahogany with a thick off-white head.  This smooth medium bodied beer has a wheat and caramel taste.  It fades leaving a mild nutty/biscuit caramel flavor lingering.
Cloudy brown pour with a nice full head.  A fruity and a little yeasty aroma.  Malty and a little spicy flavor.  I really enjoyed this.

Murky brown w/ tan lingering head. Nose has some heat to it, and theres candi and yeast.  The mouthfeel is velvety w/ bubbly tounge and warming linger and swallow. Finishes alot stronger than 8%.  I gotta say I feel like fucking royalty drinking this amazing ale... or that could be this nice new Watou St. Bernardus glass, yeah baby. bottled

An interesting beer with an odd musky chocolaty/coffe aroma.  Dried tart fruity earthiness with a strong dose of sweetness, almost raspberry jam flavor with a touch of wood.  Is this beer Im describing?  My bottle showed signs of age, with dark flakes of sediment swirling around.  Tight bubbles, light tan head with a strong bead.  Good stuff.

Very much a more-ish beer this one, and that can be a bit dangerous when your getting to this abv. Looks pretty damn good - opaque dark brown with a generous frothy head. Smells of muscatels and some licorice. The body is a little less than full, but its sufficient enough to carry the fine flavours of this abbey ale. Bitter edge to the flavour, but it might just linger a little long without a perfect balance. Top notch.

wow excellent chocolate and fruity. smooth finish and carbonation. drinking this with trappistes rochefort 10. this is smoother, less alcohol finish -8.0 vs. 11.3. maybe a little more watery? 2 great ales. liife is good. yes!!

Thicky hazy brown with a descent sized creamy head. Aroma is sweet with a bready aroma too. Flavor is mostly sweet with a touch of alcohol in the background. A well balanced belgian strong ale. Many are too sweet and strong alcohol, but this one works well. Not too crazy for the style, but this works.

Pours a deep brown with red tint and a frothy tan head.  Aroma is very fruity with fig, plum, apple, raisin, and pineapple.  Also, there is a sweet bread aroma with molasses and nutmeg.   Excellent flavor, there is this yeasty character that all St. Bernardus beers have that make them so delicous.  Also plenty of fruits in the flavor and an great malty taste.  Its initially sweet with a citrus flavor, and ends slightly bitter with a lingering rich, slightly smoky flavor.  Creamy texture and very good mouth feel, but slightly watery.  Another great St. Bernardus beer.
Heavy malt aroma. Frothy off-white head. Excellent lacing, fully lasting. Clear body in ambor collour. An the beer have a great tast.

On tap at Lucky Baldwins Belgian Beer Festival 2006 in Pasadena. Dark, bloody amber with a large beige head. Excellent lacing. The nose is dry.. notes of chocolate(!), prune, and spices, with a vague soapy astringency (maybe the glass wasnt rinsed properly?). Big malts up front in the flavor, roasty and chocolate again w/molasses. Spices and dark fruits. Lightly bitter. Finish is brief and quite sweet. Highly drinkable but the palate is a weak point.. watery and too flat. I would definitely pick up this beer on tap again.

From the bottle. Pours a beautiful deep brown with golden highlights, abundantly carbonated.
This is a perfectly nice beer, but its not a world-beating Belgian strong.The aroma is brown bread baking, molassas, plums, and a sort of musty cellar sourness; the flavor comes through with a big taste of dark malt, slightly sweet, spicy, some nutmeg, belgian yeast, a curious hint parmasean cheese.
Bottle. Frothy white excellent mostly lasitng head. OK aroma but a bit week flavor. Not the best Belgian strong ale, but still good beer.
11.2 Fl oz: Opaque dark caramel color. Good frothy yellow head. Berries and spice scent. Big on palate, malty. Alcohol finish.

750mL: Pours a very dark brown color.  Very slightly off-white head, big, lasting, smooth.  Aroma of citrus, lavender, spices.  Slightly bitter, slightly sweet taste, molasses, warming, good mouthfeel, alcoholy.

Pours out murky brown with ever flowing yeast chunks.  Head is off-white and incongruent.  Aroma is figgy and yeasty.  Flavor is much of the same and malty.  Not as much fruit flavor as Ive seen in BSAs.  Seems more like a tripel.   Body seems medium to light.   In the end its a pretty good tasting Belgian.  Kicks the ass of the Rochefort 6 I just had.  Wish it was more "complex" though.
Strong smell. Good whitish head that dissappears quickly. A fruity powerfu taste with slight bitterness. Quite sweet but with a long, fresh fruity aftertaste with slight malty undertones.

Strong scent that I picked up past arms length, very sweet and very aromatic.  Light head hugs the glass over a very dark pour.  Bit of alcohol in the taste at first then bitter with a clean finish.  Swear I tasted Prune in this one.  I found it got more sour the more I drank it.

Aroma is lots of apple juice,  though gains sweet malt and spicyness as it warms. Pours deep, ruddy brown  with a huge head. Flavor is very full and complex,  much like that of a Quad, with lots of plum, sour apple, a bit of puckering from the palate. Interesting, velvety mouthfeel. Nice beer.

Moderately malty, medium to strong molasses like sweetness.  Light yeast notes. Hints of brown sugar.  Medium light body.  Small head that lingers the entire sitting.  If this didnt cost me $11.99 for a four pack Id be putting these in my fridge more often.

The head is very good - turns creamy like a nitro beer and produces good lacing.  Aroma is sweet with some light alcohol and coriander or nutmeg.  Flavour is just spicy enough with some light alcohol and good amount of bitterness.  I cant decide if I like this better than the Abt 12.

Købt i Superbrugsen for 35 kr. (70 cl. flaske). Øllen er brun med flot brunt skum

Øllen er utrolig tung, og det tager lang tid at nyde den. Eftersmagen varer længe, og er god.

Alcohollen dominerer dog en del, hvilket ikke lige er min smag.

Øl, som skal drikkes i små mængder.
Bottle. Nice sweet yeasty, raisiny scent. Fairly malty at the start with a nice biting dry aftertaste. Nice zing with citrus and yeast scents. Great beer.

Pours an opaque umber brown with a gigundous khaki head. Aroma of caramel malt, strawberry, sugar.  Caramel really heavy here, along with strawberry and blue berry, malt, a hint of alcohol. Finishes with like berry candy, but leave a slight alcohol kick in the back of the throat. Body is brow ale solid and fairly creamy, not too thick. When it comes to these abbey style ales, 8 seems to be my lucky number.

Bottle.  Pours dark, murky brown and a thin to medium light brown head.  Great lacing.  Nice fruity aroma of plums, apples and a hint of spice.  Flavor is mostly the same dark fruits, lots of malt.  Mouthfeel is creamy and full.  The finish leaves me with a bready flavor in the back of my mouth.  Very good beer, Im looking forward to trying others from this brewery.
Pours chunky mahogany into a snifter.  Aroma of caramel. bread and hay.  Medium texture, sticky and lively.  Medium finish.  Nice.

Pours a murky hazy brown color with a thick creamy tan head.  Aroma is of cinnamon,nutmeg,baked apple crisp,plums and malts.  Flavor is much the same as the aroma with hints of figs and other dark fruits.  Very good but not as good as the 12.

Pours deep amber with a thinnish tan head.  Nose is stewed apple, fresh dates, malty.  Flavor trends toward dark fruit (plums), malt, with rather tasty bitter finish.  Not real complex, but very well done and very refreshing.
Bottle. Off-white lasting head. Amber body.Fruity malt aroma. Spcy caramel hops flavor.
Brown color with burgundy highlights.  Tan head with nice lacing.  Aroma of yeast, rich malt, some fruit and spice apparent.  Full malty flavor and mouthfeel.  Alcohol well hidden.  Very nice.

bottle thanks to jimbowood. pours dark brown with a thin off white head. little lacing. aroma is sweet yeasty and fruity though i cant pinpoint any specific fruit as i have had too many beers tonight. mouthfeel is incredibly smooth and enjoyable. and i cant detect any alcohol. taste is sweet fruits malt and yeast. very good.

Bottle.  Cinnamon, stewed apple and plum aroma.  Opaque dark brown with large head.  Sweet plum/prune flavor with a moderate astringent/bitter finish.  Flavor not quite a complex as aroma would lead you to believe.

Very nice beer.  A bit more mainstream than I was expecting, not being a regular drinker of Belgian Strong Ales.  Beautiful dark copper body with some sediment and a nice white head.  Flavor of wine, yeast, and alcohol, complex and subtle.  Very smooth.
This is one solid dubbel (or strong ale, whatever). Strong and spicy, it has some coriander perhaps and other great stuff. Worth trying. Caramel at the end.

Very dark brown pour in a tulip.  Alcoholic, yeasty, grape-like aroma.  Highly carbonated.  Date/raisin flavor intensifies and warms in the finish.  Nice and smooth, despite the strong alcoholic overtones.  Thanks to Brigadier for sharing.

It poured deep brown with medium bodied head and strong lacing.  The initial aroma hinted at grapes, toffee, cherries and bread.  As the first sip melted on my lips, I immediately picked up on a complex group of tastes - first toffee, then cherry and finally plum.  The carbonation was evident but not overpowering.  The palate was long lasting with a slightly bitter finish.  This is one of the
best beers Ive had to date.

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2007 Pours very dark brown with mahogany hues when held in intense light. Vigorous carbonation forms a thin tan head with excellent retention. Aroma of wine grapes, and bread dough with raisins. Taste is raisins, bready toasted malts, and dark candi sugar. Also aromatic fruity esters, notes of plum and sweet yeast. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with lush, quite high carbonation. Quite delicious!

(12.30.05) 11.2 fl oz (330 mL) brown bottle purchased from DiCarlos, Mundelein, IL. 8% ABV. Bottle label states that it is best consumed before the end of 2004. Clear brown abbey ale having a small diminishing head with spare lacing.  Soft carbonation. Sweet, yeasty, bread dough aroma. Full bodied that starts with rich, smooth malt sweetness and toffee/vanilla flavors.  Finishes with light sweet malt aftertaste. Delicious, smooth and rich tasting, even though sampled one year past the expiration date. Best as a digestif. In a side-by-side comparison with St. Bernadus abt 12, the ales have a similar flavor but the prior 8 is somewhat drier.  Much better flavored than the Westvleteren 8 and Rochefort 8.

(bottle) Hazy and cloudy dark amber colour with a foamy tanned medium head. Sweet malty and plum-fruity aroma with yeasts; notes of brandy when it warms. Sweet flavour, medium body, fizzy carbonation. Malty and fruity (dried plums, raisins) taste with notes of caramel and yeasts. Dry and slightly bitter finish, slightly alcoholic but not in a disturbing way.

Bottle. Very strong aroma of bread and dough, with sour notes. The beer pours hazy, and dark brown, with a light brown head that is frothy and lasting. Flavor is of apple, dough and raisin. The finish is long lasting as well. The beer is very smooth on the palate  mainly due to its excellent foamy head.
some hops linger on the palate

330ml brown bottle. Red brown colour, 1 inch of creamy, rocky tan head. Malt, brown sugar and nuts in aroma. Big malt flavour and malt sweetness, subtle caramel and light alcohol. Some yeast and alcohol carry over into the finish, giving it a bit of a pleasant bite, and some dryness. Soft palate, medium carbonation, some stickiness and weight to the body. A nice rich, slow sipping experience overall, even though the bottle foamed like crazy upon opening!

Bottle conditioned, 330ml, aged 7 years. Brown tawny colour with white head. The general sweetnes of this beer had been developed over the years, conditioning into a full flavoured spicy, rounded beer with a heavy, sherry like, alcohol presence. The beer has little bitterness present, but has a fruiy, bramble jelly, skinny make up. An enjoyable sipping beer for a cold winters night.

33cl bottle:  This one pours a very hazy mahogany color.  There was a good bit of a tan head that dropped away rather quickly.  Definite dark fruits to the nose.  Also some breadiness, yeastiness and some caramel/toffee notes.  The taste is quite good, I get the caramel, raisins, breadiness, as well as a plethora of other things mixed together in there.  A slightly spicy aftertaste, as well as a full body.  Quite nice.

Tried this gem a year ago but lost my notes. Thankfully a few from the same batch a year later taste even better than I can recall! Tasted at around cellar temperature. Pours a lovely, deep ruby red with an ½" whipped cream, sandy beige head that remained steadfast leaving fine lace trails down the chalice. Raisins, sultanas and all manner of dry, savoury dessert-style fruits leap from the glass. Lightly spicy with a decent balance of woody and doughy yeast, and a late addition of banana that seemed a little odd. Quite dry and almost pasty in the mouth, full in body and smooth like a thick dessert sauce. Flavours of crushed cashews and almonds add an almost woody edge to notes of powdered cocoa, dried out garden herbs and softer dried fruits that manage to fill every nook-and-cranny of the mouth. Finish is long and malty dry with a light warming sensation to remind me of its ABV. Took a long time to finish which I find the best part of the St. Bernardus beers, they just fill that need for quantity. This was a great winter warmer that, even in the shadows cast from its bigger brother, is still worth its weight in gold. Quite nice!!! (33cL, 12/04/08)

In absolute pristine form, included in a gift pack taken straight from the carton. Ripe dark & dry fruits lead taste impression, hint chocolate-bitter, enjoyably round and softly spicy. It tastes "deep red" to me, as a playful, round Mourvédre wine does. Dont miss this one.

Dark, cloudy brown colour with a bubbly tan head.  Has a sweet raisiney malt nose with a touch of alcohol and light chocolate.  The body is spritzy and alcoholic.  Lightly sweet at the front with brown sugar and yeast notes developing in the finish.  NIce and complex...if only it didnt have the spritziness and alcohol presence.

First I have to say I drank this warm and from the bottle.... That said ill try my best to examine how it would have tasted if I wasnt stupid.  Malty chocolate with a light alcohol smell.  Slighty fruity with a strong body.

The Lure:Roasted malts ably laid out on fat prunes. Chocolate sweetness reaches earthiness, luring the tastebuds closer. Less fruity than Rocheforts and Westvleterens 8s, but still very attractive.

The Festivities:Chocolate-laden yeast does a masterful job of propagating its sweet ideas all over the tongue. Maybe less aromatic and complex than the 2 aforementioned 8s, but how can you complain at this level of wealthy goodness?

Transcendence:Simplicity and meditation can get you on the path to understanding.
Frothy off-white head with a very very dark hazy brown color. Light wheat aroma with strong malt tones. Strong sweet malty flavor.

A deep brown and cloudy beer when poured.  As with other St. Bernardus brews this one has a light white, yet thick head.  Malts and grains permiate the aroma while deep chocolate, molassas and malt flavors attack the tounge.  Little carbonation in the after-taste.  Highly enjoyable.
Bottle. Pours a hazy ruby color with a huge off-white head that was lasting with good lacing. Heavy complex aroma. Medium body. Good complex sweet flavor with an average finish. Very good brew.

Cloudy dark brown hue, Nice beige head. That at this time has lasted about  45 minutes. Malty and light clovy sweet flavour. Light stewed pea, honey aroma. Very flavourfull and delicious. Palate is smooth and oily with nice bites of bitter on the back of the tounge.

Fantabulous and malttastic.  There is a very large white head that leaves a thick lace on the glass.  Appearance change as you get closer to the bottom of the bottle, becoming darker and less transparent.  Some large chunks of sediment.  This beer is much less about alcohol or even fruit than it is about malt, unlike many beers of this style.  But the fruit is there as well; aged and fermenting fruit in the pleasant aroma along with a hint of alcohol that also shows through in a very minor burn on the tongue. I did think I was drinking a dubbel and I think it this beer fits in that style rather well, without a need for resorting to the all-encompassing Belgian strong category.  Hard to find in Minnesota, I am pleased I found the last bottle at the bottle shop.

Deep brown hue, with some reddish highlights, and a frothy tan-colored head.Toasty, bready, sweet caramelized malt, with a fruity nose of figs, dates, with a chocolatey hint in the aroma, follows through on a medium-bodied palate, with a sweet malty character, fruity note of dark dry fruits, brown sugar, a good sweet-bitter chocolatey accent, roasted malt, leading towards a touch of alcoholic warmth and a low hop impression finish.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2006 Pours a deep reddish brown with a large cramy head. Smells malty with a bit of a musty undertone. A nice balance of hops and malt. Bitter but not obnoxiously so. Not as complex as the abt or tripel but a fine beer nonetheless

Bottle from St. Bernardus gift pack. Deep, hazy brown colour with a small tan head. Aroma is quite malty, with some burnt caramel, cloves and yeast. Body is very lively. Flavour follows the aroma pretty well, with some nuttiness as it warms, and a strange salty note in the finish that I found off-putting at first but came to enjoy by the end of the glass.

Draught: Deep dark mahogany almost black, medium white head that stayed throughout. Poured in a trappist glass, Pretty crazy flavor I cant put a name on, I could taste some fruit, some nutyy flavor slightly sweet. It tasted ok, not my style.

Big thanks to HYDE for hooking this up for me! Deep brown body, topped with a fluffy beige cloud. Molasses, prunes, spices, and malt all fill the nose. Sweet and spicy. Lots of huge and heavy malt flavours, accompanied with molasses, honey, brown sugar, and spices. Warming alcohol. Very smooth muothfeel. Thanks derek!

Turbid deep orange and brown, thick lightly tanned head.  Rich and complex nose of plum, musty caramel, rum raisin, and pineapple, with very soft toasted coconut notes emerging at room temp.  Similar flavor notes throughout, rich, malty, but some light hop bitterness late provides good balance.  Medium bodied, yet a bit thin, fizzy carbonation, lightly bittersweet, malty finish.  Really nice and certainly worth a try....

Bottle.  Poured tinted brown, with a nice head that lasted the whole time.  The aroma was sweet and got stronger over time.  The flavor was beautiful and got nicer over time.  
 Great beer, Ill be having more of this.

Pours hazy amber brown ale, large foamy, creamy head on top. Aroma consists of largely sweet notes with hints of spice and light hop character .Smooth body, very clean. Very nicely made ale that hides alcohol so well. Gentle sweetness grows out so gently towards the alcohol that they blend so well. Unfiltered body just adds another pleasure to my palate. Another well made Belgian ale .

Tasted in Toronto, obtained from the LCBO.  Tasted in trappist glass. Pours lighter than 12, slightly reddish hue, same thin tan coloured head.  Aroma of shotbread, biscuits, deep fig and nutmeg.   Flavour is slightly more balanced than 12, less sweet, larger malt and yeast component, very rich, slight ending tanginess. Oh my.....

Prior 8 has an aroma of dark fruit with a background of alcohol.  The beer poured a dark murky brown.  Head retention maintained through to the finish and was a light tan.  There was some lacing.  The flavor was malty with a dry fruit, somewhat plumlike, finish.
Corked bottle: Poured a cloudy mohagony with an ample head.  Taste is aggressive and carbonated with touches of grapes, alcohol, and  molasses. Dry finish.   Real clean.  Loved it

Dark brown with a perfectly-formed, creamy head. Aroma was yeast and caramel, the taste truly delectable: sweet, plummy, spicy, vinous, alcoholic. Pleasantly dry. Nearly, but not quite, as good as the 12.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2007 Poured solid brown with a good amount of carbonation. I could easily make out fruit, nut, and caramel flavors, as well as a potent maltiness. Not overly sweet,though.  Very satisfying and drinkable; the best Bernardus Ive tried so far.

Nearly opaque brown in color. Aroma is of freshly baked fruitcake or something, a little unusual but not unpleasant. SOme good malt presense in the flavor. Definitely a winter warmer. Like most booze, theres the cheap stuff which is harsh, and theres the good stuff which is smooth. By that token, their brews are in the smoother category.

Dark brown and red color, big beige head. Sweetness, brown sugar, mild spices and alcohol in aroma. Medium to full bodied. Spicy, very sweet, medium alcohol and chocolate in flavor, creamy palate. Alcohol lasts in aftertaste.

Poured a murky dark mahogany with a large frothy off-white head.  Aroma of sweet grapes, cinnamon, and alcohol.  Taste is aggressive and vinous with touches of grapes, alcohol, a hint of caramel and molasses.   Dry finish, felt perhaps a little too dry for eight percent.  Good.

Deep brown-red, nice head. Yeasty cider or even chardonnay or champagne, marzipan, pear, honey-flavoured yoghurt, orange rind, toffee, banana and something herbal, but the aroma is too yeasty-phenolic for my liking. Seems like theres potential for something really good there, though. Quite powerful in the mouth - marzipan, bitter cocoa, brandy, stale milk and a bit of roast. Quite alcoholic, and carb is relatively low (though Ive had both a massive gusher and a dead flat bottle of this before so who knows whats going on.) Quite good, but not in the upper echelon of Belgian stuff.

This stuff is really tastey.  A lot like a dopplebock or a porter in terms of malt character and mouthfeel.  Looked great in the glass, with the really smooth, creamy head of the Belgian ales.  Tastey stuff this.
Lively nut-brown beer, creamy beige foam. Soft yeast aroma, nutty, caramel, cakes and hops. Taste is malty sweet, cake like, breaddy and has a good hoppy finish. Aftertaste is tuning a little dry.

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2010 10/18/2005: 750 ml bottle, it pours to a clear reddish brown body with a creamy foamy off-white head with excellent lacing.  The aroma is sorta soapy with some strange sweet malts that almost comes off as cement "rust".  Strange but not unappealing.  The flavor is a oaked molasses and currants.  It has some sorta strange dank earthyness.  The palate is creamy, fizzy, watery.  Overall, I wonder if this is just an old bottle?  Im not a huge fan.  Its not "bad", just that I dont think this is as good as others believe. 6, 4, 7, 3, 13 = 3.3

05/04/2010: ~12 oz bottle.  Was a gusher, but that was likely due to the beer not being chilled.  Pours to a deep brown body with a soapy looking light khaki head.  The aroma is very big and malty.  Toasted hay and caramel.  Earthy yeast.  Light vanilla.  The flavor has a medium sweetness with a bit of earthy umami.  Very much like Westmalle Dubbel.  Very clean palate has a nice medium body with a surprisingly soft carbonation.  Slick velvety texture.

a deep brown color w/ hints of red and a tall thick off white head well laced.  Smells a touch soapy belgian yeast some odd fruits spices, and some other odd fruity aromas.  Highly carbonated avg coating... Flavor is typical belgian yeast some sweet malts and light fruits.. I think this is pretty over rated.

[bottle from kulminator, tasted comparing this and westvleteren 8] Very Dark with a tan head. fruity complex nose, raisin, plum, lots of malt. full body slightly sweet finish. prefered westvleteren because the body was slightly fuller and was slightly more complex.
No#11. Strange but nice aroma of feet and vanilla. Taste is oaked with malty sweetness, excellent beer.

330 ml bottle.  Poured murky pond color with a really nice head that lasted forever.  Left nice lacing as well.  Aromas were super sweet and malty.  Caramel Apple,  Cherries, Currant, Molassas.  Flavor was decent and simlar, but left a bit of a sour note in the finish.  Pretty good alcohol heat as well.  Good stuff.
Muddy brown pour with a white creamy head.  Nice lacing.  Small chunks floating around.  Aroma is spicy and alcohol.  Flavor  is brown sugar and spicy alcohol.  Well blended and full bodied.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry at Smokeless Joe. Pours a murky copper with a large lasting light-brown head. Aroma of caramel malt, bread, ripe apple, alcohol and spices. Flavour is sweet and spicy and follows the aroma. 8% alcohol is barely noticeable. Medium bodied palate is a tad harsh. A very good beer.

Bottle (330ml).  Shared with blankboy at Smokeless Joe.  Poured hazy bubbly dark coppery-brown with a large lasting creamy tan head - a thing of beauty.  Aroma of various apples (ripe, winesap, green, etc.), some brown sugary roasted malt, but an incredibly appealing sweet bread dough yeasty aroma asserts itself, accompanied by notes of clove, pepper and other spices and fruits.  Taste is again of ripe tart & sweet apples, caramel roast malt, yeast and spices.  Palate is straightforward abbey dubbel, but balanced, sweet, almost candyish.  One of the best abbey 8s Ive tried (only slightly below the Rochefort, a little further below the Westvleteren).

Fairly fresh 750mL bottle (date code 082008). Pours a murky brown with a thick fluffy off-white head. Bits of floaties (bottle started foaming over, so it forced a bit of a "rushed" pour). Aroma is smooth, yeast raisins apples. Taste is apple, cinnamon, pepper - bit of a twang to it. Probably still a little cold. Warming up, taste is calming down and smoothing out. Malt starting to shine. Dark apples, yeast in the taste. Good enough to leave me wanting more. MUCH better a little warm. Smooth and dangerously drinkable.
user_location: Waco (Buckle of the Bible Belt), Texas, USA

text: Pours a dark brown with a big ol head. Yeasty, bready aroma with a hint of raisin. Very bready tasting beer, with a surprisingly strong alcohol flavor. Not nearly as fruity as the aroma would suggest. Enjoyable stuff.

The nose reveals a sweet maltiness with dried frutis, banana bread with a touch of yeast and just a hint of juniper berry. Poured from a bottle with a creamy lasting head. Great flavors with sweet rum raisin, fizzy spice and a woody oak finish. Wonderful beer!

Tight, spritzy carbonation settles into a creamy, thick head with beautiful lacing.  The aroma is fig and deep fruit, but somewhat subdued and almost flat.  The body more than makes up for the lackluster nose, bursting with complex flavors that are kicked up by the lively carbonation.  The expansive mouthfeel helps to meld the beautifully crafted Belgian yeast with the bready backbone.  Notes of fig, ripened banana, apricot, wood and oak throughout.  Solid.

Ymm. Trying all the Belgians at the local whole foods. Nice pour on this one with a head that stayed around to keep me company. A nice indescribable flavor plus bread and fruits. It says enjoy by end of 2004, but that was in german, so I didnt realize until later. Oh well, still good.

Draught.
Brown coloured with a lasting and lacing beige head.
Aroma of dried fruits, spices, cane sugar and bread.
Sweet and complex flavour of dried fruits, bread, fruits and spices.
Nice.
Very nice brew. Dark brown colour with a nice aroma. Very malty flavour. Good one!
Mahogany colored with a thin white head. Rich, sweet and nutty aroma. Sweet malts, some hazelnuts and a touch of cocoa. A solid Belgian Strong.

Pours a dirty brown, with a solid 1 1/2 finger head that settled into a 1/4 cap that never faded away, with pretty nice lacing.

Smells doughy with cloves, dark fruits, and some mild spices that I cant place. 

Taste is of bready malts, spices, and candied sugars. Theres hardly any hop flavor to this beer and it finished kind of dry. 

I prefer the Abt. 12, but Id get this again. A solid Dubbel.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: 12 oz bottle. Pours a cloudy brown with huge head that quickly settles to a quarter inch dirty tan head throughout consumption. This isnt a "pretty" beer. Aroma has the familiar Belgian yeast smell with sweetness.  Taste was "big," moderately sweet, and with more alcoholic warmth than I expected at 8%. Overall, not a bad brew.
Dark brown, big head, lots of yeast (ina good way), malty, enjoyable! (vacation on the Block over a game of Catan with TM)
Cloudy brown, moderate head. Raisiny, butter-rum, caramel and alcohol aromas. An estery quality too. Sweet fruity palate, warming alcohol, full mouth feel. Good winter sipper.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: pour is a foggy brown with a thin tan head.  aroma is caramel, with fruit.  taste is caramel, apricot, alcohol, and oak.

dark brown pour, small fizzy whtie/tan head. aroma is caramelly malt, sweet, little alcohol. good fruity/sweet malty flavor, a little yeasty and spicy too.a  little alcohol felt.. full bodied. very tasty.

Pours with a deep amber body topped by a medium thick head with some lacing.  Its sweet, malty and fruity with a slight lemon note, a touch of yeast and some alcohol esters.  Full bodied and warming.

bottle. Joes. hazy brownish colour with specks of yeast and a small quick dissipating head. malty nose with nice alcohol attributes, dark fruit, funky cheese notes, and a generous tickling carbonation. body is malt-accented with soft fruit flavours and chocolate. warm alcohol throughout. nice.

Brown with a reddish hue, and a medium off-brown head. Aroma of yeast (leaves, leather), dried fruit, rasins, hops and alcohol. Some extra bitterness in the taste, and some toffee in the finish. Medium bodied and a long yeasty-ish finish.
A nice deep amber color with a tan head. Fruity malty aroma. The alcohol content is masked well, as a dark fruit flavor reminicent of a sweet red wine and complex hints of spices prevail.

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Dark brown with beige head which dissipated fairly quickly. Aroma of molasses, dried fruit, yeast. Good mouthfeel, salty fruity finish. Very drinkable, but doesnt approach the Westvleteren.
Very dark brown pour, aroma is belgian and solid, and so is the flavor, good beer.
Hazy brown with a small off white head, left nice lacing. Sweet and flowery nose. Taste had rasins and dark fruit caramel, chocolate and sweet sugar. mouth feel was very nce as well. Good beer.
High dense tan head on a hazy brown body. Very well rounded brew, delicious drinking with lots of taste hints: caramel, fruits, chocolate, raosted nuts. A real caleidoscope. One of my faourite ales.

Dark brown colour with a dense head; pepper, plum, spice and caramel aromas; sweetish/bitter taste with liquorice, dates, alcohol, cherry, pepper and caramel aromas; bitter finish with liquorice, roast, toffee, chocolate and chicory aromas.
A wonderfully complex ale. Amongst the very best Belgian beers.
caramel, chocolate, toast, redish brown, cloudy, frothy, tan foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, mediium body and malty, medium finish

Pours with a very thick, creamy, frothy head with lots of lace that lasts and lasts. Dark brown with amber/red highlights. Aromas of grapes, cherries, vodka, and brandy. Flavor isnt as fruity aand also has notes of burnt sugar, coffee, and walnuts. Predominant alcohol character. Little thin in body. Had it on tap at Bodega in La Crosse where they have it in bottles too.

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2005 Minor rerate based on resample and reassessment, bumping the flavor down a point.  Nevertheless, the original review...Hazy, murky caramel brown with a fading, lacy tan and bubbly head.  Its a beauty.  Aroma leads in with rich chocolate, unsalted walnuts, cloves, coriander, pepper, banana and nutmeg.  Taste delivers.  Rich, creamy, vibrant chocolate and caramel complimented by subtle spicing.  Slight hint toward deep fruity esters of plums and black cherries, but it is first and foremost sweet and smooth.  Creamy and full-bodied.  Impeccable palate feel, blanketing with a lasting sweetness and complexity.  Chewy malts; so sweet, so good.  Absolutely no trace of alcohol content.  Rich chocolatey finish.  Simply a delight in every way.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2006 Pours a perfectly opaque dark brown with a foamy tan head. The nose reminds of dark fruits: figs, plums, raspberry and a sweet creaminess. The mouthfeel is very creamy with medium carbonation. Leaves beautiful thin lacing on all sides of the glass. Pleasant warm aftertaste.

A friend brought over a selection of St. Bernardus ales for our "Weekend at Bernies"   Poured a  rich brown with an off-white head that remained for a while.  Aromas of malt, bready yeast, and earthy fruits.  Caramel and malt flavors dominate with aftertastes of raisins.  Excellent beer.

(Draught - St. Sixtus Rouge 6,5%)
Dense and creamy foam, good persistence. Alcoholic and sweetish scent, light flowery notes. Medium smooth taste, not particularly prickly. Modest bitter and prevailing rumor of caramel.
75 cl Bottle. Nice head, brown dark colour. Little aroma, hints of dried fruit. Taste like a dubbel, notes of roasted barley and choclate. But overall the taste lack of some harmonie in the beer.

Burgundy-bronze body with moderate carbonation and a thick, frothy beige head. Interesting aroma of toffee, chocolate, raspberries, mild tobacco, and earth. Nice depth of flavor with toffee, butterscotch, light smoke, and some fig. Medium sweet and not cloying. Mild bitterness with some lightly detectable tartness. Creamy texture. Excellent beer all-around.

Deep, unclear red-brown with a lasting off-white head. Complex aroma with dried fruit, flowers, oak-wood, dirt and the slightest hint of alcohol. Sweet, malty flavour with a bit of bitterness (anise-like) and a dry finish. Very soft mouthfeel.

Beer #30 at Croydon Draught Belgian Beer Festival. My notes say " a pleasant fruity beer (plums and damsons), with some underlying chewy malt. Sweetish.". Pleasant isnt really a word Id use to describe a world class beer. Good but not great. I have a bottle tucked away, so Ill re-evaluate to see whether it shows better than on draught.

Bottle. Pours a dark reddish brown. Fine lasting head. Aromas of plums, prunes and other dried fruits. Also evident yeast notes. Full-bodied and soft on the palate. Nice warmth from the alcohol finishes off.

pours our thick and brown with a huge light brown head.  taste is sweet, yesty, and not very strong at all.  (not a bad thing).  smells like oak, yeast, and malts.  this is a beer that i found myself almost gulping because it was going down so well.  there really wasnt much to it, it was a damn good beer, but it wasnt exactly what i was expecting.  maybe a little too drinkable.

750 ml corked (champagne style) brown silk print bottle, bought in Denmark.  Brown colour with a slight haziness, pours with a large fluffy off-white head. Very nice aroma of oak, leather, yeast, brown sugar, dried fruits and spices, hints of barnyard. Flavour has plenty of brown sugar, malts, oak and figs, hints of sour berries. Some spices and a certain alcoholic bite in the finish. I had to struggle to finish the big bottle by myself, which means that the brown sugar sweetness combined with 8% ABV becomes a little too much in the end. The big bottles are for sharing! Still - this is another solid abbey beer.
Pours a brownish color with minimal head. Aroma and taste is dominated by raisons/plums. Finishes sweet and is enjoyable. Still, its no 12.

A beer that seems to get better and better through the glass. Dark brown colour with a decent sized slightly off-white head that lasts throughout the drink. The head is bigger in the middle but unlike some other trappists is still there round the edges just less thick.

Aroma is wonderful, deep fruity smell, plums, raspberries and grapes all seem to be there. Taste wise it is very warming with hints of fruit, spices and alcohol though not as interesting or strong as some other trappists.

Overall an excellent beer Id say probably best suited to the winter.

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2011 Bottle. Dark chestnut brown colour, small light brown head. Malty, vinous, brown sugar flavour with liquorice aftertaste. Nice mouthfeel. An almost perfect dubbel IMHO. I want another!

Bottle, 8%, 1.5 years past BB date. A lot like my initial rating, but of course with a little oxidation. It has a hint of paper, but it is quite mellow even though the alcohol is still prominent. I guess I would prefer this beer around its BB date.
Nice dark color, a pleasure to look at.  This beer really grows on you throughout the glass.  The first sip is decent but not like other trappist beers.  But it begins to grow on you throw the glass.
Bottle.  Pours nice dark brown with huge tan head.  Big fruity aroma, likes of earth fruits like plums.  Lots of spice and fruit flavor, and very little alcohol pepper, tho the beer is very warming.

a sim rate:
The taste is full and very fruity. It smells like plums... but better plums than Ive ever eaten! It tastes like plums also, and I wish I could really do this rate justice if only I wasnt a bit toasted. Great, great abbaye bier! Proost!

Unscrewing the metal cork cage the cork popped right into my hand. 1" long lasting head. Very dark orange brown with a few sediment chunks. Sharp aroma makes me want some cheese with my beer. Notes of yeast and malt. Delicate wine-like beer. Minimal alcohol notes. Very drinkable. A fine subtle sweetness makes you want more. Hard to describe but flavour is more enticing with each drink.

What color is this? It is like brown or some shit. Dark caramel in color with a HUGE HUGE  tan head with POWER head retention. Not sweet as is characteristic of the style. A little flat and a little bitter. Yeasty, flat, garbage. Impress me. Dont serve this crap to the public. Ok it isnt that bad, but I expected much better.

1 pint 9 oz bottle.  Aroma of bread dough, alcohol, and cherries.  Nice spoungy tan head with a blackish reddish body.  Salty and bitter on the first taste, odd, never experienced that in a beer before, but hey, I havnt been drinking too long.  Dry flavor most of the time, but there is some sweetness on the finish.  Fresh and Dried pit fruit flavors, tiny bit of bitter chocolate, nutmeg, and perhaps some toffee.  Very creamy mouthfeel with a medium amount of carbonation.  Very complex and tasty.  Nice beer,
Bottle.  Malty choc nose that dominates throughout.  Tangy hoppy finish.  A really good dark brown beer that warms and keeps you interested.

in bottle.  Pours a beautiful dark brown, porter color with off-white head.  Black flecks of particulate matter float on top.  Aroma is medicinal, with hints of raisins and dates. Very sweet, malty palate.  Finishes with a little bitterness and roasted flavoring.  Delightful from start to finish.

Pured with a frothy off white head. Brown, but has some ruby and purpleish hues when held to light.  I get very little from the aroma.  Maybe some chocolate, raisin, mostly malt.Fairly heavy on the palate.  Light carbanation.  No real sign of the 8% alcohol until you swallow, and the just a hint.  Id say Id go buy another couple of bottles and put the in the cellar, but I dont think that is what this beer needed.  Actually, this beer is probably exactly as intended, just not wowing me.
Rich, thick creamy brown body with a large active caramel lacing head.  Sweet candied caramel malt flavor with a smooth palate.  Nice lasting aftertaste that makes me want more.

750 ML best before 04/2009.  Pours medium brown with a fantastic bubbly head that bubbled over when the cork popped.  Much lace on the glass on the way down.  Black specks dot the head letting you know this is a living brew.  Taste is very fruity.  Plum, fig, maybe even a touch of cherry.  And yet a touch of spice.  Very complex on the palate.  Light and airy yet creamy and delicious.  And oh that wonderful afterburn of the alcohol.  What a fantastic brew!! This was great!

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2006 (Bottle 33 cl) Medium brown with a decent off-white head. Typical dark brown malty flavour + perhaps a touch of ...licorice? Body is only medium in spite of the strong alcohol making this rather easy to drink. More dry than bitter, although with a pronounced touch of hops. 051093

Pours a rich, dark auburn with a dense frothy tan head. Lots of fine lace. Smells spicy, like spiced apples. Sweet rich malt.

Taste is fruity and yeasty. Spicy. the spiced apple flavor is there again. Winey tasting (vinuous, I guess?). Lets break the fruitiness down: apples, cherries, plum and sour berry. A light alcohol burn and a lightly metallic finish. Full-bodied but velvet smooth. Exceptionally easy to drink for the style. A really excellent beer and I am not a big fan of dubbels. Bravo!
Bottled. Hazy nut brown colour, big foamy beige head. Alcohol and malt in aroma. Strong alcohol and a bit breadish malt in flavour. A bit bitter finish.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2007 Rerate: Gosh is this beer underrated and far better than its larger sibling, smooth and malty with a spicy finish...yummy! 

Muddled brown hue with a big frothy off-white head and very good lace. The aroma has notes of candi and brown sugar, caramel malt, earthy yeast, sublime caradmom and pipe tobacco. The taste starts sugary sweet with a mighty malt backbone. Follows with a hint of dark fruits, moderate peppery spices, wild grains and hints of whisky. The finish has some dryness and subdued bitters. The feel is sharp and moderately lush with some alcohol presence. A well crafted brew and has some good taste. Beer geek worthy.
Dark cola brown with a nice frothy white head, taste is reminiscent of the abt 12 but with a ighter malt brown sugar and sweetness.  Good stuff!

Bottled (BB 11/2009)
Good beer to enjoy just the after election of new Pope :)
hazy nut brown, decent foamy off-white head. Much lighter nose than in Abt 12, licorice and anise dominates the aroma. Flavor is quite similar to Abt 12 but lacking the alcoholic burn: licore, raisins, alcohol picks up in the finish.

Dark brown body, big creamy off white head. Sweetly alcoholic, brown sugar and malt in the aroma. Flavour is likewise, more malt and brown sugar, lingering sweetness. Alcohol is apparent but subtle in announcing itself, much better hidden than in the 6.  Smooth medium bodied palate. Very nice beer. A pleasant surprise.

Thick head and long-lasting lacing as expected of any artisan brew. Clean, bready aroma. Flavor is fundamentally vivid yet shows little depth -- the basic yeasty malty forefront is there with maybe a touch of unripe strawberry, toffee-mint and nutmeg. Alcohol prevalent in the mouth which tickles the tongue sort of like a sloe gin. Just a tad of hops come through in the flavor but even more so in the finish, sort of a change of pace having drunk more tripels than dubbels in the past. In addition, finish is like raisin pie. Nice bubbles in the mouth but slightly thin; still, Prior 8 has that liquid bread fillingness in the gut that has kept many a monk on "Cloud 9" during fasting time. This may not be one of the better batches but overall its a good dubbel with potential.

Pours dark mahogany with a tall off-white creamy head. Pours fairly clear at first but has lots of sediment half way through the bottle. Aroma is rich and sweet with brown sugar and a candy apple smell. Taste has a good blend of sweetness and spice, caramel, candy apple, bread, brandy, and some yeastiness throughout.
Very malty smell. It reminds me of a grain silo. :) A standard Belgian much comparable to the Abt 12.

Auburn appearance with a billowy head. Yeasty, dark fruit aroma. Full dark fruit flavor with nutmeg spice and tartness.  Flavor cuts off just as complexity begins to build. I wish this one went (british accent) "to eleven"...I mean twelve.
Raisiny aroma.  Long-lasting head.  Tart, bubbly.  Creamy finish.  A standard Belgian much comparable to the Abt 12.
Pours dark brown with a mostly diminishing yellow head. The flavor hints at raisins, sherry and sweet liquirish. Has a strong, very good finish. Very intense and flavorful experience.

Deep brown somewhat cloudy with an off white quickly diminishing head. Aroma is soft and sweet and surely of alcohol. Toasted sour malts, prunes and earth. Cherry and raspberry tart. Brown bread and lemon pith. Light clove. Toasted pecans and buttery when warmer. Dry finish. Awfully good.
yeasty bready aroma.  Flavor is toasted malts, some fruit, and yeast.  Very good. More complex then the  st bern. 12, without the alc. bite.

Superb strong abbey ale. Poured a cloudy brown colour with a lasting head. The aroma is fresh, rich, raisiny, with chocolate notes. Creamy mouthfeel. Lots of sweet dark malt but with a surprisingly restrained finish for the 8% abv. Treacle, raisins, chocolate, with some dry sherry in the finish. Complex flavour profile. The alcohol is very well balanced here. One of the best of the Belgian strong ales at this alcohol level. (Bottle)

I was anxiously anticpating trying this beer after having had the ABT 12 (best beer in the world to me) and this beer was sort of a disappointment.  It is not bad, but for the price it leaves a lot to be desired.

Poured a beautiful brownish red with a monster head that lasted throughout.  Aroma was Belgian yeast with some maltiness and a bit of hops.  Taste is sweet malty heaven with a bit of fruitiness and a mild yeast aftertaste.  Full bodied mouthfeel. Was already wishing I had more before I was finished.

This brown dubbel-style ale pours with a nice tan head that dissipates quickly.  The aroma is sweet and malty, and so is the flavor. The flavor stays on the palate and has a nice caramel finish. A very nice brew.

Dark brown, with an off white head that laces nicely; Full of small particles. Aroma is metallic and slightly cheesey. Flavor is medium sweet with a metallic tinge, some notes of carob, plum, raisins; medium bitterness.

Beautiful toasted malt with a very fruit forward midpalate focused on berries and plums. Turbinado sugar and maple candy with vanilla creme and caramel finish. good balance somwewhat westy 8 ish. They used to brew the Westvleteren beers after all.

Wonderful dark brown color.  A very strong frothy head.  A little too much head but it went down quickly.  Smells very sweet and malty.  Tastes clean and crisp.  Very good finish, not too strong but very noticable.

Murky,dark brown color with a nice frothy tan head. Sweet malt and yeast aroma with a bit of dark fruit. Flavor was much drier than expected. Dark bread, raisins and an alcoholic warming finish. Excellent.
Strong (8% ABV)  brew with a very mild flavor considering the strength and the amount of malt.

On draught Feb 2005 @ Moan and Dove.  Dark grey-brown color, with some slight hints of reddish coloring along the edges.  Off-white head recedes to small clumps on the edges.  Aroma of raisins, tobacco, nuts, very dry yeast and a bit of banana and alcohol.  Flavor is dry, very dry relative to what I was expecting.  A definite ashiness throughout really seems to dull the flavors.  Strong yeast presence, with some alcohol, lightly sugary raisin/fruit notes.  Not much incidence of residual sugar, candied or otherwise.  I guess its a good thing that this isnt a syrupy sweet, alcoholic mess, but its still missing something.
