Very attenuated, medium body,  peppery carbonation.  Cant seem to get in to St Bernardus beers.
One of the best bottles ever.  Ale has a malty, yeasty nose and is translucent roasted brown.   Sweet and mild, not over the top alcohol profile, but a solid drink.  Short, slightly bitter finish.

God i love that monk. His cheeks flush with alcohol and heart disease. Smells yeasty, lightly spicey, couple hints of caramel. The taste was rye bread or maybe pumpernickel, fig all through it. Very smoothe, long lasting thin head.
750ml bottle in St Bernardus chalice.  Great beer, not much to say, Il think of it as the little brother to the abt 12. Wish I could get it regularly.

Bottle: 11.2oz brown glass, with an orange and monk label. Capped 

Color: A medium muddy brown 

Head: 1/2 finger of small bubbles, with good lacing 

Aroma: Yeasty, with gingerbreaed, and pumpkin pie spice. 

Taste: Toasty malt, with plums, alcohol, and a candi sugar aftertaste. 

I would argue that this is actually a dubbel, albeit a sweet one.

Chesnut brown with hezy caracter and bubbely beige foam. Malty and fruity nose, caramel and fresh cakes aswell. Full mouthfeel with some fizzyness. Good balaced taste with malts candysugar and cookies. Very nice beer.
nice beer, not as memorable as the St. Bernardus Prior 12, but still decent.  i agree that the gift set is great, i love the glass!
A very good beer.  Dark and murky hues, fruity malt with just a touch of spice.  A great belgian indeed.
At touch of leather and tobacco in the nose, with lots of phenolics.  Nice color and quite tasty.  A very good brew.

Darkly brown and ruby with a huge foamy tight head that peaked like meringue. 
Hugely complex aroma, dried fruits, chocolate, malt, yeast, almost leathery.
The flavor is also quite complex. Raisins, brown sugar, chocolate, cream and a touch of alcohol. Very smooth and sippable.

11.2ozer in St Bernardus glass....damn im getting tired of saying the same thing....Lots of flavour to be had here. My bottle was pretty carbonated so I had to air it out a bit in the glass. Taste had plum, some raosted malt, clove, banana and maybe a dashel of cinnamon. Aftertaste was still carby and had a nice chewy/nutty sensation. Smooth overall. good stuff, but I liked the 6 a little better.
A lot of flavor, this one is as good as the 12 in that respect.  The St. Bernardus gift pack is a wonderous thing 4 great beers and a kick ass real trappist glass.  This beer MAKE ME HAPPY!!
This one is nice malty offering.  Not too heavy, but it definitely lets you know its got a little alcohol in it.  A very approachable Belgian.  This is one fine brewer.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Bottled. Poured in a goblet.Cloudy brown/red colour. Medium foamy, lacey head. Aroma is toasted malts, nutty,  raisins and hints of plums. Tastes malty, sweet, nutty and fruity (plums, raisins). Slightly bitter, sweet finish. A lovable beer.

Tap.  First off, heres an attaboy for Eli Cannons for serving this in the proper glassware.  Aroma was alright, nothing really stood out, mostly malty.  Flavor had a lot of dark fruit (I tasted a lot of plum and fig)  As it warmed, thre was some chocolate, and the alcohol really presented itself, but that faded toward the end of the glass.  It finished a little dry, not too bitter, and warm from the alcohol.  Overall, it was a good beer.  Now we know why that monk on the bottle is so happy
Dark amber, great brownish head. Nutty aroma, malty and dry. More hazelnuts is there after a while. Mild and with a great body, malty and nutty.

Bottle, Smokeless Joes.  Hazy dark brown pour.  Aroma was a little disappointing - some caramel, but subtle.  Big thick creamy head - this was like a nitro head only with flavour!  Medium body mouthfeel.  Interesting slightly yeasty taste - there is a rich base of chocolate here, more prevalent than in the ABT 12 in my opinion.  Malt taste dominated in the context of a strong Belgian, and the alcohol is very well hidden as well.  Not as overall flavourful as the ABT 12, or as complex, but still a very solid beer - this brewery is 2 for 2 in my books - cant wait to try some of the others that have just become available here.

Bottled.
Dark brown with a huge, beige head.
Vinous aroma with chocolate and notes of hazelnuts.
Dark and fullbodied. Rather sweet and very malty with hazelnuts in the flavour.

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2005 ah yet another abbye ale.i love these.anyways,here we go....when i first poured the st. out,it appeared to be a dark brown.then when i shown it up to a light.i was greeted with a red appearance,and little "floaties" scurrying around the liquid.next came the aroma.i was rushed with a complexity of chocolate,figs,malts,and honey.the last and best surprise was the flavor.very smooth with malts,fruit,belgian yeast,and chocolate.this is simply outstanding.bolth of the st. bernardus brews i have had were top notch.
re-rate:this gets better everytime i have it honestly.this perticular instance the prior 8 poured a picutre perfect brown/ruby red body with a lovely 2 inch head.when the head simmered it left gobs of webs on all sides.i just drank my last one,damn i need to re-up and age a few of these.
A good tasting beer.  Not a noticeable taste of alcohol, but a very good beer.  A hint of chocalate and spices.
Dark muddy brown coloured beer, aroma with hints of fruit and malts. Taste is fairly complex with lots of fruit, caramel, biscuits. Too sweet.
UPDATED: APR 19, 2014 Not as yeasty as abt. 12, but the malt and bread is more clear and present in Prior. Dark, big head.
Dark hazy color, off-white big head. Sour/sweet malty, alcohol aroma. Taste dominated by bitter, malt and sweetness, and a little bit smokey. Nice beer!

11.2oz bottle. another in the gift pack with glass.  Muddy brown with an off-white head that dissipates after a while, a little lacing.  Nice sweet malty aroma.  Excellent flavors that go very deep.. sweet malts, dark fruit.  A lot of carbonation in the mouth which delivers a tart, dry finish.  Very balanced, with a nice medium body and a little hop bite towards the finish.. not too much bitterness.  I like it a lot.  No fault to be found, its an excellent brew all around.  Beats the crap out of Chimay Rouge.  The folks at St Bernardus obviously pay attention to quality.  Very tasty!

Bottle. Mahogony color with a nice  off-white head. Rich malty aroma with some spicey yeast. Some banana/clove flavors from the yeast, but otherwise toffee and some date stone fruit. Nice depth. Finishes dry and makes you want to keep drinking...

ruby brown color, cloudy, with a fluffy tan head.  bready, fruity aroma - liquid fruit cake??  sweet fruity and malty flavor, also some dark rum and yeastiness.  not much hop, but dryish finish, a little port-like.
This was a very good beer.  Kind of in between tastes between the 6 and the 12.  Worth a try and recommended.

Good size off-white head on top of a murky dark amber brown body. I dont get a lot of caramel in the nose but I get toasted grains, spice and rich fruit. Taste is better as it warms, smooth rich mouthfeel with a medium body, hints of caramel, cocoa, soft spice, fruit and  pleasant alcohol.
Nice dark brown color with huge airy foam. Complex aromas of caramel, malts, and dried fruits. It has a heavey taste with a very good balance and a refreshing carbonation.
Poured an amberish hue, and had a tan head which lasted a good while. Aroma was malty, fruity and spicy. I enjoyed this beer, flavor was a little sweet, and had hints of spices and malts, very nice.
Slightly oxidized aroma supported with notes of chocolate and fig. Cloudy brown with a loose tan head. Full flavored with cocoa, yeast, malt, dates. Mild, soft finish. Nice.

Deep amber brown with thick off white head.  Pillowy nose of malt and carmel with fruit overtones. Heavy weight with a rich finish. Flavors of tootsie roll, carmel, chocolate, malt and rich goodness. Yum.

Turbid orangish brown color with a huge head.  Aroma of malt, hops, citrus, barnyard.  Tastes malty, fruity, with finishing orange, cranberry, toffee, caramel, and even watermelon.  Smooth finish with well hidden alcohol and a multitude of flavors that seem to go together.  Very complex and enjoyable.

From an 11.2oz bottle. Best before 01/01/07. Tasted at 52 degrees in a tulip glass. Dark brown with a big cream colored head that sticks around, maybe too long. Plenty of lacing.  Sweet, malty aroma. Raisins, fruits, sour candies.  It takes a minute or two for the nose to open up. Flavor is sweet and has notes of ripe banana, yeast, bread, plums, and malt. Sweetish, dry finish with some nice residual flavors. It is maybe a bit too sweet for me. This was tasted after the Trois Pistoles, I found that to be a more complex beer.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2006 Cloudy dark brown with a thin white head.  Super sweet malty aroma.  Tastes of sweet raisins and prunes.  Slightly bitter finish.  

Re-Rate.  Murky and brown with a thick tan head that seems to just sit with no ability to subside.  Malty aroma with some chocolate, raisins, prunes, cinnamon and dough.  Lively flavor of prunes, grapes, raisins, caramel, chocolate, bread and alcohol.  Somewhat warm finish with some yeastiness left on the tongue.  I simply cant say enough about this beer, top o the heap.
Murky red/brown colour with small off-white head. aroma has got lots of malty sweetness with some toffee and yeast. Flavor is sweet and spicy with a slight touch of alcohol.

hazy red brwon, off white head.  big aroma of booze, toffee, baked apples/apple pie, vanilla and raisin.  flavour is sweet and spicy with fresh baking bread flavours, booze, raisins and mild spicy bitterness.  very nice.
UPDATED: NOV 16, 2008 Brown color with a tan head. Aromas of fruit, malt and some yeast. Kind of bread-like. Taste is fruit, spice, raisins, and yeast. Rerated 11/16/2008.
Black color with a thin head.  Aroma of bread.  The bread turns bitter in the taste.  There really isnt much depth here other than some yeast and bread.  Decent, but not great.

Hugely yeasty, malty and fruity aroma. Plenty of yeast in suspension in the amber-brown body with lasting covering of small-bubbled, tan head. Sweet, malty, caramelly flavour with plums and raisins. and a decent balancing bitterness. Cremy, chewy mouthfeel and medium-full body. A nice way to warm up before heading out for the Grey Cup game in Ottawa. Bottle enjoyed with CapFlu and Lubiere.
Brown ale with reddish hues, off white head. Sweet fruity malt aroma, and sweet raisiny malts with a nice hop/alcohol moutfeel which was sustained, Creamy and complex. Thanks to Capflu.
Red Coloring With Off White Head.  Yeasty.. Malty..Some Bread Dough...Little Dry at the End.  Very Enjoyable.

(750ml bottle) Pours a creamy yellowish-head and a cloudy deep-brown body. The nose is very yeasty with malt and fruity undertones. I enjoyed the light and quaffable creamy and heavy malt taste. Enjoyable yet drinking the whole 750ml bottle in a night might be a daunting task...

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2005  I am going to rate this for real now.  Pours a very dark brown which looks nearly identical to the Westy 8.  That would make sense because they are brewed in the same town.  The aroma is very fruity with raisins being the dominant fruit.  There is quite a bit of white wine in the aroma as well.  The taste has quite a bit of similarity to the Westy 8 with the white wine palate added to it.  There is also the great maltiness which is recognizable from this brewery.  This is similar to the 12 except it is less complex and not quite as good in my opinion.  This is a really fine beer and one of the greatest examples of a Dubbel I have had.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2011 Murky brown, rocky off white head, fades to thick film, spotty lacing. Prune/fig/raisin up front in nose, clove, spice, alcohol, really dig it. Flavor not quite as nice, rather muted. Faint dark fruit, alcohol and not much else. Not bad, just not what you would expect after aroma. Billowy mouthfeel, flimsy at times.

Murky brown color, thin off-white head. Aroma of malt, alcohol and fruits, its woody too. Flavor of chocolate, fruits, caramel and malt. Light to medium body, creamy texture. It feels like a mix between Rochefort 8 and St. Bernardus ABT 12, not bad at all!
Just like its bit brother. Little to distinguish this brew from other belgian strong ales. Very little complexity and just not that great.

On tap at Anam Cara Belgian Beer Month.  Very drak brown, almost black.  Bubbly tan head.  Raisony malt aroma.  Sweet but not too sweet with raison and plum malt.  Full and complex.  Ummmmm....so good.
Dark brown color, medium spicy sweet aroma and taste, full body, dry light alcoholic finish.

Bottle:  Pours dark honey/amber brown with a small-medium off-white head.  Hazy, small bubbles and small yeast particles.  Aroma:  Dust, earth, toasted grains, mild wood, sweet yeast, figs, raisins, mildly spicy notes, dark syrupy malts.  Taste:  Warming flavor, sweet candy, raisins, apples, plums, nuts, light spicy yeasts, caramel, finishes with a dry & bitter molasses taste.  I like the fruit background that I cant quite put my finger on.

This was still quite young being 2 1/2 years from BB date. Poured a hazy daerkish brown with a fairly decent pillowy head. Aroma of semi sweet chocolate,mild malt,yeast dark fruits(raisens,dried plums,black cheeries.)
 Add in some bits of spice ala Aventinus as it warmed on the flavor.Almost creamy mouthfeel. Best dubbel Ive had so far.

Deep dark cherrywood with a tall sturdy crown that starts as foam but resonates down to healthy head of a 8th inch bubbly/frothy whipped light tan topping. Leaves tons of lacing coating the glass.

Aroma is dry of light earthyness along with some yeasty esters of flowers and light spice.with a strong fruity sense of figs, raisins, and dark cherries keeping a lush and full sweet edge over the top. 

Flavors ensue a pleasurable display of fruits displayed from the aroma with dry little spices. Firm, steardy, and steady with a full taste brigade from start to finish. Sweet and chewy finish late with bits of candied fruits and a light textured nuttyness. A great taster.

Feel is creamy and nearly full with some light drying effects floating around and finishes terrific with a super yummy and smooth exhibition of chewy fruits and earthly delights. Another fine drinker by St. Bernardnus.
pours dark brown with a fair-sized head. Spicy aroma. Sweet, slightly fruity flavor. Hardly any aftertaste. No alcohol detectable. Pretty good.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2008 [33 cl. bottle] Dark brown color with an off-white head. Light aroma of yeast, roasted malts and some spicy notes. Very sweet and complex flavor. Begins with a sweet and spicy mixed flavor followed by a nice yeasty middle and a sweet and warming finish. Very creamy mouthfeel and leaves a slight aftertaste of yeast and fruits.

This one like all the Bernardus beers really need to age. This brew is fine, it has all what I want in a beer, I would like to see this brew with a bit more character though                                              .

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Opaque dark brown colour with a light brown, good sized head. Roasted malts, yeast,dark fruits and spicey sweet aroma. 
What a lovely taste. Like aroma promises, with great body and well hid alcohol, that reveals itself in a warming manner some time later. Delicious.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2004 Exceptional brew.  Not quite up there with the 12, but excellent none the less.  Really, its almost just like the 12, with a bit less kick.  And there is nothing wrong there.  The complexity is all here, so delicous.  Spicy, sweet, zippy, yeasty, fruity, malty, just downright awesome.  Belgians ales are emerging as my new favorite style, set to replace imperial stouts.

Pours a dark musty burgundian brown with tiny sediment particles clinching to the sides of the entire glass. The head is mountainous, dense and definately Belgian. Sheets of lacing left all over the glass with the head lasting the entire session. Rich aroma of red licorice, sweet malts, raisins, yeast and bread. A very vibrant and diverse flavor profile of caramel apples, raisins, figs, cane sugars, spices, sweet candy, yeast and alcohol. Trememdously balanced! Full mouthfeel and a smooth aftertaste that lingers on and on. Stupendous!

Poured ruby brown with a nice rocky tan head that faded into a thin lasting tan layer...smelled very malty and lots of raisins and alcohol...taste was sweet with notes of plums and raisins...a little caramel and alcohol, but very subtle...finish, however, was a little disappointing...rather cloyingly sweet, but definately good...

Bottle:  Aroma is very malty with caramel, raisin, and alcohol.  Pours a dark reddish-brown with a decent tan head with fair retention.  Excellent lacing.  Flavor is malty and fruity with caramel and raisin.  The alchohol is really noticealbe in the finish.  Caramel flavors seem to intensify in the finish as well.  Decent beer but I like the 6 better. I don’t like the more intense alcohol flavor of the 8.
Deep Brown; Head was lasting if whispy. Dark fruit in the nose. Good sweetness. Nice hiding of the alcohol as well.

75cl bottle, BBD rubbed off the cage.  Brown.  Thick tan head.  Toasty malt aroma, some fruitiness(raisin).  Thin beer, thick lace.  Not one to be drank cooled, it takes on more body, complexity & creaminess as it warms and breathes.  A nice, toasty brew, finishing with a bitter/sweet balance and a lingering chocolate taste.

09.13.04 11.2oz bottle (07.12.06 dated).  Pour is opaque, chestnut brown, clouded.  Head is large, even, medium sized bubbles, sheeting lace.  Aromas of apple, chocolate, banana, toffee; yeasty and doughy.  Flavors of raisin, prune, plum, more toffee.  Little noted in the spice department, slightly pie spicey.  Hints of rust evolve with teh alcoholic nasal effect, strange.  The body is creamy, but unfortunately effervescent, tingly, takes away from the nice maltiness.  Wish it was sweeter.

Id give this a 6/5 for appearance - wow!  Classic dubbel appearance with the most beautiful rocky head that laces like a champ.  The appearance is only the beginning of this beauty.  The aroma is of red apples, currants and slight spice.  The flavor is just like the 12 (chocolate, caramel, spice, blood, cloves, apple), with a little less body. The creaminess of the head is unique to the carbonated parts, as the remaining body is a tad thin and watery.  Very much as expected - a good thing.  8% ABV is buried in this complex goodness.

Dark copper hue, medium off-white head consisting of big bubbles, mostly diminishing. Big yeasty (dough, light must) and vinous aroma with several fruity hints (banana, plums, grapes) matching a generous toffee and alcohol presence. RIchly malty. Sweet on the tongue, with scotch ale characteristics, but a very yeasty one. Mild acidic profile. More alcohol than most in the finish. Not so balanced imo, leaves an oily coat around the mouth. Slight yeasty and leafy bitterness. Medium body is extremely bubbly, a bit too much for its own good.

Dark mahogany brown color, full, fervent foam, a bit beigey in color, slowly simmering down.
Aroma, spice, nuts, fruit, faint cocoa, more spice, cinnamon, clove, very carbonated, very enticing, uplifting, arousing, even...a lovely snootful, me likey.
Very lively, zesty taste, the mouth swims with this pruney, raisiny, vibrant flavor...Im liking it more as it nestles in the crevices of my tastebuds.
Bursts afresh on the tongue again and again. Full-bodied, long, warm, lovely finish. Goodness aplenty in this bottle. A keeper if ever there was

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2014 Bottled.  An extremely complex beer.  It is dark brown with an everlasting cream coloured head.  the aroma is a bit meaty almost smoky.  The taste is very malty and chewy.  It is very full-bodied and has loads of character.  A demanding beer which, looking back, reminds me of Abbaye des Rocs which I wasnt keen on at the time.  I really must redrink that one. Score 4.0Subsequent rating scored 4.3. Average becomes 4.1

Presentation: 330ml bottle.

Full, rocky tan head that maintains a good presence to the end. A cloudy dark brown/red color, with plenty of sediment. The aroma is yeasty, of dried fruit, malt, bubblegum and a little medicinal. Flavor was quite complex: sweet start, creamy/malty middle with a dry spicy finish that maintained a taste of plums. The mouth feel is full-bodied, and smooth with relatively low presence of carbonation. It rolls off the tongue leaving an oily consistency. St. Bernardus has a pleasant well-rounded blend of flavors and mouth feel with no overwhelming/over the top characteristics.

Brownish with a head that lasts forever albeit thinly. Nose is dusty pear and honey with a musty floral hint. Raisins and dark malt come out as you sip. Slightly watery, slightly sticky with mild carbonation.

8 May 2004 - Spiritous, vinuos, heavy malt with a hint of earthy aroma. Cloudy deep brown colour with small head and soap lacing.  Sweet and medicinal flavours, with an earthiness and a spiritous throat. Medium mouthfeel. 
I wouldnt mind rating this one again.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2007 Well heres my rerate from a 3.1 rating, it appears the original was a bad bottle. Poured a bright rubyish hue, a tad darker than pure red. 3 finger head with sheets of lacing - enough protein that my tulip glass shapes the head. Aroma is strongly fruity with plum, date, persimmon coupled with a mild caramelization. Flavor starts with a pillowy body fleshing out lots of sugary malts, and a slight fruitiness. Next, a yeasty spiciness couples tightly with a light alcohol burn through the finish. Lingering banana and phenol. Nice big Belgian, but not as smooth, complex and well-integrated as it could be.
Dark brown, some red, opaque, with a small white head, aroma of grape, sugar and some alcohol, flavor is sweet, malty, not particularly fruity, no hops, some alcohol. Overall, pretty good.

Pours cloudy brown in color with a huge light brown head that sticks to the sides of my glass. Fruity sweet and spicy aromas, sugary plum and raisin flavors, medium bodied with a crisp almost soda like mouthfeel, finishes with a brown sugar sweetness.

Says its a dubbel. If so the strangest dubbel ever. Nose is peppery, fig like and meaty rounded out with a lovely cinnamon or spice touch. Flavors however do not match the nose. Not all that peppery not all that fig like not all that meaty. More bland than anyhting else in the mouth but not awful
G-rat

This might be my favorite st bernardus yet. Bottle, pours a deep dark amber with a fat fluffy head that stays til the end. nice pear aroma with a touch of earthy yeast scent.sweet and chewy taste with an up front bitterness that finishes with a fruity sweet maltiness. nice enjoyable warming brew.
Bottle. Good mild, belgian ale. Malty, raisin, usual Belgian notes. Finish is full and quick.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2004 Hazy brown body with a thin but lasting beige creamy head. Lots of carbonation as I poured it. Strong alcohol and toffee aroma. Vigorous and warming alcohol attack. Then the taste gets milder, balanced and characterized with nutty, chocolate and caramel hints. Long and pleasant vineous aftertaste. This is quite a nice one! Thanks for the order, PrimeMinister!

750 ml corked bottle dated 2002 (best before 2007). Poured a medium mahagony color with an averaged sized tan head. Floating particles. Nice carbonation. Aromas of malts, plums, raisins, bread, and some spices. Tastes of molasses, brown sugar, light yeast, and some plums. Alcohol well hidden. Top notch belgian brew.

Aroma is malty with some cherries, raisins, and roasted almonds. Appearance is brown with a moderate white head. The flavor is slightly spicy with some nutmeg. I can detect some grapes, caramel, and wheat. This beer is also quite carbonated. A good one! Thanks Wunderbier.

Sampled at From The Vine beer tasting Jul 9th, 2004: Pours a lightly cloudy brown color with a light tan head. Thin lacing. The aroma is an interesting concoction of malt, raisin and caramel. Medium-bodied with a great Belgian feel from the get-go. Flavors of spice (cinnamon and coriander), yeast, warming alcohol and caramel. The finish is nicely complex with lots of spice and malt. I am a fan of the 12 and this beer is no slouch either.

Great brown beer with intens creamy froth.Well balanced aromas of light roasted malts,ripe banana,ricecrispys and caramel toffees.It has a creamy taste with a fine freshness and a good selection of fine malts.This beer has a good afthertaste with a sweet side and a great complexity of fine hops.

This brew poured to a huge creamy head,bigger than Donald Trumps.I was finally left with a hazy ruby brew busy with carbonation.Unfortunately,there was little to speak about as far as taste and aroma so this beer will need to be revisited.Unusual for a St.Bernardus.

The quality of the beer is immediately apparent in the reddish brown insanely carbonated body, and the towering tan head.  The aroma is complex, with chocolate, honey, and musk on the nose.  The taste has a warm and spicy alcohol bite, with a banana nut bread taste, and some dusty yeast lurking in the back.  The mouthfeel is creamy and a bit on the light side.  This is technically a Dubbel, but comes in Tripel strength of 8% ABV.  A welcome newcomer to Georgia shelves.

Smells like buttered bread.  Well, not exatly, but maybe in liquid form.  But its a dark brown hiding under a good vat of cream.  Taste is a bit of caramel and banana.  Hmmm... Maybe Its liquid banana bread.  Regardless, its very smooth except for a slight ending bitterness which comes with a ending sweet feel on the lips.

Bottle: Poured a quite opaque brown beer with a great head with good retention. Aroma is bit weaker then expected with some roasted malts and some light plums. Taste is also a mix between roasted malts, a bit of candi sugar and some light plums. Overall, this is a good beer lacking a bit of complexity and overshadowed by better products from this brewery.

There are beers using fish bones to clarify, and I hope I did not hit it here or at anytime! Complex carbonated taste includes orange and other fruit and yeastiness. Strangely reddish colour.
Thanks IP Freely
Overrated

Brown with lighter amber tones and a large, nicely sculpted off white head which quickly produces some nice lacing.  There is a strong aroma of dried fruit and it seems very light and sweet.  Raisin and possibly cherry are present.  The taste is initially sweet with the dry fruits like raisin and plum making a visit.  Its nicely smooth and as it warms up the smell, feel, and taste of alcohol is noticable.  It finishes nicely, with a medium body.

dark brown almost black color with a huge head that didnt last to long.
very slight aroma.
this is a good tasty beer but nothing amazing,,i would by some again if i seen it and couldnt decide on anything else but i wouldnt go out looking for it,,not bad at all though.

Large, rocky head and decent lacing; huge yeasty, citrus, banana, and tropical fruit aroma; notes of raison, date, and plum in the flavor; spicy rum finish; thick, oily palate; pretty complex and quite wonderful.

33 cL bottle. Hazy, dark reddish brown colour, with a thick, dense and stable head with a reddish tint. Fresh aroma with strong notes of banana and weaker notes of malt. Initially good balance in the flavour between sweetness (dark, dried fruits) and alcohol with a hoppy, bitter aftertaste. However, as the beer warmed up the sweetness became too dominant. A good beer.

Standard thick brown Belgian body with a fruity, kind of banana aroma.  Decent taste to match it but nothing truly spectacular.  A good example of an average Belgian.  Superior to most non-Belgies, but just average in its own category.

This was a very good and enjoyable beer.Nice thin white head.Body was dark,very cloudy and above medium texture.It looked great and inviting to me.Taste is hard to decribe.Not as complex and spicy as the ABV12,but very pleasant.(i´m sorry i just can´t describe the taste,but yummy it was!).This is a very very good beer!

I found the Prior 8 to be a good beer, but unspectacular.  The aroma was light and faintly orange-y.  The head poured average, off-white, and frothy/fizzy, and it diminished somewhat slowly until it was small (but not gone).  In the glass, it was a transluscent amber-yellow, and looked nicely refreshing, with the aroma still in mind.  The taste I didnt find to be sweet at all, with a subtle malt flavor in the back of the tounge and moderate acidity all around.  The finish began slightly sour (which I enjoyed), and then evened out and lingered for an average amount of time (although I couldnt identify it as either hoppy or malty).  At the very end, it became a bit metallic, but not obtrusively so.  It wasnt dry, was mostly watery, and the only very noticable thing was the very lively carbonation.  As I said, this one seemed very simple to me, and perhaps my palate isnt developed enough to pick up a whole bunch of subtle flavor.

Nice average-sized off-white frothy head that mostly lasts, and a dark red/brown body. Aroma is light with an earthy/musty raspberry and strong banana. Taste is complex with wood, brown sugar, raspberry, prune, banana, and blueberry. Didnt like the mouthfeel... the flavor was full, but it was a little watery and harshly carbonated. Overall, very good though.
Dark brown with a medium long lasting tan frothy head, good lacing. Nose is malty with some Iron. Taste is grainey with some hints of rusty and lager funk. Medium bodied pertty darn good

Not very good.  Murky copper/brown with frothy off-white head.  My first thought upon smelling it was of raw meat.  Who knows why.  Iron, perhaps?  But thats what I thought as I inhaled the vapors.  The body was medium and the flavor was a tad astringent.  Not impressed.

Bottle Conditoned, poured in a chalice. Dark, diminishing head.
Yeast, spice, pepper, reserved sweetness, powdery and rum. Very good, but not up to the 12 cap!

Mr. Bernard pours with a robust mahogany body and a thick quilted tan head. The aroma is light, notes of a yeasty biscuit, a touch of coco, and some fruity plums, apricots and dates.
 The flavor is dark and toasty. A loaf of Pumpernickel bread, but with suggestions of Rye. More coco, a little orange zest, loads of black pepper, and cantaloupe. Ive gotta give it to Mr. Bernard on the palate light, velvety, drapes the glass with its quilt of lacing after every sip! Good Stuff!
Huge lasting tan head. Cloudy dark brown color. Fruity aroma with rasins, plum, banana. Malty sweet with ripe banana and a vinous finish.

Hazy brown appearance, rich, pillowy beige head. Fruity aroma of banana, apricots and plums with a with notes of spices and yeast. Sweet flavour of plums, yeast and banana. Spicy finish with a vauge note of dark bread.

dark and ruby with a substantial foamy head. chocolate and malt, yeast, and alcohol in the aroma.  thick bready and malty body, definite taste of yeast in there too.  really rich, and if you let it warm up in your mouth a little you get some extra sweetness and then some bitterness in the finish.  excellent beer!
Strong aroma of alcohol but some raisiny and malt notes shine through. Cloudy red/brown with a small head. Lightly hoppy with strong alcohol and malt flavours, quite mellow and yeasty.

Poured a nice murky brown with some orange highlights with a fluffy beige head. Nice doughy aroma with some plum notes. Comples with notes of plums,raisins, with some slight spiciness over a nice caramel malt backbone, excellent.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2008 (Bottled) Very dark brown with a large head. Aroma of lavender, rosemary, anise and orange-peel. Flavor is herb-accented with anise, orange-peel, lavender, and hints of rosemary - but still reasonably malty. Alcohol sticks out a little, but doesnt irritate. Medium to full-bodied, neutral palate with soft carbonation. A pleasantly herby, slightly alcoholic brew with good balance.
Spiritus malt aroma with dark caramel colour and thick head. Bitter malt flavour with fizzy palate.

Nightcap on a "malt-based" tasting night.  Raisins/dough/alcohol/figsmell.  Odd spoiled bread smell coming from the yeast.  Bland and sharpish up front but a more pleasing smooth swallow that warms with dark fruit flavors.  For some reason the alcohol was very apparent to me although not many other raters seem to note it.  This was a bit of let-down but it deserves a re-rate sometimes when my allergies are completely subdued.

Pours from the bottle with an active and light tan head. Light brown color reminds me of highway patrol men pants. Smells of apples, vanilla, clove and a hint of vinegar. The taste is full at first with lots of bread. Then it fades to apples and some raisins. A nice one to take your time with.
Amber color with a root beer head and a candi sugar nose.  Very light for the 8% alcohol.  Lots of malty sweetness, candi sugar with some yeast.  Thinner that the bigger strong ales, but very nice.

bottled: into the glass this one is mahogany brown with lots of sediment floating throughout,  an off white tan head. nice bold aroma, mostly malt and fruit. on the palate what you expect you taste, raisin malt...rock candy sweet. changes as the beer warms, maybe some figs...sweet. a solid robust brew cant wait to try the rest.
UPDATED: MAR 11, 2016 Bottle.Another Abbey cracker,taste of dates,muscovado,old wine and wood,earthy fun.

Bottle pours a sediment ridden cherry red brown with a monster head and cob web lace.  The aroma is yeasty.  The flavor has a large yeast component, a dry finish, chocolate malt, and spice.  The palate is very cleansing as it is quite carbonated, but also very smooth and rich.  The alcohol hides well!  Overall, this is a very good BSA.

Aroma malty yeasty, slightly fruity with a bubble gum component. Head is off white, dense with a consistant eruption of bubbles from the center. The head laces the glass with a very dense carpet of bubbles. Starts sweet, full bodied and noticebly carbonated. Very smooth mouthfeel. There is a baseline of sour in the flavor as well as a subtle bitterness. The finish develops to chocolaty bittersweet. Overall, a nice rich belgian, but a little to sweet.
Dark amber brown, tan head, slightly hazy. Deep dark fruit, leather, subdued spiciness, roasted malts

Beer pours (in Chimay glass) from the 11.2 oz. bottle a deep, dark brown, slightly red, liquid with a medium amount of slightly caramel colored head that lingers and bubbles.  Aroma is of plum, raisin, chocolate, figs, slight malt.  Flavor is of chocolate plum, raisin, figs, with a slight amount of hops which makes the ending a bit dry.  Good, but not as complex or as malty as Chimay Blue.  Sampled at 68 degrees Fahrenheit.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2004 Bottle pours earthy brown with a nice frothy tannish head, good carbonation, adequate lacing.   Aroma is very vinous, bubblegummy, as well as a bit alcoholic.   Light notes of figs/dates are apparent, but are masked by the alcohol.   Dates/plums make up the majority of the flavor, as well as the typical belgian yeastiness.   Slightly malty as well.   Finishes with a prune or over ripened fruit flavor.   The 8% is well hidden, doesn't seem to be noticable at all.   Overall its good, but I prefer the Abt 12 over this one, with the Tripel coming in 3rd.
bottle...hazy chocolate brown color with substantial head that lingers.  Malty aroma.  Malt dominates the beginning, giving way to sweetness.  Very palatable, nicely balanced, delicious beer.
Aroma is light and somewhat fruity.  Cherries maybe somewheres in there.  Pour is a hazy mahogany witha  robust tannish head.  Malty body.  Rpasted.  Refreshing.  Nice. Some sweetness.
Pour dark with a large white head. Aroma of Dark fruit with a slight metallic note. Palate is a bit thin. Flavor is of dark fruit, nuts, there is a bit to much alcoholic warmth but only a bit.

750 mL bottle, snifter.  Caramel, nutty malt (M); doughy yeast (M); toffee, clove/banana, fig aromas.  Tall, frothy, tan head is slowly diminishing and sits on clear brown-amber body.  Moderately sweet, lightly acidic flavor becomes a moderately sweet, lightly bitter, lightly acidic finish.  Medium-heavy body, creamy texture, fizzy carbonation.  The bottom line is: really good, it just doesn't thrill me though...maybe it's the acidity and fizziness.

aromas of dark fruits plum, raisons, spice and alcohol. the color is mohagany with ruby  huge creamy head that lasts. huge flavors of syrup, malt, chocolate, plums, raisons, a drying bitterness toward the finish, also nuts, and cookie. hints of rum. full bodied and creamy. the sweetness is a little much with out some balancing bitterness. the beer is probably a little young. I'll definately age the others I have longer.

Belgian.  Reminded me slightly of Corsendonk, a spicy brown ale of sorts, with some nice nutty characteristics.  Lots of dark fruits, such as prunes and figs, with some raisins in the mix as well.  A little sweet at times, but never cloying enough to be unenjoyable.
Ugly orange/brown color with smallish head. Aroma of candy and malty sweetness. Tastes is a thick malt with bread and molasses.

aroma is yeasty and a little nutty. pours dark brown with a light tan head.  flavor is somewhat tart and sweet, flavors of apples and belgan yeast. i really have trouble putting my finger on flavors in belgan beers, but i do know that I enjoyed this beer and would seek it out again
(Bottle)  Pours a medium brown color with a descent sized off-white head.  Aroma of raisins and plums.  Flavor is creamy and malty.

Hazy brown body, thick, foamy and long lasting head. Heavy aroma of fruit, plum, raisins, spices and a nice hint of alcohol. Great! Flavor is very soft and spicy with penetrating raisin and chocolate notes. A little watery finish but with a nice alcohol bite. A very full-bodied and tasteful beer. Can't wait to taste no. 12!

Nice thin head which last the duration.  Subtle aroma of grapes, malt and a little bit of spices.  Color is a nice cloudy dark amber.  Sweet flavor with some fruit, malt and a touch of alcohol.  Finish is creamy and warming with a slight dry artertaste.  A good abbey brown (dubbel) but I am starting to notice that this is not my favorite style.

Another great abbey-style beer, brown color, no head whatsoever, I don't know if my bottle was a little flat or not but there was absoutley no head, it didn't taste flat so I went with it, huge malt profile, sweet nose & flavors, yeast & candy sugar as well in the flavors

Very attractive light brown in color with a big off white head that is very fully retained.  Aroma is compelling.  Notes of raisins, yeast and alcohol.  Flavor is initially malty.  Finish is very long lasting and chewy.  Excellent beer.

Georgeous unfiltered dark brown, with a nice fluffy tan head. Reminds me of dark, dark cider with nutmeg floating around.

Nice sweet alchohol scent... not too overpowering... some fruitiness in there too.

This one is odd... first sip I was thinking, "Hmm, a bit too harsh and fake." But the second sip is when I truly tasted the complexity. Starts out with a sweet fruity apple, or similar fruit, and gets progressively bitter, finishing with an creamy chocolatey/coffee taste.

Nice beer... not a session for it's sweetness and abv... but I'll see more of these in my future.

750 ml. big 'ole brown Belgian bottle. Corked and caged. Freshness date on metal cap was 7/2008. Must be fairly fresh then.
Loud pop releases the cork, satisfying hiss of carbonation escaping from the bottle. Poured out a murky, cloudy reddish - brown color, with a huge off-white head. It leaves a more than decent lacing down the sides of the glass. Thick, yeasty matting on top of the beer itself. Aromas are of candi sugar, dark malts, slight caramel, toasted bread, and Belgian yeast. Tastes are of caramelized sugars, Pilsner malts, and Noble hops. Spicy hop bite to it, and a decent maltiness as well. Mouthfeel is slightly thinnish.
Dry finish to it as well. A decent double, but not my cup of tea.

Muddy brown orange with a medium head with small persistant bubbles.  Bready plums that are swimming happily in alcohol.  Smooth and almost creamy.  The body is filled with small bubbles.  Caramel notes at the end.  This is the best beer that I've had all year.

dark brown. nice creamy head. aroma is sweet and yeasty with a citrus hop presence. flavour is well balanced sweet and malty with an understated vinious almost sour brett tang and hop bite. Excellent beer I'll have to find some more of this!!

Pours cloudy brown with a large tan head.  Aroma is sweet, fruity, with a little grain.  Flavor is strong.  Sweet and malty, dried dates or prunes and caramel.  A good yeasty kick.  A nice bitterness and alcohol balances nicely.  A VERY good beer.

Dark brown appearance with a mocha colored head - excellent thick lacing. Sweet, tangy aroma - reminds me of raisins and brown bread. Flavor has the same elements with an ever so delcate lacing of alcohol. Also detect some prune flavor (I like prunes!) Goes down ever so smoothly. One of the smoothest drinking Belgian Strong Ales I have had. The monks are doing it up right at St. Bernardus!

Good aroma -- grain, a little floral, boozy.  Good label, good walnut colored brew with camel-colored head. Very well-balanced, rich, with an alcoholic kick.  It would make a good mincemeat stock. Very, very good.
Good Belgian ale, almost felt like a trappist with its spicy carbonated mouthfeel. Good amount of alcohol in it to make it a meal drink though it would stand alone as a meal with its full finish.

This belgian strong was originally brewed by, and is now dedicated to Richard Pryor, the famous freebasing comedian who as you probably know also invented the kite, chocolate ovaltine, and lightning. Nice dark chocolate (dark!) opaque color. This one's malty too like all of the St. Stephen brews but this time it's bitter, too. Nice balance. You know what other raters are saying about the plums and all that fruity stuff? Well, they're right too. Nice dry finish. Medium to high carbonaion. Way to go, St. Funkmaster!

750 ml. corked bottle.  Large light tan, fluffy head.  Dark brown, mostly opaque liquid.  Dusty malt aroma.  Tastes is spicey with notes of nuts.  A little heavier than most dubbels I have had.  Vey nice, not as sweet as the St. B. 12.

Deep brown in colour with a creamy beige head.  Aroma has some malt, lots of apples, bread and some sweetness.  Flavour of malt, licorice, caramel sweetness, plums and yeast.  Finish is very malty with a medium bitterness.
UPDATED: DEC 26, 2003 Poured a murky dark brown with earthy tones under a fluffy head that left a huge curtain of lace.  Tasted slightly watery, with plum and root beer.

Deep muddy brown, perfect pillow head that lasted nicely.  Aroma has that baking bread trait I'm coming to associate with this brewer, along with some light raisin and fig notes.  Deep, complex flavors of dark pumpernikel, cherries, raisins, touch of port oriented warmth at the finish.  Fine beer.

A nice garnet color when held up to the light, otherwise this is an amber beer topped by a tan head.  A spicy musty aroma wafts from my goblet.  There are undertones of fruit in the aroma as well.  Definitely spicy tasting as well, finishes a bit hot.  This beer definitely features what Belgian yeast can do.  Lots of yeast character here.  There is a subtle malty sweetness that helps to carry the complex yeast flavors and aromas.  The spice notes from the yeast that I can differentiate are; ginger, pepper, bergamot, and cardamom.  This beer is medium bodied, though, as many Belgian beers are, it is quite light for its alcohol content.  This beer is very similar to the 6, just a little bit richer.
Has a strong aroma of raisins, and bread dough. Wonderful copper color with a lively head. This is the best of the St. Bernardus line

Dark cloudy brown. Some red hues when held up to a bright light. Big pillowy light-tan head. Sweet and spicy aroma. Some dark fruit, raisin. Flavor is sweet with lots of plum and raisin. The body is very nice, medium-full and creamy. Big fruity aftertaste. A very fine example of the style.

Thick foamy white head consisting of tiny bubbles.  Lacing shortly after pour. Dark brown color appearance.  Few belgians have this dark a color so this is very enticing.  Malty aroma with hint of chocolate.  Good malty flavor with chocoloate, and perhaps even a touch of fruitiness at the end?  Not as yeasty as I would have expected a belgian beer to be.  Good palate with complex character.
UPDATED: DEC 9, 2003 Deep copper color, with big tan head. Fruity pleasant aroma. Yeasty  malty flavor. Fruity. Pleasant to drink. Really enjoyed it.  Good stuff.
Deep copper color, with big tan head. Fruity and pleasant aroma. Yeasty fruity malt flavor. Thin with a touch of alcohol. Pleasantly drinkable. Good stuff.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Dark brown with a large head. Smells of bread and fruit, with tastes of yeast, sugar, and plum. Alcohol very evident, and seems like more than 8% ABV.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2004 Poured a dark red, brown color with a foamy off white head and nice lacing.  Sweet aroma of dark fruits, malt, caramel, and spices.  Chewy malt, candy sugar, clove, cinnamon, vanilla, and some pepper in the taste.  Very light taste of alcohol.  Carbonated mouthfeel.

Bottled: Amber coloured. Unclear. Light chocolatish brown head. Good lasting. Full malt, spices, alcahol and yeast in the nose. Malt, sweetness and fruit in the flavour. Notes of alcahol, but well hidden. Balanced beer. Has a sweet and grassy aftertaste.

Dark brown color. Medium white foamy head. Aroma is malty, bready and sweet. A medium bodied Belgian Ale. Malts are sweet and fruity. Nicely spicy. Touch of molasses, cane sugar, dark fruits (plums and cherries) and spices.  Touch of mustiness. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

Dark brown mahogany color with a nice sized head that stays until the end with enough lacing to cover the inside of the glass. The aroma has a nice mix of yeast and dark fruits with a slight hint of alcohol. The flavor is pretty sweet with a light bitter hop end. The finish is very malty and full bodied. Overall this is a well rounded and smooth BSA with a fair amount of complexities. Well deserved of its reputation.

Dark ruby red when held near a light, darkens to a nice brown away. Rather large head of small bubbles that looks to be leaving a fair lacing behind it.  Lots of bread comes out first in the nose with several fruits (plum) and some spice lying underneath. The bread/yeast is still there in the flavor though not as much. Sweet malt is there as well, some of that aforementioned fruit, finishing with a bit of an alcohol flavor that I've noticed in most of the St. Bernardus beers I have had. A nice creamy palate with some alcohol left behind in the aftertaste. A pretty good strong.
This pours an opaque walnut color with a tan/grey head that quickly disappears. It's a bit roasty in the flavor, along with some maltiness. quite enjoyable

Dark cloudy reddish brown appearance, exceelent head formation. Sweet fruit, cherry, malt aroma with strong alcohol. Throws a little fruit and bubble gum at the front of the palate turning toasty and dryish in the finish.

Very creamy, raisins and fig with distinct light cocoas. Yeasty and complex with enough bacterial twist to be interesting but unchallenging. Looks great in the glass with a generous and perfect head. I'm very glad this one arrived in Texas. I prefer the 12 but this one is really something special.

Just like the commercial description, deep hazy-brown, with a frothy tan head. Sweet like brown sugar and prunes and figs.  Delicious.  Full bodied, sweet finish.  This is one excellent Strong Ale guys and gals.

Dark rich brown color. Deep tan frothy head. Intoxicating sweet malty aroma. Has a sweet smooth body and texture. A mixed flavor of dates, raisins and other fruits ring the palate. A very drinkable and inviting  Strong Ale.
Typical cloudy brown color with a small off-white head. The aroma was full of raisins and other dark dried fruits. The flavor was very sweet, yeasty, and full of raisins. Soft feel...wet finish.

Pours a dark ruby red, with a big thick and creamy off-white head. The aroma is sweet, sour, and spicy. Malts in the beer were very noticable and dried fruits are noticable. Overall this was a very well-balanced and enjoyable beer.

The beer pours an opaque brown color, the head mountainous and light tan that is also semi-creamy in texture with the lace forming a silk like curtain to conceal the glass. Sweet malted grains, bubble gum and hints of yeast, maybe even an over ripe banana, at any rate a first class nose to be sure. Start is rich in malt, lightly sweet; the top feels full and rich. Finish has a suitable acidity and the hops are unobjectionable in their spicy bite, very dry somewhat vinous aftertaste, and the 8 percent ABV does warm the tummy, a most pleasing beer to end the day.

(bottled) Deep ruby amber color, brilliantly clear.  Velvety, rich malty nose with pronounced sour cherry & raisin aroma.  Big malt taste leads the attack followed by slightly sour fruit, raisin, peach, spicy peppery alcohol.  Assertive bitterness keeps the sweetness in check.  Strong effervescent bottle conditioning also helps lighten the feel of the big-bodied beer, lifting that flavor right into your palette whilst softening the mouthfeel. Complex and tasty. I'm sure the wild critters make this beer dynamic from batch to batch, but the aroma on this batch was especially enticing.
Bottled. Very dark brown, off white head. Raisiny vinous aroma. Sweet and full bodied. Clean but deep, plummy malt character. Complex flavoursd and a salty finish.

Very nice. And wound up being a good way to end a night of conversation and bread, cheese and fruit. I am often afraid I'll be attacked by overwhelming yeastiness in a dunbbel. Not sure which one brought that on, but this was just plain. Just plain nice. Perhaps not delicate, but extremely well rounded so that it just helped me glide to the end of a very nice evening. What more can I ask?

What a pleasant surprise.  I always thought that an 8 was suposed to be less interesting than the same company's 12!  Nose of malt and chocolate.  Appearance reddish brown and cloudy, with a decent head that fades fast.  Taste of malt, caramel, chocolate, coffee, with a sour Belgian ale taste and a bitter finish.  Mouth feel was adequate, but I did not get the same full heavy mouth feel that some other reviewers did.

Dark, murky, and ruby brown with a tan rocky head. Nice lacing. Has that charateristic tutti frutti SB aroma. Big fruity, malty and buttery nose. Heavy malt - doughy flavor. Alcohol present in nose and taste. Thick, viscous texture - chewy and bread like. Nice hearty offering. Comfort food in a beer. Mild hop presence on finish.

mahogany color, with a light tan head...excellent head. aroma is big malt with a little nuttiness and earthiness. also detect a bit of alcohol. alcohol mostly isnt present in the flavor, only a tiny bit when swirled around the tongue...some nuttiness shows up in the finish as well...different from most of the belgian strongs i've tried.
Light brown head. Brown body. Had this along side Affligem dubbel - and this was better due to a more full body and some nice spicy notes.

First off, I love the way this beer smells.  I'm not sure what the aroma is, but I would like air freshener that smells like this.  It's a doughy, malty smell; it reminds me of Westy 12.  The beer tastes almost as good as it smells too.  Good stuff, I'm glad I bought it.

I love the old fashiones label, reminiscint of a '60's version of a Women's Weekly or Mr Sheen ad. Great bold colour and nice subtle fruity nose of peach and plum. There is a good crystal malt and toffee overtone in the taste with a subtle backdrop of hops. Fine lacing in the (Chimay) glass and a good finish. Another BSA that goes into the high ratings I feel.
user_location: Potts Point, New South Wales, AUSTRALIA

text: Light aroma, malty and some yeast. A bit of sour milk, acidic. Fruity. Light tan frothy lacing head over cloudy copper-brown liquid. Medium thick body with medium heavy carb. Alcohol, brown sugar, sediment yeast. Sweet malts but little hops. Fruity but finish is bitter and a bit chalky and musty. Maybe a bad bottle.

Dark hazy brown with a deep reddish amber hue when held up to light. Big frothy head which settles down to a creamy foamy layer. Aroma is a rich fruity and malty one with notes of cherries and dates. Body is creamy and medium to full but not as full as the Abt12. Flavor is slightly sweet and slightly bitter with a bit of a dry finish. Malt is big as well as fruit and yeast. Nice brew but I prefer the Abt12 over this one.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Dark musty, hazy brown colour with ruby highlights and a very dense micro-bubble comprised tan head. Aroma of sour  cherries, malt, raisins must and a bit of dark fruit (grapes & apples) sweetness. Medium-bodied; Strong maltiness,  assertive sweetness and a subtle sourness that only lasts for a few seconds right at the beginning of the taste.  Aftertaste bittered from the malt and a bit of subtle chocolate flavour (not initially picked up). An odd combination of  all these different essences and tastes, but it works out very well. This is somewhat similar to the Abt 12, and if you  liked that...definately pick this one up! Overall, this beer is a bit better than average for a style which already  represents so many VERY good beers! I bought this 33 cL bottle at Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, New York and sampled it on  1-September-2003.

Dark, dark brown with a medium, longlasting head of a light tan color; very smooth feel and taste; the taste is malty and slightly sweet; a pleasant touch of bitterness in the finish; I'd like to try this side-by-side with the others from this same brewery
Very good belgian. Went down easy.  Don't know what else to say.  Really.  I'm done.

Dayton, OH AleFest:This beer had a medium sized ivory head that contained fine-small sized bubbles.The body was slghtly hazy with some carbonation noted.The hue of this beer was brown and the nose was that of alcohol and malt.The flavor was malty and hoppy.The mouthfeel of this beer was smooth, tingly, watery, and light-medium bodied.This beer also had average lacing.

This brew poured a medium head of medium sized bubbles that were mostly lasting .  The body was a softly carbonated semi-transparent dark brown color.  THe aroms wasmildly malted with some yeast and its mouthfeel wasbubbly while bein of smooth palate and a mildly bitter finish.  The flavor contained notes of caramel and malt.  Not as complex as I was expecting.

8/17/03:  bottle.   yeasty aroma with some notes of alcohol.  big frothy almond colored head accompanied by a nice red-brown body.  good amount of lacing.  lots of flavors, which include raisins, plums, malt, hops, honey, alcohol and even a little bit of peach.  towards the finish there is a faint hint of sourness.

Dark brown body with a thin, light tan head. Some lacing.
Big raisin/plum aroma when the bottle was opened. Malt, bread and alcohol seem to dominate the aroma. Sweetness is in there too.
Nice malt/raisin/plum flavor dominates. A bread-like yeastiness is quite prevalent too. A slight hop bite in the end.
Very smooth palate with a great crisp finish. Nicely carbonated with tiny champagne-like bubbles.

This beer pours a cloudy brown color with a nice full head and just a little lacing on the glass.  The aroma was very fruity with some yeast and alcohol notes.  The flavor is very much the same as the aroma.  It is fruity, malty, and slightly spicy, but very smooth and enjoyable.  This is a very nice Belgian.

The aroma is sweet, fruity with notes of plums - a pretty complex aroma. The color is a deep red and it has a small beige head though fast disappearing. The flavor is sweet and rich in fruit; plums, raisins, and prunes. The alcohol ticles the tongue which combines with the bitterness into a dry end. It has a good palate which in combination with the alcohol makes it rather winous.
Dark brown. Fine off-white head. The aroma...well I did not find it very appealing - has some hensfood tendencies. Better flavor though, yeasty  with notes of rasins and prune.

Aroma: nice grape-ish malts with tanic overtones. Palate: smoothly carbonated and sultry. Appearance: dark lacy and earthen. Flavor: apple plum and grape tones to complex to sort orchestrated with an earthy musk. Dee-lect-able. Overall: smooth, tasty and refreshing. Here's too tradition and the art of finely crafted beers.

Poured a dark brown with fluffy tan head. Has a huge yeasty dough aroma which was nice. Loved the aroma. Has a slight fruit/spice flavor and still very yeasty. I tasted a little banana. A very nice beer.

Had from bottle on July 23rd, 2003 - Day 23 of Blake's Beer MonthAfter a short respite in the ratings, I'm back and ready to go on a run - with a Stone tasting coming up Friday and Dogfish Day still to come, Blake's Beer Month rolls on.The St. Bernardus Prior 8 is an interesting beer - has a strong taste which hits the taste buds with full force.  Brown in color with a red hue, the head is tan and lasts from start to finish, though it diminishes slightly.  The aroma is yeasty/doughy with a tartness that balances out the bread yeast - a bit of alcohol is evident as well.  The beer's flavor exhibits quite a bit of alcohol with a sweetness of fruits and some nutty goodness as well.  The beer itself was an interesting concept, but a bit too strong - quite a bit of alcohol and a bit too sweet as well.  An impressive beer, but not one of my faves.Quick Re-rate:The beer gets surprisingly better as it gets warmer - perhaps just a tad bit too cold at the start, the full complexity of the beer was not blended well.  As it gets warmer, the flavors all blend together beautifully as it becomes much easier to drink with a flavoring of alcohol that is not quite as strong.  The sweetness is still there, but blends well with the malts - a much better beer as it warms up - do not have this one too cold.  Flavor up 1, Overall up 1.

Make sure you have a glass handy when you open this one, either that or a bar rag. Brown in color with a huge head that lasted all the way down. Yeasty, with raisin and cinnamon aromas. Full bodied and very sweet, with caramel, plum and alcohol flavors. Finish lingers and is sweet, with a faint bitterness. This beer is interesting and has an awesome aroma, but the candylike nature of it was a little much for me.

UPDATED: JUL 19, 2003 Pours a deep deep brown.  Large head that has staying power.  The aroma is all yeast and sweet.  Some dark fruit flavors in the flavor (plum, prune, raisin.)  Quite a bit of malt, the alcohol flavor is nicely balanced.
Large tan head, a bit liverly. Fruit and raisons, some sugary sweetness. Very malty, very smooth. Nice Dubbel.

Bottled. Well conditioned. This beer was everything you expected from a trappist double. Brown with a bold, fluffy white head, sweat malt aroma with vanilla and cinnamon flavours mixed in around the nutty roasted malt flavours. Not all that on the finish but still a quality drop.

Big head on the cloudy brown stuff. Wafts of fruti and cheese and some caramel sweetness. In a velvetty mouthful it maintains these points and adds nutty qualities to boot. definitely a new favorite, but cost is a consideration.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2003 aroma of raisons, sugar, twisslers, toffee. appearance is cloudy brown, fizzy head dissipates to thin layer. Soothing malt taste with caramel, sweet w/slight bitterness coming through at the finish.
Color is yellow non-transparent with a nice white stable head. Taste is malty with sweet hints and a kind of a spicy finish.
a very malty nose, not a very large head but it almost remained the same over the 20 minutes I was drinking this. Malty taste with hints of caramel, chocolate and some spices. Very sweet also..

Strong dark fruit notes in the nose, along with banana.  Very rich copper/brown body, topped with a nice, creamy tan head.  Intense, rich flavor of candied fruit, fermented banana, tart, and caramel.  A liquid pleasure.

Best by the end of 2004.  Very dark in color with a nice little head that slowly goes away.  The bubble pattern on the glass is very fine.  Nice nose that is very complex.  Malty front with subtle fruity flavors weaving in and out to a sweet finish.  The end is strong on the caramel and has an ever so slight bitter touch that is only noticable because of the strong sweetness.  The sides of my tongue tingle a little.  Excellent.  This bottle seems to be at its peak because the malt is not so dominant and the subtle flavors have room to linger.

Nice deep dark pour, with flawless lacework. Smelling of raisins, bananas, fruit cocktail. first sip says ultimate complexity, very well rounded Ale. Flavours of Plums, gorgeous Belgian sugar, caramel,fresh baked bread. I would drive back To Indianapolis for more of this, Glad I bought 2 bottles, I had to drive through the "hood" to find this store as Indy is under some serious road construction, hell I think I might would drive through Baghdad if I had to so I could get some more of this, Extremely Recommended!
Lovely, lasting head. Delicious rich fruitcake flavors. Malty clove and allspice. This reminded me of Chimay blue but more intense and flavorful. Near perfect on all fronts.

Deep dark brown with a  beige head, and a lot of lacing. Aroma was fruity and sweet with a little alcohol. Flavor was of dark fruits- plum, raisin, and black cherries. Smooth finish with some alcohol warming. A quality beer.

Deep, dark chestnut brown brew with a thick tan head.Nose is big,sweet and alcohol laced. Flavor is full of plum and raisin with a candy like sweetness and a big alcohol bite at the finish.Medium bodied. No match for the Abt 12.
UPDATED: JUN 18, 2003 Dark brown color, big beige head, heavy lacing. Aroma is sweet, vinious fruit, candy. Flavor is sweet, and candylike. Has a little bitterness and acidity.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2003 Slight but pleasant aroma, some dark breadiness, toffee and candi-ish sweetness, just a little bit vinous and raisiny.  Murky brownish red in color with a fine, ivory colored head.  Flavor is estery, richly malty and sweet, with a touch of red apple, spices, toffee and cocoa.  Very smooth palate, moderately full body.  Some faint hop flavors and alcohol emerge on the finish after warming.  Enjoyable, reasonably complex and satisfying.

Cousin to the Tripel I guess; same massive creamy lacey head, this time topping a deep burgundy body.  Nose a bit faint, but malty chocolate-banana tinges are there.  Creamy and silky on the tongue, with much caramel and brown sugar, and those candied bananas again.  Not on the level of the 12, but truly excellent and for me another confirmation that I generally like the "brown" Belgian ale styles more than the "golden" ones.

Brown sugar, caramel and candied malt aromas, the colour of a pomegranate. Explosion of foam ocurred after opening, still poured a fair sized toffee head, with some floaties. Toffee and caramel flavours, candied malt after taste, plums too. Complex, full bodied, very dry finish. Another fine one!

Big creamy beige head, full lasting. Dark brown-mohagany color. Aroma is sweet, malty, slightly vinous with vanilla and raisins notes. Flavour is malty too, slightly fruity with tones of caramel, more balanced. Finish is moderately dry with touch of candy sugar. Full bodied.
Had this at 't Brugs Beertje on 5-15-03. Cloudy brown body. Fluffy tan head. Nice sweet cocoa aroma. Sweet malty taste with slight spice. Finishes dry with definite malt notes.
I swear this was sooo sweet it had maraschino cherry-like flavors, but it worked because the big effervescence and later warming brought out cask woodishness and normal bruney malt depth. Quite good.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Rich brown body with a big thick, even, dense head.  Plenty of sediment, looks tasty!  Ripe fruits prevail, mostly dates and raisins, some alcohol and a hint of spice.  Some definite yeastiness and  Perhaps some woody notes as well.  Malty domination in the mouth, earthiness, and dates in a rich velvety, pretty lively palate.  Nicer as it warms, smoother and sweeter. Good stuff.
raisin aroma, choclate colored with a big tight head, seems to have a lot more carbonation than Westy 8, mediciny, silky and lots of raisin and barley flavors

UPDATED: JUN 20, 2004 Rating #1 (8 4 8 4 18) - Tap from the Toronado Belgian beer month.  Deep mahogany color with a foamy tan head.  The aroma has dark fruits, vinous, raisins, dates, plums, and cherry.  Rich and full with a little zesty feel on the palate.  Sweet and a good balance in the texture and malts.  Rating #2 (7 4 8 4 17) Bottle.  A deep brown color with a light brown head.  Bananas - lots of it both in the aroma and flavor.  Spiced flavors with a dry finish.
Draft - Dark brown color.  Great aroma.  This was a great beer with a long finish.

Deep, hazy brown/red. A head that does not quit. Nose of mineral water, caramel, cocolate, nuts, some dark fruit, cookie dough and yeast. Medium bodied, sweet with upfront flavors of rummy alcohol, cookie dough, spices and raisons. Then shifts and turns a bit thinner with some bitterness, yeasty sourness and acidity. Makes for a nice interplay. Maybe a bit yeasty heavy but a tasty brew! Alcohol is hidden nicely, balance is good and has a soft feel.

Oops. Opened the bottle of this one and ended up with 1/4 of it over myself. Huge flowing head out of the bottle. Once it was in the glass (eventually) it had a great muddy/cloudy brown colour with medium browny long lasting head. Lovely aroma of dark fruit with hints of caramel. Very fruity. Great body, hint of alcohol in the taste even at room temp serving (around 15). Nice fruity taste, slightly yeasty. Dark fruit in the taste too. Nice balanced drop. Loses 2 overall points from me though for the excessive bottle carbonation.
UPDATED: MAY 7, 2003 A great beer.Raisin bubblegum, caramel are a few of the flavors I taste. Aroma is strong. Finishes bold at the end but still has carbonation.
An excellent beer.  I love tha tguy on the label too...he makes good beer typically.  Dark, murky in color, average head.  Fruity and yeasty....simple and to the point, but very well balanced.

Bottle.  Brown, big head, sloshy pour.  Tastes more like an excellent dubble than anything else to me.  Bready, thick, yeasty, excellent.  So why do Belgian breweries number most of their beers with even numbers?  St. Bernardus does have a Triple 9.  What about a triple 6?  Or maybe an abt 7?

A curious beer that meets many of my expectations but proves disappointing in a few respects.  It pours with a slightly-looser than idea head (not creamy though moderately small bubbles).  The body is cloudy brown, though an off-brown through the light.  The aroma is the strong suitlovely flavors jumping out, raisin and bubblegum, but also caramel, vinous and sweet.  The flavor is surprisingly more dry with a particularly salty note that was the biggest disappointment to my tongue, not to mention a hint of chicken fajitas.  The palate remains vigorous, in part because of the tongue-curdling saltiness but also because of continuing zinging carbonation.  In the end, it is bold enough and lively enough to be an enjoyable beer-hunting experience, but not quite the well-rounded composition of the top tier of Belgians.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2007 Bottle... This beer rocks!...
It has a forbidding murky copper hue and a large, rocky & creamy khaki-colored head. The head is everlasting and leaves excellent, thick lacework on the glass.
The aroma is incredible and complex. Moderately malty & hoppy and very yeasty. Notes of dark bread dough, butter, English toffee, milk chocolate, herbs, flowers, grass, alcohol, lye soap, earth, mildew, dark raisins, cask-aged tawny port and alcohol. Underneath it all is a very small note of cola.
The flavor is very rich and malty with bursts of warm alcohol and buttery caramel up front. EXTREMELY WELL BALANCED with just the right amount of bitter and pungent hops, warm alcohol and a prunish, slightly tart combo on the backside. The flavor and balance reminds me a lot of Westvleteren Extra 8. Full-bodied with an oily mouthfeel and slightly lively carbonation.
Long, acrid, dry finish with a shot of clover and caramel at the wee end.
Thanks go out to Britt Rife in Annapolis for this one. Thanks!!!
Excellent beer!
Heavy alcohol aroma but thankfully not as prevalent in flavoring. Great brown coloring with a chocolate colored head. Lots of residual sugar on the palate. More maltiness would help.

Quickly diminishing light brown head.  Very dark brown in color.  Fairly strong aroma of alcohol.  The alcohol is not nearly as apparent in the flavor as the aroma would have indicated.  Flavor complexity increases exponentially as it warms, as can be expected.  A little bit of a sweetness emerges along with some yeastiness.  I think I can taste some plums, raisins, currents kind of flavors in there.  Not bad, all together.

This beer poured a dark amber color and formed an off white foamy head that disapted leaving circular lace. A medium amount of carbonation is present. An aroma of malt and caramel. A flavor of malt, caramel and slight touch of butterscotch. A fairly light finish to it, with little elements present that make up the flavor and aroma. A good beer, but not the best by this brewer, however.

Bespeckled mohagany color with a tall light tan head. Heavy malt aroma with undertones of light fruit and alcohol.  This is a double with a kick.  Light sweetness in the start with flavor of exotic fruits.  Finishes with a rum and brandy quality that reminds me of a "tom & jerry" on a cold winter night.  Has some hints of iron and blood that add to the complexity. This is a true winter warmer.
Plums and brown sugar dominate the flavor. Smells like cherries and other fruits.  Pretty decent beer - mild and easy to drink.

This smells and tastes a lot like pez, and I LOVES me some pez!  Big malt nose, hazy brown, highly carbonated.  Yeasty flavor with lots of fruits - raisins, bananas, cherries, etc.  The marriage of beer and candy.  Reminds me quite a bit of Westy 8, but not quite as good.
Quality belgian, yet outclassed by others in its arena.  I would definitely suggest you try it.  Could very well see this being somebody's fave.  :)
Great Belgian ale.  Flavors of plums malt and spice.  Finishes dry, clean, and bittersweet.  Recomended.

Thick dark brown with a voluptuous head.  Sweet caramel yeasty aroma with some candi sugar.  Body is rich and fulfilling with good complexity and a smooth, sweet oak finish.  Very little alcohol is noticeable.

Has a very cloudy reddish brown color with heavy carbonation and smells of alcohol.  Taste is of alcohol and has a similar finish, but the alcohol flavors are not as strong as the Abt 12.  Overall again the Belgian ale does not seem to be something I like too much, which is a shame because everyone else on the site seems to enjoy them so much.  Perhaps it will come in time.

Hazy brown beer with a fantastic long lasting off white head.  Dark fruit(plums and raisins) and malty aroma; followed by buttery(diacetyl) and slightly alcohol aromas; Cloves, yeast, and pepper also present, and with a slight banana ester.  Very malty and alcoholic flavored, with the darker fruits behind the scene.  The flavor is more peppery than cloves from a phenolic standpoint, but both are apparent but not overwhelming adding to complexity;  Some yeastiness also shows as it warms.  Very well balanced but slightly on the dry side as a finish and very clean aftertaste.  Alcohol is warming, not burning; higher carbonation, although not as high as other Belgian styles, seems to lighten the medium body.  At least is seems to be medium bodied, not full like the commercial description.  Very nice overall mouthfeel, not harsh or astringent and very drinkable.  In my opinion, this is the best St. Bernardus I've had of the 3 I've rated, but I do have to re rate one.  I would say this is a dubbel rather than a strong ale, but very nicely made.

Beautiful!!! This one came off of draft at Lucky Baldwins and appeared before me a dark dark dark ruby red color with a light tannish head. The aroma was very enticing with plums, malt, and cherries coming to mind. The taste is very smooth and clean finishing. Plum and malt dominate the taste, total black currant taste going on here...just wonderful. Very dry bittersweet ending given the plums with the alcohol hidden well until the very last sip. Very little carbonation to be found and incredibly smooth, just nice!!!!

Pours a dark, cloudy brown color with a small, lingering off-white head. The aroma is strong and fruity, with touches of plums, raisons, yeast, spices, and a hint of alcohol. Full bodied, fruity, and very rich, the flavor is full of malts, plums, bananas,caramel, and yeast with a thick bready finish. A damn fine beer.

Is that Sean Connery on the lable? Anyway pours a off-white head and a deep red-brown colour. Fairly complex fruity nose and all the triple falvours are there - plums in particular, has a nice sweet finish. Good stuff.
Sweet caramel aroma with a hint of alcohol.Flavors of candy sugar,bananas,bubble gum.Very mild hops at the finish.
The flavors of the triple and the abt are present but lighter. Wonderful option if you want something a bit more easy-drinking, perhaps with dinner. Save the Abt for dessert.
Poured a deep brownish orange color. Chewy, hints of chocolate chip cookie dough, brown sugar. Dry finish.

This poured with a generous head and everlasting active carbonation.  Very dark - held it up to the light to see dark orange.  Felt very foamy up front - not a sharp carbonation - soft.  Medium thick chocolate and fruit (and of course, me, I taste some anise again).  Finishes on the back-roof of the mouth - is there a little hops there too?  Very clean on the tongue at the end.  I liked it.

Sweet/dark fruit and chocolate aroma. Very rich malt...very sweet candy sugar/ bubble gum flavor. Sweeter than I expected. Very soft mouthfeel. Decent balance...finish is sweet with hints of chocolate and bursts of fruit, especially banana...maybe a bit lingering as well. Not as good as the 12.
Alcohol evident with the spice (clove).  Thiny mouthfeel but very fruity with yeasty characteristics.  Estery palate at the end that I really like.  I enjoyed the Abt 12 much more.

Head is initially large, frothy, light brown, mostly lasting. Body is murky dark orange-brown, bottle conditioned. Aroma is moderately yeasty (dough, soap), lightly malty (caramel, nutty), with light notes of clove and toffee. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Medium body, velvety texture, lively carbonation. The St. Bernard brews are just too yeasty (stinky doughy/soapy yeast) for me to enjoy fully.

Pours a color that is both dark ruby, brown and orange.  The persistent head is tan/off-white.  The aroma is both fruity and yeasty, and is made up of cherries, plums, bread, honey, and currant.  The flavors are quite nice, most of the fruit is evident, as is a bit of toffee and chocolate.  A nice feel in the mouth and a moderate finish.  I think I enjoyed this more than the 12.
Sweet aroma with a bit of spicy hoppiness.  Aroma is attractive, similar to the abt 12, but not as strong or as lingering. Taste is fairly straightforward, but with some nice texture.  Very nice.

Opaque cola colored with small tan head.  Aroma is sweet, dark-fruity, caramel, some berry.  Taste is sweet and malty up front, fruity (plum/raisin).  Finishes nice and fruity sweet, with minimal alcohol.  Fairly light body.  Tasty.

Pours with a creamy, lasting head. Color, like weak coffee. Unbelievable aromas, starting chilled from the fridge with nice fresh hops, and bready malt, warming and evolving to include,  vanilla, some chocolate, fruits, mainly banana and cocoanut, also sour mash whiskey. Nice roasted malt flavor, less complex than the aroma, but nice -  sweet, fruity, lightly bitter with come coffee and a noticeable alcohol presence. Really, really nice though not as luscious in the mouth as the Westy/Rocheforts these St Bernardus beers have been compared to.

Cloudy dark brown.  Lovely, huge puffy head that evaporates down to a consistent, thin creamy coating.  Nice nose, full of candy sugars.  Notice some raisins and a promising sourness, also a bit metallic.  Flavor is very malty, deep fruitiness predominated by plums and molasses.  Slightly pungent.  Sugars reminscent of rock candy, nicely zinger.  Has subtle hints of pears wrapped in nutmeg cream.  Texture is very smooth and creamy.  Masks the 8% beautifully.  Prefer this to the Westy 8.

Full name of sampled is: St bernardus Prior 8 Cuvée 2002, and comes in screenprinted 75cl. bottles. No real indication of a brewing difference.
Nose of candi sugar, roasted malts, and something quite fresh, as fresh mint or sage leaf.Woody.
Taste first like wet brown sugar, then overlying bitterness takes over: some hops, some dark malts; Again shrubwood, mouldy-but-nice, some liquorice. Perfumey, balance between bitterness and sweet nearly perfect.
Mouthfeel is quite chewy, much depth - alcohol is there allright.
long, spicey diminishing of the former impressions dominate the finish. Great beer indeed.
Very yeasty nose – like bread dough. Hazy deep copper color and a low tight head. Meaty middle of heavy sweet malt and very spicey. Thick and syrupy texture. Cool.
Chocolate, molasses, malt and alcohol nose. Brown with hints of orange, little fizzy head on top. Honey, chocoloate, fruite (apricots) taste. Pricks on the tongue.

Bottle conditioned. Chestnut red with a good rocky head and lively condition that stirred up some sediment. Big malty nose laced with yeast and hints of whisky. Thick and chewy mouthful of raisins and spicy malt and more yeast and a long sweet chalky finish.

750ml corked bottle/2002: Light brown liquid,with a fluffy,tan,long-lasting head. Lacework is dreamy! Aromas are fruity,spicy,bready, lightly sweet. As it warms balanced sweet/fruity aromas dominate. Mouthfeel is soft but has a thickness about it. Body is big like description says, with maybe just a touch to much carbonation. Flavors are sweet,then biscuity/fruity with a chocolate,fruit,quite bitter finish. Finish seems a bit toasty as well. The little yeast,I let,get into my glass,didnt do much to change the flavor. If anything it added acidity,to the hardly acidic mouthfeel. The flavors are ever-changing and keep getting more interesting. Very good brew!
Spicy aroma.  In the beginning I didnt like the flavout at all, but after a while I really appreciated it.

[Keg] Dark color; generous and thick head, perfect lace. Some caramel and light roasted malt aroma; spicy. Full mouth, good balance, leaning on the sweet side in the front, turning into a more bitter ending, again spicy and with caramel.
